IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder (OUD) prevalence rates have reached unprecedented levels among adolescents and emerging adults, and treatment engagement and retention for this population are alarmingly poor. For youth with substance use disorders, developmental theory underscores the primacy of family-level risk and protective factors, and family-based interventions have the strongest empirical support. This study will systematically build a research and technical assistance infrastructure designed to develop and evaluate innovative family- based recovery support services for youth with OUD that span the all phases of the services cascade: screening and referral, treatment initiation, treatment delivery, and continuing care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 1 diabetes (T1D), a prototypic CD4 T cell mediated autoimmune disease, is believed to have a prolonged pre-clinical phase that lasts many years. We will use circulating anti-insulin CD4 T cells as a real-time biomarker of islet autoimmunity to diagnose subclinical disease in at-risk population and decide of therapeutic intervention. The proof of principle of this approach has been established in a small cohort of patients enrolled in the TrialNet consortium.

PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is an infectious disease that continues to cause extensive morbidity and mortality throughout tropical and sub-tropical regions of the developing world, especially among young children in sub-Saharan Africa. This project focuses on the ability of malaria parasites to avoid the human immune response and to cause severe disease. A better understanding of these processes will lead to new forms of treatment that will help to relieve the enormous public health burden that malaria inflicts on the developing world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Impaired astrocyte coupling is associated with epilepsy, but there is no consensus on whether reduced coupling promotes or counteracts abnormal neuronal activity, which precedes seizures. Targeting astrocytic Cx43 might be an option, but the first step towards therapy is determining when reduced coupling is adaptive and when it is maladaptive. This proposal uses new tools and technology to determine if the timing and duration of reduced astrocyte coupling may determine if seizures are promoted or counteracted, and will identify critical upstream signaling causing reduced astrocyte coupling as a foundation for future therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The COVID-19 pandemic represents the 3rd outbreak caused by zoonotic transmission of a beta-coronavirus (beta-CoV) in the last 20 years, and new vaccine strategies are urgently needed to ensure rapid global distribution, lasting protection against variants of concern (VOCs), and prevention of future CoV pandemics. The proposed research is based on the EBR nanoparticle (NP) technology that modifies membrane proteins such as the SARS-CoV-2 spike (S) protein to self-assemble into virus-resembling NPs that bud from the cell surface. The EBR technology will be applied to accomplish three goals: i) Design a hybrid mRNA vaccine that combines attributes of mRNA and protein NP vaccines by encoding the self-assembling S-EBR NP construct to enhance vaccine potency against SARS-CoV-2 and VOCs; ii) Engineer S-EBR NPs to package and deliver mRNAs encoding S or S-EBR as an alternative to lipid NPs for efficient, targeted, and cost-effective mRNA vaccine delivery; iii) Design mosaic S-EBR NP-based universal CoV vaccine candidates that present S proteins from multiple CoV strains to elicit cross-reactive immune responses against a broad spectrum of CoVs and protect against future outbreaks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lifestyle interventions including physical activity appear to confer important protections to the brain that may delay the onset of symptoms of dementia. Dance movement is a form of physical activity that is promising as a potential activity to help maintain brain health, because it improves cardiorespiratory fitness and balance while providing cognitive challenge and social engagement, all important for maintaining brain health. This proposal seeks to fill key gaps in our basic understanding about the effects of the number of times per week people engage in dance movement on cardiorespiratory fitness and cognition that are essential for planning larger, definitive trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Airway protective disorders are a prevalent and progressive consequence of Parkinson’s Disease (PD), and often result in aspiration pneumonia which is the leading cause of death in PD, yet few efficacious treatments are available for people with PD and additionally many patients with PD do not access to specialized services to address these critical deficits. This critical clinical-research gap must be addressed by a diverse workforce of scholars with expertise in airway protection and its rehabilitation. As a Landis Mentorship supplement, our parent award (R01 NS126319-01) will serve as a living classroom from and through which research and enriching training opportunities will be developed to enrich the training experiences of current and future trainees in airway protection and its rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergy exerts substantial impact on affected individuals, their families, and society, including lifestyle limitations and reductions in quality of life. This application from the Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC), will address the following goals: (1) establish the VUMC CoFAR CRC, which will rapidly implement and execute single site and multi-center clinical trials, with high quality and fidelity, focused on the prevention and management of patients with food allergy, supplemented by studies to better elucidate the mechanisms underlying food allergies; (2) develop and conduct a consortium-wide, multi-center, clinical trial to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of once weekly peanut feeding (low weekly peanut protein dose) versus thrice weekly peanut feedings (standard weekly peanut protein dose) in the prevention of peanut allergy in infants at high risk for the development of peanut allergy; and (3) to better understand the alpha-gal syndrome (AGS), specifically why some patients in tick-endemic areas develop clinically evident AGS after a bite, while others do not, and why the clinical expression of AGS is variable amongst patients and changes over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative CCNE1 is amplified in 20-30% of uterine serous carcinoma (USC), but little is understood about how CCNE1 drives the aggressiveness of this disease. In this study, we will assess the DNA repair proficiency of these tumors in addition to exploring new metabolic therapeutic strategies to sensitize these tumors to standard-of-care chem- otherapy. The results will have a direct impact on the development of novel strategies to obtain a therapeutic response in CCNE1hi USC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE When autologous tissue is not available or split thickness skin grafts alone are used, full thickness skin loss may not heal or will heal by contracture of the surrounding skin. Current treatment approaches including engineered off the shelf products have significant limitations, including slow, inconsistent, and inadequate tissue formation, hence impaired wound healing. The commercialization of DermiSphereTM is expected to improve clinical practice in surgical fields where full thickness skin loss is common including, but not limited to, trauma, burns, and post- oncologic reconstructive surgery, by significantly decreasing the time required to achieve a healed wound, as well as increasing the thickness of the regenerated dermis in a scenario of full thickness skin loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a deadly blood cancer that occurs mostly in adults over 65 and is associated with the abnormal overproliferation of blood stem cells, a common age-related condition called 'clonal hematopoiesis' (CH). Although we know that aging and specific gene mutations in the blood stem cells contribute to the development of CH and its progression to AML, we do not understand how old age and CH interact to promote the evolution of AML. Here, we will elucidate how aging and CH influence the propensity of blood stem cells to adapt to altered environments (“evolvability”), which could not only forge a new paradigm for our understanding of leukemia onset but also provide candidate pathways for the development of preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE By modulating the activity of ligand gated ion channels (LGICs) and G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), complex natural products have the potential to reveal critical insight into the function of these therapeutically important membrane receptors. This proposal investigates the synthesis and evaluation of two classes of natural products and their development into new chemical tools to investigate LGIC and GPCR pharmacology. By providing new directions to rationally design small molecules that engage their receptors targets, the results from this research will ultimately lead to safer, more effective medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement This proposal incorporates innovative, multi-disciplinary approaches to investigate mechanisms governing the regulation of cardiac contraction in health and disease. The ultimate goal is to markedly advance fundamental knowledge of striated muscle regulation and inform the rational design of tailored therapeutic interventions that could potentially improve cardiac muscle function in diseased hearts. Therefore, this proposal has substantial health relevance and is directly in line with the mission of the National Institutes of Health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The atomic-level details of lipid/enzyme interactions and the determinants of their specificity remain poorly understood, despite their importance in biosynthesis and modification of cellular membranes, and in the assembly and use of lipid conjugates for essential cellular functions such as glycosylation. By applying a structural biology-based integrated approach to enzymes that are involved in assembly of the peptidoglycan layer and modification of the lipopolysaccharide component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, biosynthesis of the mycobacterial cell well and processes of protein glycosylation, we will gain testable hypotheses on the basic principles of substrate recognition, and on how membrane, membrane enzymes, and lipidic substrates interact to facilitate these reactions. These data should also provide pathways toward new classes of therapeutics targeting lipid/enzyme active sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goals of this project are to develop a marmoset model system to represent the neurobiology of the human brain and to develop a novel pluripotent stem cell/male germline-mediated transgenesis approach to advance the utility of the marmoset model to benefit the brain health research community. This supplement will introduce a promising undergraduate student from an underrepresented groups and disadvantaged background to this cutting-edge research in marmosets using bioinformatics to stimulate her continued interest in pursuit of research careers and provide her with key skills to make her a competitive applicant for MD-PhD programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disease with altered epigenomics and associated with high mortality. This proposal will explore if blocking Brd4, an epigenetic regulator, will block the upregulation of profibrotic genes thus alter the cell phenotype. This study will evaluate the efficacy of using Brd4 inhibitor as a therapeutic method to improve the resolution of persistent lung fibrosis; the completion of this study will further our understanding of this deadly disease and uncover novel therapeutic molecular targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Brain-immune crosstalk in myocardial infarction Project Narrative Myocardial infarction (MI) remains a leading cause of death worldwide. MI healing and functional recovery are critically determined by the immune system. This project combines state-of-the-art tools of neuroscience, cardiology, and immunology to investigate how the brain orchestrates the immune response to an MI and evaluates an innovative approach to improve MI outcomes by stimulating and inhibiting specific brain centers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Predicting and controlling polygenic health traits using probabilistic models and evolution-inspired gene editing PROJECT NARRATIVE: DNA is passed down with multiple errors per generation, some mutations being beneficial, but the majority being neutral or causing health disorders. We can now correct these with CRISPR/Cas9, but the models that predict the consequences of such gene interventions are still not robust. I will conduct large-scale experiments with the plant A. thaliana to investigate the predictability of fitness impacts of DNA errors in many environmental conditions, and safely trial new gene editing approaches to reduce the number of mutations arising per generation and shift their beneficial-to-deleterious ratio.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic neuropathies due to heritable diseases, glaucoma, trauma or inflammation are a major cause of blindness in humans, but no effective treatments exist for the vision impairment that occurs with them. The goal of this project is to advance the speed and efficiency of research to improve retinal ganglion cell function, the cells damaged with these diseases, by developing a new nonhuman primate model of autosomal dominant optic neuropathy. This new and better animal model will speed the development and testing of innovative therapies by our team and others that will reduce the morbidity caused by optic neuropathies in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After an initial infection with many pathogens, the immune system provides protection against re-infection with the same pathogen. However, infection of the human female reproductive tract with Chlamydia trachomatis provides limited protection against reinfection, and reoccurring infections can cause permanent damage and infertility. The goal of this proposal is to 1) determine why the cells of the immune system fail to provide protection against C. trachomatis, and 2) reprogram these faulty cells using new vaccine approaches to provide protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Medical Science Training Program (MSTP) at the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW) provides integrated basic science and medical training as the educational foundation for future academic physician scientists. The mission of MCW-MSTP is to prepare students for careers as physician-scientists, which allows students to conduct hypothesis-driven research and to practice evidence-based medicine as an MD-PhD. MCW-MSTP welcomes all applicants, including students of diversity, students with disabilities, and students from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Cognitive resilience to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and brain aging is a phenomenon whereby an individual’s cognitive functioning is better than predicted based on chronological age, genetic risk, and/or advanced neuropathology. Understanding the protective factors that improve cognitive resilience requires comprehensive identification of the protein components of unique brain cell types – an analysis that cannot be performed longitudinally in human patients. In this project, we will combine human clinical and molecular data with proteomic data from neurons and immune cells from the hippocampus of mice that are resilient and susceptible to cognitive decline to identify novel proteins and complexes that could ultimately be therapeutically targeted to delay or prevent cognitive symptoms in AD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells differ in their mechanical properties depending on their metastatic potential when measured in vitro. Understanding the role that a cell’s mechanotype plays in vivo at each step of the metastatic cascade will be critical for developing new diagnostics and therapeutic targets for metastatic disease, the cause of a majority of cancer-related deaths. This proposal seeks to understand the heritability of cell stiffness and the advantage or disadvantage conferred by cell stiffness to metastasis through the combination of high-throughput microfluidic mechanical screening, in vivo mouse metastasis models, and multi-omic analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a pilot project to assess whether antibody-drug conjugates, an emerging class of anti-cancer drugs, are a viable treatment option for patients with uterine serous carcinoma. Briefly, we will survey a series of uterine cancer tissues to determine whether they express proteins that are targeted by antibody-drug conjugates, and then investigate whether we can combine antibody-drug conjugates with other therapies to increase their efficacy, especially in patients who show or develop resistance. We anticipate that our studies will seed future clinical trials of new treatment options for patients with uterine cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Oral health during pregnancy and postpartum has significant impact on a woman’s overall health, birth outcomes and their child’s oral health. This study will provide evidence on how the generosity of state Medicaid dental benefits during pregnancy and postpartum impacts access to routine and emergent dental care. Understanding the effects of dental benefits generosity and duration is critical to inform policy decision-making and implementation of recent expansions of Medicaid dental benefits for pregnant and postpartum women aimed to improve maternal health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has evolved into an indispensable tool in clinical medicine and biomedical research. Yet, due to its high cost to purchase, site, and maintain, access to MRI is limited to mainly well-funded medical centers or research institutions. This project will test a new silent MRI technology that simplifies the MRI system in terms of its hardware components, cost, size, weight, and infrastructure requirements. Future portable MRI scanners based on this technology have a chance of empowering communities in remote, resource-limited settings to address health inequities, build local capacity for better health, improve understanding of brain development and degeneration in diverse populations, and enable access to high quality clinical care worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to create viscoelastic dynamic double network (DDN) hydrogels to define the influence of matrix properties on the generation of pancreatic organoids from induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC). The viscoelastic DDN hydrogels are integrated from two interpenetrating networks, one elastic and one viscoelastic. This will allow us to define the physicochemical parameters critical for pancreatic exocrine cell fate determination and will advance our knowledge in matrix-guided organoid differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To sustain the considerable investments by the US government and in-country partners and ensure the well- being of older people living with HIV, the next phase of the HIV response must also focus on aging-related quality of life for the 25 million people living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. The current project directly addresses this goal by 1) determining the epidemiology, phenotypes and pathophysiology of cognitive impairment among older people with HIV in Uganda, 2) measuring the impact of cognitive impairment on the economic and psychosocial well-being of their households, and 3) identifying contextually-relevant risk factors for cognitive impairment. In doing so, this project will respond to numerous gaps in our understanding of cognitive impairment in Uganda and lay the groundwork for interventions to improve the health and quality of life for older people with HIV in the region.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although HIV infection rates have seen reductions with advances in healthcare and therapy, the number of people living with HIV continues to increase. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV/AIDS is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among children and adolescents, and robust estimates of the HIV burden among these age groups are needed to inform intervention priorities and monitor progress toward global targets. The goal of this study is to address limitations of existing methods by triangulating empirical data sources to produce more accurate and comprehensive estimates of pediatric HIV burden than current statistics, including the first-ever global estimates of new HIV infections among young adolescents, as well as insight into the unique contributions of biomedical, behavioral, and structural factors on the burden of HIV/AIDS in children and young adolescents. We will do so by assembling and triangulating data sources; quantifying the relationship between risk and protective factors and child/adolescent HIV burden; and forecasting the future burden of HIV among children/adolescents through 2040 based on current trends in incidence, prevalence, and mortality, and exposure to risk and protective factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Regulation of lipid production and degradation is a critical part of cellular health with defects in this process associated with aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, mechanistic understanding into the function of AD risk genes that are involved in the uptake and breakdown of lipids remains elusive. Here, we systematically probe the impact of AD risk genes involved in these processes using Drosophila models of lipid droplet formation and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 20 million older adults undergo major elective surgical procedures, yet very few receive advance care planning (ACP). Patients and/or caregivers must make complex decisions, but many are unprepared to articulate individual care goals and consequently, older adults may undergo surgical and post-surgical treatments inconsistent with their values and goals. We will conduct a three arm pragmatic randomized controlled trial, leveraging the electronic health record, in 3 geographically distinct healthcare systems to determine the effectiveness of increasing support intensity with improving ACP completion rates and increasing patient engagement with ACP (measured by survey).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Alzheimer’s disease, brain cells are unable to absorb or degrade molecules properly, leading to abnormal accumulation of lipids and toxic proteins and thus to cell death and impaired memory and cognition. Today, we do not yet have a full accounting of the molecules involved in these processes, nor how they act within specific types of brain cells. Here, we propose to perform a large-scale screen to identify the molecules responsible in brain and vascular cells. We will then perform in-depth functional studies to define how these molecules act in the brain and uncover effective ways to prevent the progression of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it tests how stressors across the life course— including harsh conditions in early life and challenging social circumstances in adulthood—predict autonomic stress responses and cardiometabolic measures of health. The project validates insertable cardiac monitors for measuring autonomic stress responses in captive non-human primates, and then use this validation to measure autonomic activity in a natural population in response to real-time, longitudinal data on adversity in early life and adulthood. This natural population offers fine-grained data and a simplified model, without the complexities of human health risk behaviors. The project is highly relevant to NIA’s mission of understanding aging processes across the life course by testing how repeated social and environmental stressors cause over-activation of the stress response, as a driver of accelerated aging.

PHR: Project Narrative Animal species differ dramatically in longevity and susceptibility to age-related diseases. This Project identifies genetic and epigenetic mechanisms responsible for extended healthspan and lifespan in long-lived bats experiencing social stress. This knowledge will enable the development of interventions to delay the onset of aging and age-related diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is defined by an accumulation of genetic variants that drive tumor growth and metastasis. With the ongoing development of therapies that target specific deregulated molecular pathways, it is increasingly important to understand the connections between genetic variants and the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment response of cancers. In this project, the ClinGen Somatic Knowledgebase and UniProt data resources will collaborate on AI-driven data strategies, including the use of Large Language Models (LLMs), to extract information about cancer variants from the scientific literature at large scale and make it accessible to researchers and clinicians for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE | 5R35NS111644 | Administrative Supplement Multiple sclerosis is a common and disabling autoimmune disease of the central nervous system in which B cells play a central pathogenic role. The principal goal of the project is to identify the disease trigger(s), and to understand the mechanisms underlying disease progression. Central elements of this initiative include large well-characterized clinical populations, comprehensive biobanked materials, serial magnetic resonance imaging of the brain and spinal cord using novel quantitative techniques, complete genetic information, and state of the art tools to investigate B cell biology including single cell B cell transcriptomics, recombinant antibody libraries, and phage-displayed synthetic protein arrays to identify antibody reactivities against foreign and self proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: In this study, we will culture human PAX7::GFP+ skeletal muscle stem/progenitor cells on aligned, electrospun fibrin microfiber bundles to induce their fusion into myotubes and assembly into 3D skeletal muscle grafts. We will optimize the delivery of soluble and tethered agrin in combination with insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) to promote the growth and myogenic differentiation of PAX7::GFP+ cells. Subsequently, we will use skeletal muscle grafts engineered with and without soluble and tethered agrin/IGF-1 to promote neuromuscular regeneration and functional recovery in a murine model of volumetric muscle loss.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The fellows and mentors trained by this program will contribute to short- and long-term improvements in global health. In collaboration with 21 low- and middle-income country institutions, fellows’ research will help develop clear and effective programs and policies to advance global public health, including care for HIV, other infectious diseases, noncommunicable diseases, global surgery, cancer, mental health and addiction, sexual and reproductive health, and planetary health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to establish the association of genetic polymorphism of the NK (natural killer) cell receptome in human populations. NK receptors are critical for innate immunity against tumors and are encoded by the highly polymorphic Leukocyte Receptor Complex (LRC, Chr 19) and Natural Killer Complex (NKC, Chr 12). To address our goals, we will deeply sequence the LRC and NKC in 18 ancestrally diverse human populations and leverage our expertise in bioinformatic analysis to integrate genetic data with single-cell transcriptome sequencing to search for expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) markers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the crucial tasks following the COVID-19 pandemic will be addressing the enduring consequences experienced by the millions of individuals who have recovered from the illness. This project aims to investigate the underlying causes of enduring olfactory, neurological, and cognitive symptoms that linger for months to years post-infection, even as systemic inflammation diminishes. We will explore potential interventions for addressing long COVID through the utilization of an innovative transgenic mouse model and state-of-the-art genetic techniques. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-1 has been a public health crisis for 40 years and still causes 690,000 deaths a year around the globe. The key to ending this crisis is an efficacious vaccine which can produce broad immune responses. This research will develop fundamental knowledge on a new approach to produce multiple broad immune responses simultaneously giving us more shots on goal for ending the HIV-1 pandemic.

PROJECT_TITLE: eDyNAmiC - SCRIPPS

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Eﬀects of semaglutide (Ozempic, Wegovy) and tirzepatide (Mounjaro and Zepbound) on incidence and outcomes of stimulant use disorders and opioid use disorder in real-world populations: target trial emulation using patient electronic health records PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study would utilize TriNetX Analytics, a nationwide electronic health records (EHR) database, to evaluate semaglutide’s association with changes in both the incidence of StUDs (MUD, CUD) and clinical outcomes associated with StUDs. Outcomes will be separately assessed by age groups, sex, and race and in patients with co-occurring mental disorders or other substance use disorders (SUDs) including alcohol, nicotine, opioid, and cannabis use disorders, whenever sample sizes permit. Our methodology is based on our successful use of TriNetX Analytics to evaluate semaglutide’s association with reduced incidence and relapse of cannabis use disorder.

PROJECT_TITLE: CANCAN - Harvard

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Our overall goals are to utilize novel pro-apoptotic host-directed therapies to develop short (2-3 months versus current 4-6 months), and efficacious TB treatment regimens which also prevent / improve post- tuberculosis lung damage, as well as develop novel clinically-translatable imaging approaches to expedite the clinical development of pro-apoptotic drugs for shortening TB treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (for public disclosure) We already identified ELQ-300 as a selectively potent inhibitor Qi site of the Plasmodium falciparum cytochrome bc1 complex. We have recently identified an ELQ derivative that is more potent in vitro and in vivo than ELQ-300 and now seek to modify the structure of this molecule to optimize for enzyme targeting to enhance antimalarial potency, selectivity, and overall performance in vitro and in vivo in rodent models of disease infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prior infection or intranasal vaccination establishes populations of tissue-resident memory T cells throughout the respiratory tract that can protect against experimental respiratory virus challenge by rapidly eliminating virus- infected cells and limiting immunopathology. This proposal seeks to define the ability of respiratory tract-resident memory CD8+ T cells to prevent viral propagation following natural respiratory virus transmission and identify mechanisms critical to this process. Our findings will provide valuable insights for the future development of cell- mediated vaccines designed to provide broad protection against viral strains and limit the spread of respiratory viruses in the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Human noroviruses are the leading global cause of childhood diarrhea and are attributed to the deaths of 200,000 young children each year. Understanding their pathogenesis, particularly in young hosts, is thus an important priority to aid in the development of vaccines and therapeutics. Our studies defining the mechanisms by which intestinal microbiota regulate norovirus pathogenesis should inform development of new types of treatment in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arenaviruses are the causative agents of several viral hemorrhagic fevers; however, there are very limited countermeasures against arenavirus infections, such as vaccines or antiviral drugs, leading to consideration of global threats of pandemics. By targeting the viral glycans with sugar analogs we propose to develop a novel way to treat arenavirus infections. In this project, we will develop the antiviral compounds usable as pan- arenavirus therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Biofilm-related infections are a significant cause of illness in the US, and many of these infections are caused by the bacterium Staphylococcus epidermidis. Biofilms are particularly important on poly-methylmethacrylate (PMMA) surfaces, which are used in many orthopedic implants, and in this project, we will characterize the molecular mechanisms by which bacteria attach to PMMA surfaces to form staphylococcal biofilms. We will also develop an anti-biofilm coating for PMMA, and we will test the effectiveness of a novel nanoparticle-based anti-biofilm treatment in an animal infection model.

PHR: Hantaviruses (e.g., the rodent-borne Sin Nombre virus and Andes virus) are bunyaviruses that cause severe human disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogenic and antibiotic-resistant E. coli is a leading cause of worldwide morbidity and mortality. The objective of this proposal is to examine the utility of two virulence factor candidates produced by this pathogen to serve as an effective vaccine against E. coli that disseminates systemically. Encouraging pre-clinical results produced herein will provide the necessary data and experimental backdrop to evaluate testing in phased clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC), is a leading cause of diarrhea in children under 5 years old and therefore, to avoid further morbidity and mortality due to ETEC, an efficacious vaccine given effectively is urgently required. Since children in LMICs have been difficult to effectively immunize with other oral vaccines, we propose to uncover a more effective immunization approach for protecting infants by maternal passive immunity in the first 2 years of life and beyond. We will study the protective benefits and components of ETEC specific maternal immunity from natural infection in protection of infants from ETEC infection and diarrhea.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Staphylococcus aureus is the leading cause of skin and soft tissue infections and a major cause of devastating heart, bone, and bloodstream infections, all resulting in nearly 12 million hospital visits each year. This, combined with resistance to multiple antibiotics, emphasizes the need for new strategies to combat infection, including those that target the regulation of disease-causing factors. This proposal seeks to understand novel regulation of the SaeR/S two component system by branched-chain fatty acids and its contribution to S. aureus virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HEALTH STATEMENT Mosquito-borne diseases such as malaria, Dengue, West Nile Fever and Yellow fever, which are transmitted to hundreds of millions of people every year, are anticipated to remain a major global health problem due to a lack of vaccines and lack of cheap, safe and broadly effective vector control methods. In this proposal, we begin with human skin-associated compounds to predict and test new repellents that act at close-range, via both olfactory and gustatory pathways, to reduce mosquito-human interactions. Such skin-derived chemicals could be developed for use in controlling the spread of mosquito-borne disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Stem-like T cells are proposed to orchestrate autoimmune responses, but little is known about the role of CD4+ encephalitogenic stem-like T cells. We have designed new ways to identify and characterize these cells using state-of-the-art transcriptomic signatures based on multiple genes rather than relying on the conventional single-gene approach. These new analytical tools will help develop these stem-like CD4+ T cells as novel bioindicators of MS, and the outcome of these studies will have both scientific and translational impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Transplantation is a curative therapy for organ failure in many different diseases. Although acute rejection mediated by T cells is a significant contributor to the premature failure of grafted organs, there is limited understanding of how CD8+ T cells differentiate into effector populations after grafting. Greater understanding of the signaling pathways controlling the effector CD8+ T cells that reject allografts will lead to more targeted therapeutic strategies to improve graft survival.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PCDH19-clustering epilepsy (PCE) is a severe developmental and epileptic encephalopathy predominantly affecting girls and caused by pathogenic variants in an X-linked gene. Using a mouse model that we recently developed, we propose to study how this unique inheritance pattern leads to abnormal interneuron development and susceptibility to seizures. This work will provide insight into disease mechanisms and may identify a therapeutic target to treat patients with PCE.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Screening mammography has contributed to the 25-40% reduction in breast cancer mortality, but false-positive results and delays in obtaining follow-up imaging are potential harms. We propose an online interpretation, same- day diagnostic imaging paradigm, which aims to eliminate the anxiety-ridden wait times between screening and diagnostic evaluation and reduce unnecessary recalls by using an artificial intelligence solution to triage screen- ing exams. We will study whether implementing an AI algorithm at the point of care can make online reading and same-day diagnostic imaging a reality in high-volume breast screening clinics.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using artificial intelligence to support efficient same-day diagnostic imaging in breast cancer screening

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is a common, chronic, progressive condition affecting at least 3 million Americans, in which the heart muscle pumps insufficient blood to meet the needs of the body. Approximately 1 in 3 patients with HFrEF develop skeletal muscle mass wasting, which has been associated with impaired physical function and decreased survival. This project seeks to understand the nutrition and metabolism abnormalities that occur during skeletal muscle wasting and to facilitate future development of new therapies that aim to both reverse muscle wasting and improve survival for patients with HFrEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Despite people with schizophrenia (SCZ) facing marked tobacco-related health disparities, most smoking/vaping behavioral pharmacology studies and clinical trials exclude people with SCZ. Indeed, although withdrawal is considered a key feature of nicotine/tobacco addiction that contributes to difficulty quitting smoking and likely electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS; e.g., electronic cigarettes), there is currently no research on ENDS withdrawal in people with SCZ. The proposed supplement will extend the parent study’s systematic and comprehensive characterization of withdrawal (in a general population sample) to people with SCZ who vape daily compared to those who smoke daily, filling critical gaps in our understanding of ENDS dependence liability for people with SCZ and contributing to the identification of intervention targets for ENDS use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Nearly 40% of descendants from East Asia possess a genetic variant severely limiting their ability to metabolize reactive aldehydes. In addition, several other genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway also occur in Asians which may impact organ injury, particularly during surgery. This project will develop tools in the basic science laboratory to better understand how genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway may impact organ damage and translate these strategies to monitor and reduce organ damage in humans undergoing surgery.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, hypertension, obesity) are a costly, pervasive problem for older adults, accounting for 90% of Medicare spending. This project will test the ability of voice-controlled "smart" technology to expand the implementation and sustain the use of a proven electronic health system (Elder Tree, or ET) for these patients; specifically, we hypothesize that older adults using ET delivered by a smart system (smart speaker plus smart display) will use and benefit from ET more than patients who access ET through a laptop because the smart system enables such easy use, even by those who have a tremor, poor vision, difficulty getting to a laptop, or other side-effects of aging. If successful, this smart system-delivered eHealth intervention will make ET more accessible and effective for older patients, improve their quality of life, and point the way to more impactful delivery of future eHealth innovations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: AHRQ Administrative Supplement

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells require their actin cytoskeleton to divide, move, and communicate with their environment. This project will reveal novel mechanisms of how actin monomers, the basic subunit the actin cytoskeleton, control the assembly and organization of actin structures in the cell. Deciphering these fundamental mechanisms could explain why defects in monomer regulation are associated with human diseases such as neurodegeneration, inflammatory disorders, cardiac disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed aging center will study societal changes leading to an aging society – low fertility, longer life expectancy – as well as the effects of behavioral changes (e.g., obesity, smoking) at the level of the individual and society, and consider the adequacy of our decision making capabilities in the face of these challenges. CEDA will provide the infrastructure and support for fostering innovative research, conferences and other collaborations, and dissemination of data for analysis by researchers, policy-makers and others. Ultimately, the focus and structure will advance the development of theories and empirical data to address complex interrelationships underlying healthy aging and therefore lead to policies for improved public health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Natural products are the best source of drugs and drug leads and terpenoids, the largest family of natural products, have a wide range of clinically important activities including antibiotic, anticancer, antimalarial, and immunosuppressant properties. The proposed studies will lead to the discovery of new natural products with important biological activities, facilitate future discovery efforts by the development of systems dedicated to facile identification of terpenoids in bacteria, and result in the characterization of natural product biosynthetic enzymes. A greater understanding of terpenoid biosynthesis will also provide insights into how nature constructs medicinally relevant compounds and how these enzymes may be used as tools for future discoveries in biochemistry, bioengineering, and drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Americans over age 65 are the largest group of patients and survivors of cancer in the U.S. and are also the most likely to experience sub-optimal treatment outcomes. Assessment of these factors, as part of a clinical exam, can help reduce risk. However, assessment and documentation of age-related risk is not well- coordinated, putting older adults at greater risk, especially diverse older patients such as those with limited English proficiency. The proposed project seeks to examine medical record and multi-level factors that can improve assessment of age-related risk and documentation with a broader goal of improving treatment planning and care for diverse older adults with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Treating dental caries infections is a massive healthcare expense due to the high number of cases to remove oral plaque, and mature biofilms are resilient to clinically available antibiotics due to their intricate architecture and strong binding to the hydroxyapatite coating of the enamel. Reported natural antibiofilm agents, such as isolates from Morus alba leaves and plant lectins, have shown moderate antibiofilm activity for S. mutans by targeting glucosyltransferases, yet natural product isolation can be time-consuming and expensive. Since there are no effective antibiofilm therapies provided in clinic, there is a demand for the development of antibiofilm agents that target a signaling pathway of S. mutans and other pathogenic bacteria while keeping the oral microbiome intact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcal species, such as S. mutans and S. gordonii, are known to cause or contribute to infections of the oral cavity such as caries and periodontal diseases using surface proteins to adhere to tissues for colonization and infection. A streptococcal-specific set of surface proteins, the AgI/II-family, have been shown to adhere to a range of human extracellular matrix proteins, other microbes, and components of the biofilm such as dextran. Directly interrupting adhesion to these targets would offer an antibiotic-fee treatment option to prevent infections of the oral cavity as well as preventing their contribution to infections of vital organs where AgI/II proteins contribute to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: This Stage II Randomized Efficacy Trial will compare the effectiveness of a theoretically informed and culturally responsive brief motivational intervention to a non-adapted brief intervention among non-treatment seeking Latinxs admitted for medical treatment of an injury who engage in at risk drinking or were drinking at the time of their injury. The culturally informed brief motivational intervention (CI-BMI) increases autonomous motivation to engage in protective drinking behavior and reduce alcohol problems while addressing barriers to help seeking and facilitating treatment utilization. This project will address the alcohol related health disparities and treatment inequities among Latinx who are more likely to experience alcohol problems yet less likely to receive treatment in order to reduce the negative public health impact of alcohol.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Public Health Relevance Some types of hormonal contraception have been associated with an increased risk of adverse cardiovascular outcomes, but the safety of these contraceptives has not been well studied among people with sickle cell disease (SCD) even though they have an elevated risk for these outcomes. Further, people with SCD are more likely to have an unplanned pregnancy than the general population, but little is known about what factors affect contraceptive decisions in this population. Results from the proposed study would help inform patient-centered contraceptive counseling for people with SCD by evaluating the safety of different contraceptive methods and examining patient and provider factors that affect contraceptive choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The autonomic innervation of the heart provides regulatory roles in heart function. Here, we propose to develop a 3D microphysiological co-culture platform to better understand fundamental aspects of sympatho-cardiac interaction and reciprocal regulation and growth of cardiac and autonomic cells. We will also establish a human model of cardiac muscle disease with sympathetic neurons, which will provide novel insights into understanding neuromodulation of cardiac pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Copper is an essential metal nutrient that is required for physiological functions spanning respiration and metabolism to antioxidant defense. Loss of copper homeostasis resulting from a combination of genetics, environment, diet, and lifestyle is connected to diseases including cancer, heart and neurodegenerative diseases, and metabolic disorders like obesity and diabetes. We are developing new chemical reagents for copper imaging and proteomics in biological systems to help decipher how copper contributes to healthy and disease states and target copper-dependent disease vulnerabilities, focusing on the contributions of copper and oxidative stress in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will determine the disease-altering properties of high-intensity exercise by randomizing 150 cognitively intact, sedentary elders (ages 65-80 years) at genetic risk for Alzheimer’s disease into two groups: one engaged in a high-intensity home-based cycling program and the other engaged in their habitual level of physical activity. Both groups will be monitored over 18 months with cognitive testing and MRI brain scans serving as primary outcomes to determine the disease-altering characteristics of aerobic exercise. Successful translation and demonstration of the effectiveness of a scalable home-based exercise intervention capable of slowing disease course will transform AD treatment, improve patient outcomes and quality of life, and reduce healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma is the most lethal form of primary brain cancer in adults and robustly infiltrated with tumor- associated macrophages (TAMs). In this proposal, we will explore the key signaling axis that participates in TAM reprogramming and promotes glioblastoma progression. We plan to develop therapeutics targeting TAM programming against this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The discovery of circRNAs opens an entirely new window into mechanisms of neurodegeneration in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD). This proposal seeks to identify and characterize disease-linked circRNAs and RNA-binding proteins (RBPs), and functional changes in circRNAs or circRNA- RBP interactions that modify ADRD neuropathology or neurodegeneration. Successful discovery of key circRNAs or circRNA-RBP interactions in aging human brains could uncover novel biomarkers, disease mechanisms, or therapeutic targets to diagnose, mediate, or prevent the progression of AD/ADRD.

PHR: Narrative The activities of this grant represent a major upgrade in the technology to precisely analyze protein molecules from cells and the human body. From model systems and humans, proteins are measured from cell culture, cells, fluids, and solid tissue to better understand and detect mechanisms and markers of human disease. Technological improvements assist the collaborating clinical and research labs directly, but also the field of protein measurement science in general through robust programs for training, dissemination and community engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stagnant survival and relapse rates for adolescents and young adults with cancer are partially attributed to a modifiable behavior—nonadherence to cancer treatments. To address multiple calls from the NCI and other federal agencies for research targeting disparities in cancer treatment outcomes for this population, this K08 research will use novel real time mobile health methodologies to examine and intervene on the time-varying, contextual factors that influence daily oral chemotherapy adherence in adolescents and young adults with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The proposed research and career development plan will yield critical multi-level data and a just-in-time adaptive intervention for nonadherence, with the potential for the investigator to advance adherence intervention science and improve clinical outcomes in adolescents and young adults with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Individual aging is the outcome of biological configuration and socioeconomic conditions and experiences. Aggregate population aging alters individual aging as it generates conditions that affect social organization, health services, and macro-economic change. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a strategy to develop an integrated-diagnostics tool for eventual clinical translation, which will enable enhanced predictive modeling of clinical outcome and diagnostic precision in 1st line immunotherapy for NSCLC, the choice of which has shown to have a large impact on patient survival during the course of cancer management since subsequent lines of treatment are increasingly less likely to be successful. Our radiomics signatures, combined with clinically established and emerging biomarkers, will result in increased precision for the management of patients selected for anti-PD1/PDL1 therapy by more accurately predicting who will benefit from therapy and detect response with more precision and earlier than currently possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL With an estimated 22,000 new cases and 14,000 deaths each year, cancer of the ovary, fallopian tube or peritoneum (termed “ovarian cancer” in this application) remains the most lethal of the gynecological malignancies. The Mayo Clinic SPORE in Ovarian Cancer provides support for translational research projects that are intended to have a rapid impact for ovarian cancer patients. Specifically, we will develop and test four novel therapeutic approaches designed to i) stimulate the immune system (Project 1), ii) introduce a Next Generation TOP1 inhibitor for ovarian cancer (Project 2), iii) repurpose the FDA-approved kinase inhibitor ceritinib as an ovarian cancer therapeutic (Project 3) and iv) provide a new form of adoptive immune cell therapy (Project 4).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Nature continues to drive the design of new drug leads through the inherent capacity of naturally produced chemicals to treat human disease. New tools in genomics and synthetic biology now allow for the accelerated discovery and engineering of novel natural product compounds from microbes and their DNA. We propose to combine poorly studied biological resources, such as deep-sea marine microbes, with modern genome mining strategies to increase the prospects for the discovery of new drug leads.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date there is no access to long-acting injectable (LAI) antiretroviral therapy (ART) – specifically long-acting cabotegravir and rilpivirine (LA-CAB/RPV) – in low- and middle-income countries outside of research studies. Our overall objective is to leverage a critical opportunity to determine the clinical and economic value of viral load, drug concentration and genotypic data in making clinical treatment decisions amongst adolescents and young adults in South Africa who would benefit from LA-CAB RPV. Understanding the durable value of LA- CAB/RPV among adolescents – and which adolescents would benefit most from this intervention – will be critical to convey to policymakers and international organizations negotiating for access as well as to global treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current clinical practice guidelines issued by the American College of Rheumatology strongly recommend Tai Chi as an intervention for knee Osteoarthritis (OA). To date, however, critical gaps exist in the evidence regarding "real world" effectiveness and implementation of mind-body approaches for knee OA pain across multiple Health Care Systems. The proposed pragmatic trial will test whether remote Tai Chi can be deployed effectively across multiple Health Care Systems in management of knee OA. The results will facilitate widespread deployment of Tai Chi mind-body therapies across multiple health systems in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Despite the increasing availability and effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy, HIV continues to be the greatest pandemic of the last 50 years — 70 million infected, 36 million currently living with HIV and over 1.8 million new infections, including over 180,000 new infant infections annually — so it is imperative to develop an effective population-based approach to reduce transmission. This proposal for the Leadership and Operations Center of the HIV Vaccine Trials Network, the collaboration of scientists at 64 clinical trial sites in 15 countries on 4 continents dedicated to developing a globally effective HIV vaccine, describes the marked advances in candidate vaccines to induce broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs), the advances in bnAbs administered by injection at levels that can prevent infection, and the HVTN’s extensive programs in engaging both local communities and other scientists throughout the world working to stop the spread of HIV. The goal of the HVTN is to develop a vaccine or monoclonal antibody combination that will, either alone or in combination, reduce HIV acquisition in adults and children by more than 60 percent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Vaccines are efficient measures to prevent infections, a critical problem is that aging-associated changes in the immune system lead to decreased immunogenicity and clinical efficacy of most currently used vaccines; novel strategies that increase vaccination efficacy and specifically target the aged immune system are imperative. An essential facet of these efforts is the use of combinatory adjuvants that synergistically potentiate more effective vaccine-induced immune responses against various pathogens. Our goal is to deliver a novel, efficacious combination of innate cytoplasmic PRR adjuvants with rASP-1, a unique parasite protein adjuvant, that promotes protective long-lived adaptive responses and boosts efficacy of vaccines in aged populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Center for AIDS Research (CFAR) Implementation Science hub will provide coaching and consultation support to scientists receiving NIH supplement grants aligned with the national Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE) initiative that seeks to reduce new HIV infections by 75% by 2025, and 90% by 2030. Proposed activities are well aligned with NIH HIV/AIDS Research Priorities, most notably supporting research in the cross-cutting areas of “health disparities, behavioral and social sciences research, epidemiology, information dissemination, implementation sciences, and training,” and will be achieved via five specific aims centered on: 1. Coaching, 2. Consultation, 3. Dissemination, 4. Collaboration, and 5. Conducting a cross-hub IS pilot with other CFARs and AIDS Research Centers (ARCs) across the country.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health and the mission of NICHD because it will 1) help determine the molecular mechanisms of how human milk improves neurocognitive development by reducing intestinal-, systemic-, and neuro-inflammation in preterm infants, and 2) validate relevant non-invasive human biomarkers for clinical use. Determining the precise mechanism(s) with validated non-invasive biomarkers can improve monitoring of mixed human milk and infant formula feedings in clinical settings and/or in homes to optimize neurocognitive development. This proposal addresses the NICHD Pediatric Growth and Nutrition Branch’s research priorities to 1) understand the lifetime impact of nutrition on … child growth and development; and 2) understand the composition and function of human milk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The project will reveal the underlying molecular mechanisms for how OLFML3 triggers microglial infiltration in CLOCK/BMAL1-high GBM. Based on these mechanistic results, the project will develop novel therapeutic strategies targeting microglial infiltration with or without with immune checkpoint inhibitors for GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Synapses are connections between neurons that change dimensions during long-term potentiation (LTP) and depression (LTD), cellular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity that underlie learning. We have discovered that individual synapses have both functional active zones (AZs) and structural nascent zones (NZ) that can be converted to AZ during LTP. We propose a multidisciplinary approach involving slice physiology, optogenetics, glutamate uncaging, and novel three-dimensional electron microscopy to investigate how NZ and AZ dynamics during synaptic plasticity regulate the success of future plasticity with outcomes promising new insights about learning and memory and new targets for understanding and treating learning disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: EMS administered buprenorphine is a promising strategy to increase access to life saving, evidence-based addiction treatment and referral for ongoing OUD care. Current evidence for EMS initiated buprenorphine is promising but limited to small retrospective or nonrandomized prospective cohort studies. During this study period, we will develop a study protocol for prehospital EMS-initiated buprenorphine and linkage to care for patients with OUD presenting with an opioid or in acute opioid withdrawal

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framedwithin our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease, a neurodegenerative condition ultimately leading to cognitive decline and dementia, can present in a variety of time courses and symptoms in different individuals. We aim to explore the consequences on the function of brain cells of different variation in human DNA that contribute to Alzheimer, using a combination of work in cell culture, human tissue and analysis of large-scale information. Ultimately, this will allow us to characterize the mechanisms by which combinations of changes in DNA lead to different manifestations of the manifestations of Alzheimer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Public Health Relevance Statement Recent statistics on endometrial cancer incidence and mortality underscore the need to understand not only what is driving the increases in endometrial cancer, but also why Black females have a higher likelihood of developing the serous histologic subtype and much worse outcomes. The objective of this study is to create 20 new patient-derived organoid models of serous endometrial cancer using tumor specimens from Black patients and make these models available to the research community. Preclinical models that represent all patients is essential to define biological contributors to disparities in outcomes.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While significant advances in global health have been achieved in recent decades, serious disparities in health outcomes persist, especially among children, adolescents and their adult caregivers. The proposed research training program in global health disparities research, entitled “Addressing the Research Capacity Gap in Global Child, Adolescent & Family Health Disparities Utilizing Implementation and Data Sciences among Vulnerable Populations in Resource-limited Settings (ACHIEVE)”, focuses on increasing dissemination and implementation (D&I) and data science research capacity in order to address global health disparities affecting children, adolescents and their adult caregiving families; and is designed for Medical Doctors and Post-Doctoral trainees from diverse backgrounds in the United States (including underrepresented minorities) and sub-Saharan Africa. The ultimate goal of the ACHIEVE program is to support the development of a cadre of early career researchers applying D&I and data science research methods to ensure that research on evidence-based practices, interventions, and policies are effectively translated to and used in real-world settings heavily affected by health disparities impacting children, adolescents, and the adults who raise them in low and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: SUPPLEMENT PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical and public health strategies to reduce tobacco use are urgently needed in sub-Saharan Africa, where tobacco use is increasing and colliding with epidemics of HIV and tuberculosis. This project will evaluate the impact of brief telephonic tobacco cessation counseling and of a tobacco sales ban on tobacco use among people with and without HIV in rural South Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research activities will contribute a fundamental, hyperlocal knowledge of HIV risk among persons who inject drugs in Alabama. This data is essential to identify and prioritize communities for HIV prevention services, in addition to harm reduction and addiction interventions. We will not reach the ambitious aims of the Ending the HIV Epidemic Initiative without tailoring prevention efforts to meet the needs of PWID, a group who is most marginalized and at heightened risk of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glucocorticoids are commonly prescribed as a short course in the treatment of autoimmune diseases such as lupus, lupus nephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4-related disease, and ANCA-associated vasculitis, whether as an induction therapy of a study regimen or as a permitted rescue medication for both disease-related and unrelated reasons. Protocols often apply strict criteria for tapering on a pre-specified time course and fixed stepwise reduction in dose levels to discontinuation. Common Data Elements (CDEs) to capture glucocorticoid administration do not exist in the NIH CDE Repository, and data representing the specifics of a glucocorticoid taper are crucial for analysis to understand patient benefit from this approach, would support deep learning, and could inform future approaches to recording intermittent use of concomitant medications.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The incidence of melanoma is increasing rapidly in VA population in the United States, and sun exposure during US military service has been linked to increased melanoma incidence. The standard of care for advanced melanoma currently includes molecular-targeted therapies of BRAF and MEK inhibitors, as well as immunotherapies with checkpoint inhibitors such as anti-PD1. However, many melanoma patients either do not respond or relapse from the current treatments. Therefore, discovering new effective therapies for malignant melanoma is still a pressing issue in the VA patient care mission. The objective of this project is to discover the therapeutic potential of the new generation of clinical-trial-ready drugs targeting pro-survival proteins to treat melanoma by inducing apoptosis, especially for tumors from patients unresponsive to current treatments. The results will likely lead to clinical trials testing an exciting new generation of treatments for melanoma.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Research administration is a critical but often under-resourced function required for the successful administration and execution of large, complex NIH grants in Africa and other low- and middle-income countries (LMIC). The overall objective of this administrative supplement is to develop a more comprehensive and efficient research administration function at the Aga Khan University to support the development, submission, and successful administration of research grants. The proposed work is highly synergistic with DS- I Coordinating Center and Research Administrator Working Group activities aimed to support research administration functions with the consortium and can serve as a framework for standard research administration services that can be scaled/adapted to the needs of DS-I Africa members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This proposal provides scientific rationale and an empirical basis for targeting basal forebrain parvalbumin neurons (BF PV) to treat Alzheimer's disease (AD). This research will inform innovative treatment strategies by showing that BF PV excitation can be used to prevent the progression of AD pathology and restore hippocampal-cortical network integrity to rescue cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive decline is a severe complication of obesity, the metabolic syndrome, prediabetes, and diabetes, all of which are potentially linked by inflammation. In this proposal, we will identify a timeline of inflammatory events in mid to later life obesity- and prediabetes-mediated cognitive decline, with particular focus on the contribution of the innate inflammatory cGAS/STING pathway, to identify pathological mechanisms of microglial-mediated inflammatory crosstalk. Our goal is to identify disease-modifying targets and ideal therapeutic windows for obesity- and prediabetes-related cognitive decline during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although, increased DNA breaks within the genome are associated with Alzheimer’s disease and brain aging, the molecular mechanisms of this association remain unclear. I propose to use cutting-edge tools to measure the impact of DNA breaks on genome organization to understand the mechanisms of how DNA breaks lead to Alzheimer’s disease, and test the therapeutic potential of these pathways. The proposal is relevant to public health and the mission of the NIA because it improves our fundamental understanding about the biology of Alzheimer's disease with the goal of developing therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social adversity and certain unhealthy diets are both associated with increased risk of mortality, poorer health outcomes, and higher incidences of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease. The project investigates how common mechanisms—for instance in inflammatory responses to chronic stress—might enable the development of dietary interventions that buffer against the negative consequences of adverse social environments. Its results will greatly advance our understanding of the role that diet and the social environment play in resilience during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R25 application proposes a new research training program in the NIDDK/KUH mission areas of adult and pediatric nephrology and adult and pediatric (benign) urology. Our Nephrology and Urology training program has successfully trained fellows for careers in academics in basic, translational, and clinical research, while focused on diversity recruitment and retention. For this undergraduate initiative, we have utilized best practices from our teaching and mentoring experience for kidney scientists and leveraged the strengths of the Stanford School of Medicine to promote recruitment and success of women, underrepresented minorities, and other disadvantaged groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of the supplement is to acquire a replacement inverted microscope to enable the work proposed in the parent application, which is to test the hypothesis that mechanical forces directly drive tissue assembly in corneal stromal matrix produced by human corneal cells. The proposed work depends heavily on a TE2000E microscope that is 20 years old that performs a sophisticated battery of live-imaging measurements and single molecule tracking while tissue is being elaborated. Nikon is no longer supporting the microscope which is failing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we shift toward a new era of disease-modifying therapies, racial disparities in diagnosis and care of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) will become even more evident and will likely increase unless we intervene in conditions driving such disparities in timely ADRD diagnosis. The proposed research validating timeliness measures and examining structural drivers of racial disparities in timely ADRD diagnosis will inform policies and interventions that focus on modifiable structural barriers to reduce disparities in timely ADRD diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine serous carcinoma (USC) is the deadliest form of endometrial cancer due to frequent recurrence and metastasis with minimal treatment options. Black women are twice as likely to die from endometrial cancer than White women in the United States, however, the causes for this disparity are poorly understood, with emerging studies suggesting molecular alterations may be a contributing factor. The overall goal of this administrative supplement is to identify kinase inhibitor targets that can be used for the treatment of USC, as well as to evaluate the role of kinase signaling in the disparity of USC amongst Black and White women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Poor sleep quality and short sleep duration may be a mechanistic component of cognitive impairment in older adults, associated with a decline in brain-derived neurotrophic factor. Increasing the availability of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) with supplementation of its precursor, nicotinamide riboside (NR), may increase the expression of brain-derived neurotrophic factor. We propose to examine the benefits of NR supplementation upon sleep and cognitive function in older adults with comprehensive subjective and objective measures and to explore its impacts on serum brain-derived neurotrophic factor. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: What Precursors Become Lung-Resident CD4 Memory that Protect Against Respiratory Infections or Cause Lung Pathology? Respiratory infections, which include the major SARS and influenza pandemics of the 21st century as well as yearly influenza outbreaks, are a leading cause of mortality and morbidity across the world. This grant will define the pathway of development of an immune T cell type known as CD4 TRM that become resident in the lung where they can rapidly protect against respiratory infections but may also cause lung damage, so we will explore their mechanisms of protection and damage. The results will give us new insights into how to develop vaccines that efficiently induce protection in the lung and treatments that minimize lung damage during an immune response to respiratory infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We know little of the pathway to brain health in African American men, mainly because there have been notably few brain imaging studies that included substantial numbers of older African American men. My proposed research will examine cognition and AD risk markers, test diagnostic accuracy, and characterize brain health in older, cognitively healthy, urban African American men. The results will provide insights toward identifying and validating markers of brain health and AD risk in African American men—a necessary step to understanding how AD affects men and which tailored interventions are most effective for mitigating AD.
