IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As we prepare to scale cloud-first data science projects within DS-I Africa under the UZIMA-DS initiative, a U54 Research Hub funded by the NIH Data Science for Health Discovery and Innovation in Africa Initiative, we propose developing good practices for building efficient and responsible data pipelines for research. These practices will enable leveraging cloud infrastructure on limited budgets while being mindful of our carbon footprint. Using data pipelines from the ongoing UZIMA-DS project, which processes daily Fitbit data from 500 healthcare workers on a Microsoft Azure instance, we will build and evaluate data pipelines using three tools and approaches within the Azure environment. We will measure processing time, costs, and carbon emissions. Our ultimate goal is to achieve “Efficient Data, Sustainable Future for Research” by developing a set of good practices that research teams can use to ensure maximum resource efficiency while minimizing environmental impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the rational development of a therapeutic strategy targeting clinically occult breast cancer cells that persist despite current treatments. Once such a strategy has been developed, there is the potential for significant improvement in anti- cancer therapy to prevent tumor recurrence and disease progression. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the mission of NCI through the development of improved treatments that would decrease morbidity and mortality in patients with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platelets play crucial roles in the body, however, the mechanisms and molecular regulators of platelet regulation are poorly understood, including the role of the extracellular matrix and glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). The proposed research aims at elucidating the role that GAGs play in thrombopoiesis, including the identification of GAG targets that can be harnessed for therapeutic gain. This research proposal is relevant to public health and the NHLBI’s mission as it aims to advance the development of therapeutic agents for thrombocytopenic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When inhaled at high concentrations, carbon monoxide causes cardiac and neurocognitive deficits and death; however, when produced at low concentrations in tissue, carbon monoxide acts as an intracellular signal and has even been tested as a therapeutic agent. In this proposal, we aim to develop a microbial carbon monoxide sensor, RcoM, into (1) a fast-acting carbon monoxide scavenger that can serve as an antidote for carbon monoxide poisoning and (2) a sensitive detector of carbon monoxide in living cells. Development of these molecular therapeutics and tools will dramatically improve the current standard of care for carbon monoxide poisoning and advance our understanding of intracellular carbon monoxide signaling and toxicology, with the potential to substantially decrease death and disability caused by this common poisoning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sympathetic nervous system activity is increasingly appreciated as a major contributor to pulmonary hypertension severity and prognosis. Our studies focus on neuronal-immune cell interactions that seek to uncover the mechanism involved in disease-associated sympathetic activity. We focus in part on a subset of TREM2 expressing disease-associated microglia as a therapeutic target for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension and its associated end-organ damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD), is rapidly progressive with a median time from diagnosis to death or nursing home half that seen with AD and extensive burden on both patients and family caregivers. There are no approved treatments, though some drugs approved for other diseases may partially or temporarily relieve some of its cognitive and motor symptoms. The proposed research would advance clinical testing of neflamapimod as a treatment to not only relieve symptoms but also treat the underlying disease process, potentially providing hope for DLB sufferers and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) accounts for roughly half the cases of heart failure in the United States. HFpEF is a complex syndrome that presents with diastolic dysfunction, and is associated with comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, diabetes and metabolic syndrome. The underlying pathophysiology of HFpEF is not well understood, all clinical trials in HFpEF have failed to show any benefit on clinical parameters thus far. Understanding the role of inflammation on the onset and progression of HFpEF pathophysiology will significantly improve our knowledge and potentially identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vaso-occlusive events remain a clinical burden in sickle cell disease and is the major cause of organ failure. Although a major contributor to vaso-occlusion in this disease is redox stress, the mechanism by which redox stress promotes vaso-occlusion is not well understood. The goal of this project is to determine the role of oxidative cysteine electron transferring events in vaso-occlusion that are driven by thiol isomerases, which would reveal redox targetable mechanisms to prevent vaso-occlusion in sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Mutations in many genes place patients at very high risk of developing dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), which often leads to heart failure and early death. Personalized mutation-specific therapies have shown great promise in other areas, but none are available for DCM. I will test the hypothesis that identifying the molecular pathways by which different mutations lead to DCM may facilitate the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual minorities are at heightened risk of alcohol misuse; however, existing research is largely based on a static and unidimensional construct of sexual orientation rather than a fluid and multidimensional construct of sexual orientation. This longitudinal population-based study will examine the fluidity and multidimensionality of sexual orientation, improve longitudinal estimates of alcohol misuse and its negative health consequences, and identify modifiable risk and protective factors in multiple domains (individual-, social- and policy-level). This study will provide new information to improve assessment, prevention, screening, and intervention efforts targeted towards reducing alcohol-related consequences among sexual minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will examine how an HIV-infected person’s metabolism can affect their immune response to a therapeutic vaccine. We seek to develop techniques for altering metabolism either systemically or locally, at the site of therapeutic-vaccine administration, to make responses better. If successful then this project will explain why some individuals respond well to therapeutic vaccines and others do not.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical activity helps to prevent weight gain and preserves cardiovascular health yet many young adults do not meet federal guidelines for aerobic physical activity and gain weight. Smartphones and wearable activity trackers create new possibilities for promoting young adults’ physical activity and preventing weight gain. This project evaluates the efficacy of Precision AIM, a digital intervention that makes person-specific, context- sensitive dosing decisions to ensure each person receives the right message content for them at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative The research infrastructure of the Florida Node Alliance supports the development and implementation of innovative clinical trials to answer a broad spectrum of translational substance abuse treatment research questions across a wide variety of treatment settings and diverse patient populations. CTN 0121: Integrated Care and Treatment for Severe Infectious Diseases and Substance Use Disorders (SUD) among Hospitalized Patients, aims to reduce hospital readmissions for patients with these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases affect up to 8% of the US population and its prevalence is rising, setting the stage for an impending public health crisis that we do not yet understand and are not prepared to face. We will leverage a multidisciplinary team of leading investigators, cutting edge tools designed for at-home, longitudinal tissue sampling, and an innovative strategy to discover how autoimmunity begins, relapses, and spreads in a large population of at-risk individuals. This approach will provide insight into autoimmunity that will help physicians better manage, or even prevent, devastating consequences of these diseases in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Gastroparesis is a disorder of gastric function characterized by delay in gastric emptying and frequently associated with chronic nausea and vomiting, early satiety, and abdominal pain. Gastroparesis is a disease affecting predominantly young women which can have a devastating impact on quality of life. The GpCRC aims to transform scientific discoveries from laboratory, clinical, and population studies into clinical applications to improve treatments and reduce the burden of adverse outcomes due to gastroparesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - RELEVANCE Gastroparesis and functional dyspepsia affect both children and adults, is responsible for great morbidity, and is associated with increased mortality. The results of this proposal will provide novel insights into their clinical expression and course in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease and dementia are major health problems, particularly in the elderly population. Vascular pathologies across all vasculature are linked to dementia of all causes, particularly the two major subtypes, Alzheimer’s dementia (AD) and vascular dementia (VaD). The current application seeks to fill the scientific gaps by uncovering a novel function of smooth muscle cell (SMC)-expressed Runx2 in regulating cardio/cerebrovascular pathologies and VaD, and developing a novel paradigm underlying the Runx2-dependent signaling network in regulating SMC phenotypic switch. Results from these studies should also have important clinical implications in developing potential strategies for maintaining vascular integrity and improving cognitive function and quality of life. PHS 398/2590 (Rev. 09/04, Reissued 4/2006) Page Continuation Format Page

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES CENTER AT EL PASO
PHR: Project Narrative Gastroparesis affects approximately 10% of the US population, with patients suffering with chronic, severe and difficult to control symptoms of nausea, vomiting, inability to finish normal size meal, fullness and abdominal pain. The NIH GpCRC has generated an extensive number of individual studies, which have increased our knowledge and concepts of understanding of this condition, its complications, diagnostic challenges and clinical outcomes. As the next step in the continuation of our research, we are proposing two new clinical projects: 1- Investigate whether the composition of the gut microbiota, in the stomach and duodenum of GP patients differs in idiopathic, compared to diabetic etiologies and control patients; and 2- investigate how a new medication, utilizing the mechanism of 5 Hydroxytryptamine (5HT) stimulation by a selective 5HT4 receptor agonist, which is already FDA approved for constipation, may help to reduce symptoms of gastroparesis as well as accelerate gastric emptying while having a satisfactory profile adverse event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uterine cancer is the only cancer type with worse outcomes today than in the 1970s; serous uterine cancer is the deadliest subtype and it disproportionally effects black women. Tumor treatment response and outcomes are impacted not only by cancer cells, but also by cells in their microenvironment. To better understand serous uterine cancer, we will profile the tumor and microenvironment of patient samples following treatment.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The use of dashboards by district health officials to understand and visualize complex health data is a key outcome of MADIVA; the effectiveness of these dashboards depends on data visualization literacy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative mHealth may facilitate the wider introduction of human papillomavirus-based cervical cancer screening programs in low- and middle-income countries such as Kenya by supporting specimen and patient tracking, patient education, service reminders and counseling support. We propose to develop and evaluate the impact of an integrated digital platform with a mobile application for use by community health volunteers (CHVs), building on a prototype developed to address gaps in CHV-led cervical cancer screening programs identified in previous work in the region. The study will also help determine the impact of a mobile application to support cervical cancer prevention services in Kenya, as well as the personnel and infrastructure needs and implementation strategy for scale-up and sustainability in similar low-resource settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many hearing and language disorders arise from pathological alterations to the central auditory pathways. This study is relevant to public health since it will investigate the hitherto overlooked contralateral auditory tectothalamic pathways as a neural substrate in these disorders. Therefore, this research is relevant to part of NIH’s mission, since it develops the basic knowledge that will lead to improved methods for diagnosing, preventing, and treating auditory disorders associated with aging, development, trauma, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions):  Metals and PFAS are neurotoxic, however, nutritional modifiers of their effects on neurodevelopmental disorder diagnoses remain unclear let  alone how to minimize chemical toxicities on human health. This study will investigate the roles of nutritional modifiers of chemicals -  neurodevelopmental disorders relationship, and predict the effects of hypothetical interventions to reduce chemical neurotoxicity. Our findings will  inform interventions and policies to promote children’s mental health and well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Formaldehyde is a major environmental toxin and carcinogen whose aberrant exposure is connected to diseases spanning liver and cardiovascular disorders, cancer, diabetes, and neurodegeneration, but at the same time the body continually produces this reactive carbonyl species during normal physiology. We are developing and applying new chemical reagents for selective imaging and proteomics of formaldehyde in living systems to identify its molecular sources and targets, with the long-term goal of understanding how this reactive small molecule contributes both to normal physiology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Obesity and obesity-related diseases have become one of the greatest threats to human health and a tremendous financial burden for individuals and societies. NLRP3 inflammasome-mediated inflammation in obesity has been recognized to promote the occurrence and progression of obesity-related diseases. The proposed research is of great health relevance because it will pave the way for translating dietary exosome-like nanoparticles and their active biomolecules into an intervention to curb inflammation in obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this proposal is to advance a large animal model of spinal cord glioma (SCG) as a translational platform. We will accomplish this by scaling and adapting previously implemented strategies for vector- driven gene transfer of oncogenes and shRNA knockdown of genes implicated in gliomagenesis to induce SCG of variable phenotype. This will provide improved utility for preclinical therapeutic testing and surgical device development with varied grade, growth rate, and underyling genetic lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Campylobacter spp. are the leading cause of bacterial-derived gastrointestinal infection in the world with significant impacts on human health in both developed and developing countries. This prevalence is primarily due to the ability of these bacteria to reside in the gastrointestinal tracts of various animals and transmit to humans where they colonize the colon and cause inflammation. This project will work to understand how a novel regulator in C. jejuni controls nutrient acquisition through sensing an uncommon intracellular signal and subsequently upregulating a system that can transport and metabolize a host-derived molecule to obtain the nutrient it contains.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Integration of nutrient availability, TCA cycle activity, and colonization factor expression in Campylobacter jejuni

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Precision Medicine Initiative Cohort Program will enroll one million volunteers into a national Biobank that broadly reflects the diversity of the U.S. population and help accelerate progress toward a new era of precision medicine on a larger scale than previously possible. The proposed Biobank will be a valuable resource of biological specimens and related health information from human volunteers that can then be used to address a wide range of scientific questions to improve public health. Mayo Clinic proposes to provide a state-of-the-art infrastructure and cost-effective services to ensure the success of the Precision Medicine Initiative Cohort Program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: It is well established that complex mutations and genomic rearrangements are relevant to the development of human diseases, including cancer and many neurological and developmental syndromes. The proposed work will identify factors driving repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs) into a maelstrom of destabilizing repair pathways and will unravel their molecular mechanisms. In addition, this research will define the patterns of genetic instabilities produced by deleterious DSB repair that are similar to those observed in association with human disease, which will contribute to ongoing data mining efforts to develop biomarkers for early detection and to design targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Undernutrition and infections are common in pregnancy in low-resource settings in the US and abroad. This project will rigorously study how iron and inflammation interact and affect the development of the human brain in utero. We aim to improve mechanistic understanding of how to optimally intervene during critical periods in pregnancy to improve the future neurodevelopmental potential of children worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Falls in the elderly most often result from frailty, which is caused by muscle weakness, impaired balance, and unstable walking. Studies in rodents have shown that age-induced changes that lead to frailty are preceded by structural and functional changes at the neurotransmitter release site within the neuromuscular junction. This proposal aims to utilize several new approaches to understand how aging alters neuromuscular synapses at an individual transmitter release site level.

The UK-REI-CC will enhance and support the NIDA REI projects by providing resources for networking and training, conducting community- engaged research, data collection and analyses, and communication and dissemination. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The objective of this supplement is to advance knowledge and build relationships to improve cancer-related outcomes for American Indian and Alaskan Native (AI/AN) populations. We will accomplish this by establishing and convening an initial meeting of an AI/AN Think Tank at Huntsman Cancer Institute, in Salt Lake City, Utah, with the goal of bringing key stakeholders and partners to the table for listening, discussion, and learning about the critical lack of medical options available to AI/AN populations and determination of potential solutions. This work will be driven by the AI/AN Tribal members, but fully supported and endorsed by 13 NCI-designated Cancer Centers, who have convened to form a consortium of Centers that are highly supportive of and engaged with AI/AN communities.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Aplysia are highly resistant to levels of hypoxia that would be lethal to humans or most other animals. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative consortium that combines next--generation sequencing with state- -of--the--art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this consortium are to identify gene variants that are associated with compulsive-like cocaine intake and behavioral endophenotypes using genome--wide association studies (GWAS) in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to strengthen the infrastructure of a newly created data/tissue repository (Cocaine Biobank) accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms related to cocaine use disorder. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of cocaine addiction-like behaviors in males and females, and increase the impact of a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow--up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Postpartum hemorrhage occurs when the uterus bleeds excessively after childbirth and is often caused by failure of the uterus to contract properly. This study uses non-invasive genetic biomarkers to determine how well the uterus will respond to oxytocin, a common medication used during childbirth to help uterine contraction and treat hemorrhage. The biomarkers will allow us to develop new ways to predict risk for hemorrhage before birth and design treatments that are more effective, thereby saving mothers’ lives and minimizing long-term health problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid overdoses have increased for the last 20 years. Fortunately, there are evidence-based Medication Assisted Treatments for opioid use disorder (OUD). Unfortunately, fewer than 20% of individuals with OUD receive specialty treatment, and fewer receive optimal evidence-based treatment. It is clear that medication alone will not solve the current opioid epidemic; as a result, national organizations, such as SAMSHA, have emphasized the need for further development of a Recovery-Oriented Systems of Care. This NIDA R24 Project will develop a community-academic partnership to address the lack of evidence regarding recovery support services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Alcohol use increases the risk for treatment dropout, relapse, and overdose in patients receiving opioid agonist treatment for opioid use. This project will develop and evaluate a modified alcohol-focused intervention tailored to address alcohol use in patients in opioid agonist treatment who are struggling with alcohol use disorder. This brief and scalable tailored intervention will have the potential to decrease alcohol use and improve opioid agonist treatment outcomes with minimal resources, adding in an innovative way to efforts to address the ongoing opioid overdose crisis in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States faces significant challenges from drug overdoses and HIV, especially among populations involved in the criminal–legal system. A Justice HIV and Overdose Research Network will be established to address the intertwined crises of drug overdose and HIV within the U.S. criminal–legal system. The proposed Coordination Center at RTI International, termed the RTI EngageData Hub, aims to enhance the effectiveness of interventions through robust scientific coordination, data management, focused community engagement, and rigorous research dissemination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative This is a multidisciplinary, highly collaborative consortium that combines next-generation sequencing with state-of-the-art behavioral screening in a unique, genetically diverse, nonhuman animal model. The goals of this consortium are to identify gene variants that are associated with oxycodone use, the effects of oxycodone on analgesia and pain using genome-wide association studies (GWAS), and the sensitivity to FDA-approved treatments in behaviorally characterized heterogeneous stock rats, and to maintain a data/tissue repository (Oxycodone BioBank) accessible to all researchers to study the cellular and molecular mechanisms of oxycodone addiction. Results from these studies have the potential to have a sustained and powerful impact on the field of addiction because they will identify novel druggable targets, provide a comprehensive analysis of oxycodone addiction-like behaviors in males and females, and maintain a unique data/tissue repository that will facilitate follow-up and replication studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Superoxide is a threat to all forms of life and its toxicity is harnessed by the immune system to combat infection. Superoxide dismutases are metal utilizing enzymes that enable us and invading microbes to cope with superoxide, yet we do not know the molecular or environmental factors that dictate the metal utilized by these enzymes. The proposed studies will address this unanswered question, providing insight into how both humans and invading pathogens overcome the universal threat of superoxide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research aims to develop, translate, and validate innovative in-vivo imaging technologies to improve imaging and studying the development of the human fetal brain before birth. The technology will enable and improve studies on the development of the brain in fetuses with congenital disorders or fetuses at risk of having neurodevelopmental issues later in life. This in-turn is expected to result in timely and more effective treatments and therapeutic interventions that will lead to vastly improved patient outcomes in both the short- and long-term, effectively reducing the burden of human disabilities arising from congenital disorders.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Recent work shows that low middle income country trauma systems are limited by patient-payer models, limited personnel with specialized focus, high cost services, very limited access to care, and few specialists with adequate implementation research training to translate knowledge into practice to create and apply implementation science strategies. Optimizing care at each step along this continuum requires a rigorous, patient-centered, and health system–contextualized implementation research strategy and a network of like-minded, invested stakeholders. The objective of this supplement is to strengthen local capacity to train and supervise implementation science postdoctoral researchers and activities, by investing in the professional development of educators and collaborators at Kilimanjaro Christian Medical College and University, as well as expanding professional development activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Down Syndrome is primarily caused by trisomy of chromosome 21, resulting in an extra copy of over 200 genes and significant intellectual and developmental disability. Generating translational models and identifying the brain cell type specific contribution to Down Syndrome pathophysiology has been difficult and has hampered development and screening of new treatments. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission to enhance life and reduce disability, aiming to understand how human microglia contribute to the neurodevelopmental pathogenesis of Down Syndrome with a goal of identifying novel treatment targets and screening methodologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative  Developing disease-modifying therapies for neurodegenerative diseases is notoriously diﬃcult and is exacerbated by the lack of accurate statistical models to identify the optimal time for intervention. Here, we will use ﬁve longitudinal datasets of Huntington disease, a genetic neurodegenerative disease, to propose new statistical strategies to accurately estimate the disease course. These strategies can be used to help researchers identify when an experimental therapy could best modify the disease course and design a well-powered clinical trial to test that therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergy impacts 8% of children in the US but racial and ethnic differences in food allergy outcomes are not well understood. The FORWARD study is currently exploring racial and ethnic differences in clinical tolerance, development of new food allergies, food allergy management during adolescence, as well as food allergy phenotypes and endotypes. This supplement proposes to implement food allergy common data elements for data collection in FORWARD and build upon ongoing work to continue to develop a set of common data elements that can help provide consistency in food allergy data collection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health and to the NIH because it seeks to use public health and clinical data on opioid use disorders (OUD) outcomes for mothers and infants, which is the leading cause of death to mothers one year after deliver and can lead to neonatal withdrawal syndrome (NOWS) and other poor outcomes. Insufficient or incomplete data about OUD and lack of integrated programs for OUD treatment during pregnancy can be barriers to providing optimal care to mothers and infants. Completion of this project is a first step toward creating a data dashboard development methodology that can inform continuous prenatal, maternal, and infant care in other communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometrial cancer is more common than all other gynecologic cancers combined, and the incidence and death rates have both increased over the past 25 years. The work proposed will lead to both an improved understanding of endometrial cancer biology and new approaches to prevent and treat this disease. Additionally, this SPORE will expand the numbers of researchers dedicated to studying endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This research will test the potential to repurpose a small molecule BRAF kinase inhibitor, dabrafenib, an FDA- approved drug for several cancers, for new use in preventing cisplatin- induced hearing loss. Significant protection against cisplatin-induced hearing loss has been achieved with oral delivery of dabrafenib in mouse models in doses approved in humans. The successful completion of this study will provide the crucial data needed for rapidly advancing dabrafenib to clinical studies in humans for prevention of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: There are no approved therapies for Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), the most severe form of fatty liver disease that affect approximately 20% of the global population and predisposes them to liver cancer, chronic kidney disease (CKD) and cardiovascular diseases (CVD). The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it will focus on translating a novel target for the prevention and cure of NASH/HCC and CKD with the goal of improving CVD and overall survival. Specifically, the proposed study will establish the pre-clinical validation of anti-sense oligo (ASO) mediated suppression of Ubiquitin D (UBD) as a potential therapeutic approach for NASH/HCC and CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The goal of the Acute to Chronic Pain Signatures (A2CPS) program is to identify biomarkers and their collective biosignatures that predict susceptibility or resilience to the development of chronic pain after an acute pain event. In this administrative supplement, the UC San Diego Omics Data Generation Center (ODGC) will use white blood cells (WBCs) from buffy coat samples collected by the A2CPS to determine single nucleus gene expression signatures associated with the development of chronic pain. This project is relevant to public health because it will aid in our understanding of the role of immune cells in chronic pain and complement biosignatures developed by the parent grant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: There are no approved therapies for Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), the most severe form of fatty liver disease that affect approximately 20% of the global population. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission because it will focus on understanding the basic mechanisms that leads to the initiation and progression of NASH with the goal of identifying novel targets for early detection, prevention and cure of NASH and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Specifically, the proposed study will dissect the role of TREM2 in orchestrating the progression of fatty liver to NASH, fibrosis and eventually to HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A novel approach to treating bone marrow failure disorders involves shifting the balance of proliferation and differentiation in hematopoietic progenitor cells in order to increase progenitor proliferative capacity and generate greater numbers of terminally differentiated cells. I recently demonstrated that the balance of proliferation and differentiation in mouse early erythroid progenitors can be manipulated with glucocorticoid or TGFβ signaling, and results in increased (by glucocorticoids) or decreased (by TGFβ) proliferative capacity; however, the molecular mechanisms by which these proliferative capacity alterations occur are unknown and it is unclear if this developmental biology paradigm observed in mice will translate to humans. To begin developing this preliminary finding into novel therapeutic approaches for Diamond-Blackfan anemia, I propose to determine the mechanism for alteration of proliferative capacity of early erythroid progenitor cells by identifying direct gene targets of the transcription factors downstream of glucocorticoid and TGFβ signaling, and also determine if glucocorticoids and TGFβ elicit the same effect on proliferative capacity of erythroid progenitor cells from normal human donors and patients with Diamond-Blackfan anemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The next generation of multidisciplinary investigators will require foundational training and experience in both the life and physical sciences, as well as in computational, mathematical, and engineering disciplines to tackle increasingly complex problems that impact our health. TExBioMed, an education research initiative of the Multi- Interprofessional Center for Health Informatics (MICHI) at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), a designated Hispanic Serving Institution, will leverage the institutional commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion by recruiting and immersing 55 talented undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds in a training environment that will expose them to the current state-of-the-art in biomedical informatics, health and public health informatics, and data science. The program's ultimate goal is to increase the talent pool to fulfill the needs of the nation’s current and future workforce by providing the participating students with unique, hands-on training and research experience that will broaden their view of human health in post-genomic computational and data science research areas and motivate these students to pursue careers in Biomedical Informatics/Data Science fields.

PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The Human BioMolecular Atlas Program (HuBMAP) aims to create the very first computable, open Human Reference Atlas (HRA). PHR: Public health statement: We propose a Mapping Center as part of the Human Biomolecular Atlas Project  (HuBMAP), that will assist in the construction of a HuBMAP Human Reference Atlas. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The mechanisms that link structural changes in the brain connectivity to the remapping of function after  stroke are unknown. Here we will define how synapses are impacted by stroke and determine the  synaptic mechanisms that underly the recovery of lost function in the mouse model of stroke. The results  of this work will provide mechanistic underpinnings of functional recovery after stroke and have the  potential to identify novel therapeutic targets that will lead to improvements of function in stroke patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord causing loss of muscle control; ALS currently lacks effective options of treatment. Increased neuroinflammation is an important contributor to the progression of ALS which makes it an attractive therapeutic target. Our goal in this Fast Track application is to develop our novel CAR Treg therapeutic, CM-CS1, to reduce inflammation and damage to neurons in ALS, thus preventing disease progression and protecting neuronal survival and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims at defining mechanisms responsible for the formation and maintenance of the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), and the survival of motor neurons. This is important because abnormal formation or function of the NMJ, as well as the loss of motor neuron, is implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Therefore, identifying regulatory mechanisms responsible for structural and functional changes in the NMJ will enable us to improve current treatment strategies for neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  We are proposing to develop an axon-specific bidirectional optical neural interface and test the system's efficacy to neuromodulate the parasympathetic nervous system by modulating heart function. We will use optogenetics and multiphoton optical excitation to simultaneously detect the neural activity and photostimulate individual axons from the exterior of the nerve i.e. an approach that is non-invasive yet has specificity. This technology has potential for major impact on the ability to treat many conditions; for example, vagal nerve stimulation in humans has been found to control epilepsy and depression, and evidence points to improvements in treatment of inflammatory bowel disease and Alzheimer's Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic exposures to environmental dusts lead to lung inflammation, injury, and disease. The overarching goal of our studies is to determine how dietary omega-3 fatty acids promote resolution and repair in the lung following dust exposure through regulating macrophage-derived IL-22 signaling. These studies support NIH goals by increasing our understanding of how particulate matter inhalation impacts lung inflammation, and exploring strategies for promoting recovery from these inflammatory exposures to protect against disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Landscape fire smoke and birth outcomes in sub-Saharan Africa Africa is the continent that experiences the most landscape fires in the world. There is emerging evidence that if pregnant women are exposed to smoke from these fires, their babies are likely to be born smaller than normal, or earlier than usual. However, most of this evidence has been generated from studies done in the USA and in Brazil. This proposed research will test these assumption in sub-Saharan Africa. We will make use of data on the birth outcomes from some of the data that is being assembled as part of the NIH funded HE2AT center. The project will leverage and complement the CHEAQI-MNCH project that is asking similar question on other pollution exposures and their effect on the pregnancy outcomes for mothers and their babies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The HarmonAIze project will deliver a generalizable, semi-automated toolkit to aid health data harmonization and linkage with climate data using novel AI approaches, thereby addressing key barriers to the large-scale re- analysis of health data across all research topics, and markedly accelerating progress in the field of climate and health. We will accelerate and extend the achievement of the HE2AT Center and DS-I Africa’s objectives, by building data science and leadership capacity in early-career investigators, supported by a mentorship network within the HE2AT Center consortium. Sharing the open-source toolkit through the eLwazi Open Data Science Platform, and piloting implementation of the kit within other DS-I Africa Research Hubs, will maximize impact within the DS-I Africa consortium, and advance public health research more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive decline in Parkinson disease (PD) causes disability and reduced quality of life. Current medical treatments do not prevent or treat cognitive decline in PD, so behavioral interventions that mitigate its negative functional consequences and thus potentially delay the onset of dementia are in high demand. This study will test the efficacy of a targeted training approach for improving cognition and daily function in people with PD and may ultimately result in enhanced independence and quality of life for this population.

PHR: Project Narrative Here we propose to test the central hypothesis that REST in DRG neurons is involved in regulating opioid analgesia in chronic neuropathic pain and in chronic opioid-induced hyperalgesia /analgesic tolerance by governing opioid receptors and cannabinoid receptor expression through epigenomic regulation of these genes. Thus, manipulation of REST in DRG neurons could be utilized to increase opioid analgesic efficacy and reduce opioid consumption. The project is responsive to PAR-18-742.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Patients with hearing loss who use cochlear implants (CIs) show significant deficits and strong unexplained intersubject variability in their perception and production of spoken emotions in speech. This project will investigate the hypothesis that “cue-weighting”, or how patients utilize the different acoustic cues to emotion, accounts for significant variance in emotional communication with CIs. The results will focus on children with CIs, but parallel measures in postlingually deaf adults with CIs will be made, ensuring that results of these studies benefit social communication by CI patients across the lifespan by informing the development of technological innovations and improved clinical protocols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Phase I data demonstrates the feasibility of producing a gene expression-based assay for the highly accurate classification of patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and other dementias using a sample of blood spotted on filter paper which is easy to collect in the doctor’s office, clinic, or even by self-collection. The validation of this assay in Phase II with multiple cohorts of samples, correlation to FDA-approved tests, and use to elucidate potential novel therapeutic targets and the launch of RUO whole transcriptome, Alzheimer’s, and pan- dementias tests will be transformative for the field of neurodegenerative diseases at the levels of basic research, translational research, and drug discovery and development, as will the subsequent development into a definitive Alzheimer’s or pan-dementia diagnostic assay. By enabling self-collection, this test may also reduce health disparities and transform the diagnosis of Alzheimer’s Disease and other dementias to permit neurologists to focus on confirmation and treatment rather than diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Dr. Corina Bondi is a tenured Associate Professor in the Departments of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation and Neurobiology, and a member of the training faculty in the Center for Neuroscience at the University of Pittsburgh. Her R01 parent grant (R01NS110609) aims to assess cognitive- and anxiety-like dimensions sensitive to both traumatic brain injury (TBI) and aging, as the elderly represent a high risk population for both cognitive decline and TBI incidence, and to address mechanistic questions regarding altered cholinergic neurotransmission responsible for such deficits. In 2024, Dr. Bondi was awarded the NINDS Landis Award for Outstanding Mentorship to supplement training-related activities, and it will be used to ensure the salaries of a postdoc for 4 months, a postbaccalaureate trainee for one year, as well as for research supplies for the URM undergraduate supplementee on the R01 and a medical student, travel for 8 mentees to conferences, publication costs for my trainees, and a portable computer for training purposes (papers, talks, posters, etc).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Healthy bone is critical for long term health not only to minimize fracture risk and related morbidity and mortality, but as an endocrine organ with influence on energy homeostasis, mineral metabolism, and adiposity. The goal of this longitudinal study is to investigate phthalate and metals exposure across two sensitive life stages – pregnancy and peri-menopause – in relation to bone health in midlife. Findings from this work will provide insight into mechanisms of exposure-related changes in bone health, with important implications for osteoporosis, fracture risk, and metabolic and cardiovascular health, as well as identify modifiable risk factors for these significant adverse health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Gene delivery using adeno-associated virus vectors has tremendous potential as treatment for congenital and acquired diseases of the nervous system. Understanding viral vector dynamics is key to optimizing drug design and has been hampered by a lack of means to resolve nanoscale viral particles in living tissues. This proposal seeks to develop efficient super-resolution imaging tools to improve imaging of adeno-associated viral vector trafficking in live animal models to advance understanding of viral vector bgene delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Extremity trauma involving volumetric muscle loss (VML) presents a clinical challenge with significant fibrosis and fatty infiltration, impaired regeneration, and long-term functional disabilities. In this work, we will use pre-clinical models to define the roles of key cell types in the pathologic process of VML. We then utilize this foundational understanding to develop newly engineered immunomodulatory and regenerative treatment strategies with the long term goal of translating these into clinical treatments to improve functional outcomes after VML injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Uterine serous carcinoma is a highly lethal condition, and the harmful effects of fluid-assisted shear stress on its progression remained unexplored. This project will leverage our team's specialized knowledge to unravel the mechanisms by which fluid shear stress promotes the spread of this cancer. By examining and contrasting the characteristics of shear stress in uterine serous carcinoma with those found in the malignant transformation of fallopian tubes into advanced high-grade serous ovarian cancers, and by inhibiting crucial components of the mechanotransduction pathways, we aim to develop innovative treatments for this aggressive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol and other substance use disorders in reproductive-aged women are of great public health relevance given their association with significant and lifelong adverse physical, mental, and sexual and reproductive health consequences, especially for the most structurally marginalized groups in the U.S. There is an urgent need for new settings and innovative methods to address risky alcohol and substance use in preventive women’s health care contexts in order to improve interrelated health outcomes and equity across the reproductive life course. This implementation trial will evaluate family planning clinics as a novel setting in which to simultaneously test the effectiveness of screening, brief intervention, and referral to treatment (SBIRT) for alcohol and drug use. Coupled with an evidence-based Implementation and Sustainment Facilitation implementation strategy, our findings will ultimately support adoption and scale-up of substance-related care across a premier national sexual and reproductive healthcare organization and its expansive network of FP clinics serving millions of women in the U.S. every year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Duplex sequencing offers a way to robustly interrogate the landscape of somatic mutations at single molecule resolution through reducing the error rate of sequencing. A variety of such duplex sequencing approaches are being implemented across the SMaHT Network. We propose to scale up the efforts around duplex sequencing by 1) productionizing CODEC, 2) testing, and implementing HiDEF-seq at the Broad Institute, and 3) exploring the use of targeted duplex sequencing (CODEC, HiDEF-seq, NanoSeq or other) for mutation validation and driver discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascularized composite allografts (VCAs), which involve the transplantation of a combination of skin, muscle, bone, nerves, offer immediate therapy for individuals who have suffered irreparable tissue damages or deformities (i.e. face, hand etc.). However, VCAs are highly susceptible rejection and also requires life-long immunosuppression which is often toxic to the patients. Therefore, this study aims to utilize a preclinical nonhuman primate model to explore novel therapeutic strategies targeting CD40/CD154 signing pathway with anti-CD154mAb. The ultimate objectives are to minimize VCA rejection, preserve protective immunity, promote tolerance, and optimize patient health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health relevant statement This project has the potential to improve T cell therapies. Specifically, the proposal focuses on populations of white blood cells (leukocytes) that are induced upon vaccination of individuals and can protect against microbial infections and tumors. These cells are cytotoxic (CD8+) lymphocytes, and become long-lived upon vaccination, therefore are called 'memory' lymphocytes. They can express multiple functions that are important to protect the host against infectious microbes and to kill tumor cells. We studied and discovered that these cells protect vaccinated host by very precisely orchestrating the effector response of other leukocytes. We propose in this proposal to pursue our dissection of how they achieve such efficient elimination of invading microbial pathogens in vivo with the goal of designing novel immune therapies.

PHR: Narrative. Those infected with HIV are at high risk of reactivating latent TB infection. Concurrent antiretroviral therapy and anti-TB therapy does not provide immune reconstitution in TB/HIV co-infection. Our goal is to establish a novel host-directed immunotherapy comprising of IL-21-IgFc fusion protein with cART and 3HP to prevent LTBI reactivation upon HIV co-infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 39 million people are living with HIV-1 infection globally with HIV/AIDS causing >600,000 deaths annually. There is no cure for life-long persistent infection and there are not yet approved therapies to suppress viral gene expression in the context of preventing viral latency reversal. This project studies how HIV-1 hijacks host cellular machineries to regulate viral RNA nuclear export and genome packaging during virion assembly with the goal of informing the development of strategies to inactivate these viral activities in vivo.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Unhealthy alcohol use is common among Veterans and a significant risk factor for numerous negative health consequences, including chronic disease, injury, mortality, and suicide. It is also linked to increased financial and societal costs (e.g., higher healthcare utilization, criminal justice expenses). Due to these burdens, effective, evidence-based care for Veterans with unhealthy alcohol use was implemented in VA primary care settings. However, significant gaps in this care have been identified, indicating that a substantial proportion of Veterans in need of help are not receiving it. Improving the implementation of alcohol-related care in primary care settings has the potential to increase access to both preventive care (e.g., brief counseling interventions) and treatment (e.g., medications for alcohol use disorder), thereby significantly decreasing the harmful health and societal consequences associated with drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop a radio-frequency-based monitor that uniquely provides proactive alerts of bladder fullness as a support technology for toilet training for children and young adults with ASD/IDD. The monitor will be discreet and wearable, and designed to meet the needs and constraints of this diverse population. This proactive sensing approach will assist in the transition to independence for these individuals suffering from urinary incontinence, and help them achieve a higher quality of life and greater participation in educational and community settings.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The Integrated Networks of Scholars in Global Health Research Training (INSIGHT) consortium formed between the University of Alabama at Birmingham, the Baylor College of Medicine, the University of Maryland Baltimore, and the University of Pittsburgh supports training for the next generation of global health scholars from the US and low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) through mentored research experiences at 24 established partner LMIC institutions across 19 countries in Africa, Asia, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Strong emphases are on a broad range of global health research areas, including combatting the global HIV epidemic and associated co-morbidities, emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases, and mental health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Regulating stress is critical to healthy mental and physical development. Over the peripubertal period, there appears to be a waning in the effectiveness of social partners to buffer activation of stress-responsive physiological systems. The proposed research will determine the neural mechanisms of this effect as well as its pervasiveness, and will potentially improve interventions that support resilience to mental health problems in early adolescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Building from the methods and findings in the parent project, this supplement will identify the molecular mechanisms through which dysregulation of GATA2 and Piezo1 lead to invasion, metastasis, and poor patient outcome in uterine serous carcinoma. The long-term goal of these studies is to utilize GATA2 and/or Piezo1 immunohistochemistry as biomarkers to predict which patients with uterine serous carcinoma are at high risk of cancer recurrence and would benefit from adjuvant chemoradiation therapy while sparing patients with low risk of cancer recurrence from unnecessary adjuvant chemoradiation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Septic shock is acute cardiovascular failure due to an infection that affects tens of thousands of children each year. Although crystalloid fluid resuscitation is the cornerstone of initial resuscitation, there is no definitive evidence for the most effective and safest type of crystalloid fluid in children. The objective of this large, pragmatic, randomized study is to test the comparative effectiveness of the two most common types of crystalloid to improve clinical outcomes in children treated for septic shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early childhood caries (ECC) remains the most common chronic childhood disease worldwide and causes a major impact on children, families, and healthcare systems, especially in low- and middle-income countries and underserved populations. Candida is frequently detected in the oral cavity of toddlers with severe ECC (S-ECC) and its presence is implicated with an elevated risk for S-ECC, but its role on the etiopathogenesis of the disease remains unclear. This study aims at elucidating whether early Candida infection in children during the first year of life is associated with S-ECC onset and severity in a longitudinal study.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this project is to develop PanKbase, a centralized and comprehensive resource of the human pancreas for the diabetes research community, with a focus on type 1 diabetes (T1D) pathogenesis. If successful, results from this project will provide new insights into T1D pathogenesis and enable the development of new therapies and biomarkers. The project will also foster cross-disciplinary collaborations and promote innovation, with the ultimate aim of improving the lives of people with T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current diabetes treatments are woefully inadequate, and diabetes remains a leading cause of disability and death among Americans. Our program will meet a growing need within our region and the country for a cohort of capable diabetes investigators, by training new scientists in cutting edge research aimed at better treating and preventing diabetes. The trainees in this program will be scientists who are not yet independent but have earned their PhD and/or MD and intend to head their own diabetes research laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exosomes are now fully realized as being integral elements in many biological processes, first and foremost as conduits for inter-cellular communication. Key to their study and utilization across fundamental biochemistry, potential uses in clinical diagnostics, and realizing their promise as therapeutic drug delivery vehicles is the development of technologies that allow their rigorous, robust, efficient and inexpensive isolation and purification across many size scales and source matrices. Capillary-channeled polymer (C-CP) fiber and film platforms address these challenges in a unified way that provides continuity and simplicity across these fields of endeavor, holding the promise of advancing the knowledge base and applications of these important extracellular vesicles.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: RFA-FD-24-041 Project Narrative The Kidney Health Initiative (KHI) is a public-private partnership among the American Society of Nephrology (ASN), the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and the kidney community whose mission is to catalyze innovation and the development of safe and effective drugs, devices, and biologics for people with kidney diseases. KHI is a pre-competitive forum that convenes a multi-sector community, including all the major constituencies in this field (people with kidney diseases and care partners/patient advocates, health professionals, members of industry and government), to exchange knowledge and execute pre-competitive collaborations that address shared challenges. KHI’s focused projects and initiatives result in peer-reviewed manuscripts, and widely- disseminated roadmaps, workshops, roundtables, webinars, and educational toolkits that provide recommendations and direction for any individual, company, or organization to use for the development of new kidney drugs, devices, and biologic therapies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Kidney Health Initiative is a public-private partnership between the American Society of Nephrology, US Food and Drug Administration and the kidney community.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Climate Change is relevant to food production, water access, energy use, and health. Diet is related to crop production and food security, which is impacted by weather patterns in terms of precipitation, temperature, and drought. Less developed countries and their disadvantaged communities are most vulnerable yet we do not have a good understanding of these risks. To understand the connection of diet access and quality in low income rural communities to these environmental factors, our study assesses dietary behavior and health outcomes in rural Jordan that can help us develop policies and interventions to protect these communities from the impacts of these factors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Point Designs proposes to develop and commercialize a purely mechanical, ratcheting prosthetic finger system for children with partial hand limb absence – independent from electronics and batteries, thereby reducing cost, size, and complexity while increasing reliability and durability – that can be custom-made for each patient using advanced metal 3D-printing technology. Partial hand limb absence can cause physical, psychosocial, and economic damage to a child and their family. Replacement of a finger requires a mechanical design that can withstand the demanding forces, torques, and environmental conditions of everyday life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pain represents a major public health problem, and an improved understanding of the biopsychosocial contributors to pain is critical to inform interventions aimed at pain prevention and treatment. At present, there is a need to bolster the dwindling clinical pain research workforce. To address this gap, we propose the University of Florida Partnerships Across Interdisciplinary Networks: Training through Engineering, epidemiology & Addiction Medicine (UF PAIN TEAM} with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of team-trained clinical pain scientists. Working in teams, the UF PAIN TEAM will move the pain field forward through cutting edge research designed to elucidate the causes and reduce the burden of pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune cells in the lung have important functions both during infection and homeostasis. Their appropriate function in either context involves transmitting signals from lung microenvironment, and improper integration of these signals can lead to impaired pathogen clearance or excess inflammation and tissue damage. Our goal is to understand mechanisms that allow lung signals to shape immune function, to gain insights into susceptibility to infection and chronic inflammatory lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of vestibular function with aging affects both balance and gait and is thought to contribute to increased fall risk. Recently, we have found that very low levels of random electrical stimulation applied to the vestibular system produce improvements in vestibular function along with balance and gait measurers in elderly individuals with age related vestibular loss. The present work aims to test if this novel subperceptual neuromodulation stimulus can be used as an effective treatment for age related vestibular loss that will improve balance confidence, balance and gait, in the hopes of reducing fall risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is one of the deadliest cancers and is characterized by an expansion of fibroblasts which modulate the tumor microenvironment. This proposal aims to elucidate molecular signatures and functions of cancer associated fibroblast subtypes in PDAC. This research will contribute to fundamental knowledge of PDAC biology, and may ultimately lead to design of more effective therapeutics for PDAC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will assess the impact of a novel breastfeeding support intervention (“telelactation”), delivered via video calls on personal devices including mobile phones and tablets. The goal of this intervention is to increase access to International Board Certified Lactation Consultants to improve, and reduce disparities in, breastfeeding rates. By implementing a “siteless” randomized controlled trial that recruits participants through a popular pregnancy tracker mobile phone application, this study will efficiently recruit a national sample of 2400 diverse women to 1) provide evidence on the effectiveness of a widely available, yet understudied, service and 2) leverage technology to promote one of the most widely recommended health behaviors to improve children’s health and to reduce disparities in key maternal and child health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism Spectrum Disorder affects 1 and 44 children, and racial/ethnic disparities profoundly impact access to care. Though most research has focused on child and family factors, other contextual factors such as neighborhood, state health policy, and educational system determinants are likely drivers of structural disparities in care. In this research we propose to identify cross-sector, modifiable determinants of autism diagnostic and treatment disparities by combining Medicaid data with information on neighborhoods, state policy, and state educational data, and we will use a stakeholder-engaged consensus panel to turn data into actionable interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Temporomandibular Disorders (TMD) including those involving the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) itself represent a spectrum of painful disorders that afflicts approximately 5 to 10% of the US population with approximate annual healthcare costs of $4 billion. No definitive etio-pathologic diagnostics are currently available, and treatments are non-specific and largely palliative. By deep dissection of the local and systemic molecular profiles and cellular interactions using single cell multi-omics we expect to provide comprehensive foundations and depth of knowledge needed to more rationally stratify patients into TMJ disorder (TMJD) and comorbidity subtypes and severity categories; provide the basis for new directions of translational science in diagnostics, prognostics and therapeutics towards the implementation of precision medicine; define homeostatic and disease signatures that are specific to the TMJ as opposed to appendicular joints; and lay the foundation for further studies on the biologic mechanisms underpinning TMJDs, pain and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because elderly patients with mild cognitive impairment and early-stage dementia are frequently underdiagnosed, posing significant burden on patients, families, and healthcare systems. Development of a novel screening algorithm built on easily accessible data generated in routine patient-clinician encounters has a strong potential to identify these patients, promoting timely care and preventing negative outcomes, particularly emergency department visits and hospitalizations. The proposed study is aligned with one of the National Institute of Aging’s Strategic Directions for Research (2020-2025), “Develop improved approaches for the early detection and diagnosis of disabling illnesses and age-related debilitating conditions.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lewy body dementia affects men and women differently, as sex differences have been reported for prevalence, clinical phenotype, and presence of co-pathologies. Understanding the genetic and neuropathologic mechanisms associated with these sex differences will helpelucidate the etiopathogenesis of this dementia. Identification of sex-specific genetic and neuropathologic factors in Lewy body dementia will improve diagnostic accuracy at an early stage, provide reliable biomarkers and promising targets for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although regular physical activity comes with many health benefits, including lower risk of disability and chronic disease, higher functional independence, and greater psychological well-being, many US adults— especially those in later life—do not obtain sufficient levels of activity based on federally recommended guidelines. This project uses data captured repeatedly and intensively in daily life to examine whether negative beliefs about aging result in less physical activity by hampering exercise motivations and self-regulation. Knowledge gained from this work will inform the development of interventions that target negative beliefs about aging to improve physical activity in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project proposes to develop a novel measure of the unique financial impacts experienced by caregivers of people living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. We will over-sample caregivers from three NIA priority populations – Hispanic/Latino, Black/African American, and people living in rural areas – to assure the measure is valid and reliable in the general population and in these groups. This project has the potential to positively impact public health by enabling us to understand caregiving financial impacts and the influence of social networks.

PHR: Project Narrative The Johns Hopkins University seeks to strengthen the coordination of new and innovative research and practice efforts in maternal health through collaboration with the National Institutes of Health and their Implementing a Maternal Health and Pregnancy Outcomes Vision for Everyone (IMPROVE) initiative grantees. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE This Fast-Track SBIR proposal is designed to address the critical public health problem of bullying and cyberbullying among elementary school age youth. We will develop and test bullying and cyberbullying prevention materials, including interactive classroom sessions and corresponding serious games, based on the evidence-based Life Skills Training substance abuse prevention approach, which teaches personal self- management skills, social skills, refusal skills, and other life skills needed to successfully navigate developmental tasks, increase resilience, and facilitate healthy psychosocial development. The proposed product has the potential to fill a gap in the intervention tools currently available to schools that can be widely disseminated throughout the country using existing marketing and dissemination channels and decrease the adverse consequences of bullying, cyberbullying as well as substance abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The Case Western Reserve University MSTP will develop MD-PhD training to train a diverse pool of physician- scientists to meet future needs for research leaders who can accelerate research to advance the understanding, detection, treatment and prevention of human disease. We will develop an MD-PhD curriculum that integrates research and clinical training in a manner that deeply engages research training from the beginning of the program to promote retention of trainees in the research mission and foster curricular efficiency in time to completion of MD-PhD training. The integrated research and clinical curriculum, program activities, DEI focus and activities, and support for students will produce a highly skilled and diverse physician- scientist workforce, which will contribute to national goals for basic, translational and clinical research in academia, government and industry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall Antibiotic resistance is one of the foremost public health concerns worldwide. This program to combat antibiotic resistance, which has as its goal to develop new approaches to treat antibiotic resistant infections by targeting the bacterial cell envelope, was specifically designed to be responsive to this global threat. A highly productive multidisciplinary team will function collaboratively to capitalize on the many advances it has already made to enable fundamentally new approaches that target this essential structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is an aggressive and therapeutically difficult cancer to treat. Mouse models of pancreatic cancer are therefore paramount to our mechanistic understanding of tumor microenvironment dynamics and immunomodulatory interventions. The overall goal of this research is to use cutting-edge microscopy techniques to mechanistically understand the fine grain cellular interactions that dictate tumor responsiveness and leverage them to improve synergistic therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Clinical trials have become overly complex and expensive, resulting in major gaps in the availability of and knowledge about medical products. The Clinical Trials Transformation Initiative (CTTI), a public-private partnership co-founded by the FDA and Duke University, and involving all interested parties across the clinical trials ecosystem, develops and drives the adoption of recommendations and resources to improve the quality and efficiency of clinical trials. Through the support of this cooperative agreement, Duke will host and support CTTI's work to shape better the clinical trials of the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Responses to metabolic and other stresses play critical roles in development, many diseases, and aging. This project investigates how specific defenses against reactive oxygen species (ROS), metabolic stress, and misfolded proteins are regulated so that they respond to stress and other signals appropriately, including how they influence protein oxidation to maintain cellular function, resist stress, and ensure longevity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food allergy (FA) to multiple foods is increasingly common and can cause serious illness and death in children  and adults. We will use innovative approaches for immune monitoring and data analysis of blood and GI  tissues to investigate factors responsible for FA, and to improve our ability to manipulate the immune system to  safely treat people with FAs. We will also try to develop rapid blood tests that can be used to tailor treatment  for each individual patient with FA to improve treatment safety and efficacy.

PHR: Contact PD/PI: Fawzi, Wafaie W Project Narrative The HBNU Fogarty Global Health Training Program, a consortium of Harvard University, Boston University, Northwestern University and the University of New Mexico, proposes to continue to contribute to global health research capacity building and the use of research to improve the health outcomes related to priority health areas in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) in partnership with 18 sites throughout Africa, Asia, and South America.
