IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NIH SBIR Fast-Track, PAS-22-196 Advanced Comprehensive Magnetic Resonance Solution for the Non Invasive Characterization of No Clinical Trials High Resolution Metabolic Biomarkers of Risk in Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Dementia Project Narrative  We propose to develop ADRD360, an advanced hardware-software package to optimally acquire, process, and analyze magnetic resonance (MR) imaging and spectroscopy in the human brain. Using ADRD360, we will localize metabolic signatures at much higher resolutions than currently possible on clinical MR systems. Although we propose testing these metabolic signatures as predictive biomarkers of the risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) in this project, we believe the ADRD360 can improve brain assessment in patients with other neurological disorders. Confidential Proprietary Information Advanced Imaging Research dba SREE Medical Systems

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human oral cancer caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) is increasing dramatically and current treatment options are highly destructive and burdensome, leading to lower quality of life. We have identified a peptide that can more effectively carry small interfering RNA (siRNA) into these cancerous cells, which is a promising therapeutic alternative to the current standard of care. This study will establish the mechanism of how this peptide carrier works and give insight into additional modifications to make it even more effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This program will develop high performance optical coherence tomography (OCT) imaging technologies that will enable high resolution, three-dimensional spatial mapping of blood oxygenation in human retinal vasculature. This new imaging technology has the potential to improve early detection and monitoring of many ocular diseases, including diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma and age-related macular degeneration. Wider commercial availability of this high-performance OCT technology promises to accelerate fundamental research as well as clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT The long term goals of the CaRE2 center are to reduce cancer disparities in Black/African American and Hispanic/Latinx individuals, to train and increase the pool of 120 underrepresented Black/African American and Hispanic/Latinx scientists conducting health disparity research, to increase research capacity at an HBCU (FAMU), and to increase cancer disparity research at UF and USC-NCCC. The proposed two full projects and pilot project include investigators from the three institutions and will leverage on specimens collected across the partnership from Black/African American and Hispanic/Latinx, representing a wide range of subpopulations within these minority groups. Thus, our studies will reveal unprecedented findings about these two understudied minority populations, will be instrumental in transferring cutting edge and innovative technologies to FAMU, and will expand in a significant way the research focus at UF and USC-NCCC to address cancer health disparities in pancreas and lung cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Breast cancer brain metastasis (BCBM) is associated with deadly outcomes due to limited therapeutic options and poor response, urgently calling for the development of novel therapeutic intervention strategies. We have found that oncolytic herpes simplex virus-1 (oHSV) therapy induces neutrophil infiltration and neutrophil extracellular trap (NET) formation through induction of Insulin-like growth factor-2 (IGF2) expression and secretion into tumor microenvironment (TME), hampering therapeutic efficacy of oHSV. In this proposed research, we will uncover the mechanistic relationship between oHSV-induced IGF2 and oHSV-triggered neutrophil infiltration and NET in BCBM, and characterize the preclinical therapeutic impact of novel IGF2- scavenging oHSV in combination with radiation therapy as well as NET-mitigating oHSV for significant advance of BCBM treatment in the future clinical application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD) are a major public health problem, and identifying the causes is a priority for research. This project will quantify the impact of a common exposure, traumatic stress, to improve understanding of AD/ADRD etiology. In addition, the work will identify factors that exacerbate or ameliorate effects of traumatic stress across the lifecourse on AD/ADRD risk, which will inform high-risk groups and opportunities for intervention to prevent AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: KECK GRADUATE INST OF APPLIED LIFE SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States with approximately 5.8 million Americans living with AD. Many studies show a positive association between heavy alcohol consumption and AD development and progression. Our proposal explores how chronic alcohol consumption affects the liver and brain to induce and/or exacerbate AD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Contact PD/PI: Fawzi, Wafaie W Project Narrative The HBNU Fogarty Global Health Training Program, a consortium of Harvard University, Boston University, Northwestern University and the University of New Mexico, proposes to continue to contribute to global health research capacity building and the use of research to improve the health outcomes related to priority health areas in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) in partnership with 18 sites throughout Africa, Asia, and South America. The Program will recruit US and LMIC trainees to strengthen global health research networks and programs at academic institutions and ultimately help sustain global health research in the US and LMICs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Acute lower respiratory infection (ALRI) is a predominant cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Respiratory viruses are the major cause of ALRI, with influenza virus, SARS-CoV-2, respiratory syncytial virus, human metapneumovirus, and the parainfluenza viruses causing the major burden. Our major objective is to define the structural and mechanistic determinants mediating the neutralization and protection against paramyxoviruses, with a specific focus on the parainfluenza viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Measles (MeV) causes a severe transient immunosuppression in healthy individuals and can cause lethal encephalitis in immunocompromised people. The current live vaccine virus is effective but requires low temperature for transport and cannot be used in severely immune compromised individuals. Recent advances in our MeV research are ready to be applied to developing a new vaccine strategy that will lead to a thermostable subunit vaccine that will also be safe for the severely immune compromised individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of the proposed research is to understand mechanisms of ribosome assembly, its quality control as well as the consequences of their failure, when misassembled ribosomes escape into the translating pool, leading to diseases phenotypes. These questions will be addressed in a combination of biochemical, genetics, genomics and structural tools, largely using yeast as a model organism, but addressing questions of disease-relevance in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the research is to improve derivatives of oxamniquine (OXA) that are cidal against all human schistosomes, not just S. mansoni. We have identified a OXA derivative that will kill S. mansoni, S. haematobium and S. japonicum adult and liver stage worms as well as praziquantel resistant worms in in vivo assays. The purpose is to provide a second drug to be used in combination with praziquantel that will improve efficacy and mitigate resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Current acellular pertussis vaccines do not prevent nasal colonization or transmission of B. pertussis, highlighting the need for next-generation vaccines that generate mucosal immunity. Here we will test a novel booster vaccine for adults and a novel pediatric vaccine that incorporates novel CD4+ T cell recognized antigens from B. pertussis that generate tissue-resident T cells in the nose and lungs. We hypothesize that these vaccines will reduce nasal colonization in individuals previously immunized with acellular pertussis vaccines and prevent development of a B. pertussis nasal reservoir in infants who are immunized this new formulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbial cooperative and competition interactions are common, and in pathogenic organisms, often important drivers of biofilm formation and antimicrobial resistance. In the airways of cystic fibrosis patients, Pseudomonas aeruginosa cells frequently grow in freely suspended aggregates, however, the mechanisms that govern the shape and size of bacterial aggregates during infection are not well defined. This project will provide greater understanding of the interplay between physical environmental constraints imposed by polymers, properties of the bacterial cell surface and how these factors impact on aggregate formation, antimicrobial tolerance and quorum sensing-dependent cell-to-cell interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpes simplex virus causes infection in mucosal epithelial cells and causes lesions and spreads to sensory neurons where it establishes a latent infection, from which it can later reactivate and cause recurrent disease. This application investigates how human host cells attempt to prevent the viral DNA from expressing its genes and how the virus has mechanisms to neutralize this effect. Knowledge of this battle between virus and its host cell will provide opportunities to develop antiviral strategies to combat viral infection and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study involves identifying antecedents (i.e., psychological distress, drinking motives, and microaggressions) of heavy drinking in real-time among bisexual and heterosexual women with and without histories of sexual assault. Investigation of antecedents of heavy drinking is of immediate public health importance due to the very high rates of heavy drinking and sexual assault among bisexual women, particularly those with histories of sexual assault. Identifying event-level antecedents will aid in the development of ecological momentary and/or just-in-time interventions to decrease heavy drinking among bisexual women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type III secretion (T3S) is arguably the most important route through which gram-negative animal pathogens cause disease in humans. The characterization of secretion-substrate recognition and the T3S-specificity switch for the Salmonella injectisome systems will further our understanding of host-pathogen interactions, protein- secretion specificity, nanomachine self-assembly and coupled gene regulatory mechanisms. These complex mechanisms provide a wealth of potential therapeutic targets to inhibit T3S-associated pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although there have been over 250,000 pregnant women with SARS CoV-2, there are limited data on rates of in utero transmission of SARS-CoV-2 due to diagnostic challenges. The overall goal of this study is to identify newborns with in utero SARS-CoV-2 infection and investigate clinical, virologic, and immunologic factors that may contribute to MTCT and neonatal immune and clinical outcomes. We plan a comprehensive algorithm to screen newborns for in utero SARS-CoV-2 and will determine if there are immunologic dysfunctions impacting clinical, neurodevelopmental, neurologic, and other abnormalities that may require long-term follow-up, treatments and/or interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Syphilis affects millions of people worldwide, and its global rates are on the rise. Syphilis causative agent, Treponema pallidum (T. pallidum), can cause severe neurological sequelae, and individuals with syphilis are at higher risk of transmitting and acquiring HIV. Applying our newly developed genetic engineering approach to the syphilis agent will provide us with a better understanding of syphilis pathogenesis and pathogen persistence, and help devise new methods to control this serious infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The nervous system has the remarkable ability to sustain its function over lifetime of an organism. The goals of this research program are to advance our knowledge of how axons and synapses are formed and maintained, and the proposed experiments will identify new mechanisms underlying dynamic cellular processes that ensure function of neural circuits. The findings will offer fundamental insights into how genetic mutations and environmental insults cause dys-regulation of neural circuits, leading to neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquitoes infect hundreds of millions of people with deadly pathogens every year. Since mosquitoes rely heavily on their sense of smell to find and bite humans, one promising strategy to control such pathogens is the deployment of repellant and attractive odor blends that push mosquitoes away from humans or pull them into lethal traps. Our research will provide a transformative inroad into the rational design of such blends by mapping individual odor-sensing neurons on mosquito antennae to the molecular receptors they express and the human odorants they detect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of the proposed research is to understand how cells acquire the capacity to elicit specific responses to environmental cues. We aim to define the mechanistic roles of a novel chromatin remodeling complex in equipping T cells early in development with the potential to kill, secrete cytokines, and promote other T cell-specific functions. Understanding these fundamental processes will allow the modulation of T cell effector programming which can enhance vaccination, cancer immunotherapy and ameliorate autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Enhanced antioxidant capacity in cancer cells is an important contributor to the malignancy, metastatic potential and lethality of tumors. Antioxidants display heterogenous distribution among subcellular compartments, through its involvement in cancer progression and metastasis remains poorly understood. Using mitochondrial glutathione as a model, this proposal seeks to determine its role in metastasis, decipher its sensing mechanism and develop new tools to profile its distribution in the tumor microenvironment at the single-cell resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hippocampus is the central brain structure without which we could not navigate our environment or remember recent events. The hippocampal synaptic circuits that mediate information transfer and contribute to the storage and retrieval of memories are therefore crucial to our understanding of memory deficits associated with aging and neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease. In this project we will dissect the mechanisms that contribute to plasticity of a hippocampal synapse and determine how this contributes to specific forms of episodic memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a critical congenital heart disease that affects about 1 in 2520 babies born in the US each year, and frequently requires lifesaving surgery within the first year of life and valve replacement. Due to the characteristic blood flow dynamics in TOF, fetal semilunar heart valves and their supporting structures are susceptible to flow-induced prenatal pathophysiological remodeling that alters deposition of important constituents (such as collagen and elastin) in valve leaflets, impacting their competence. Using in vivo echocardiography and correlative multiscale imaging, as well as computational and mathematical modeling, this project will establish predictive relationships between abnormal blood flow in fetal TOF and detrimental remodeling of valves, ultimately guiding lifesaving treatment strategies for babies with TOF.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Achieving Maternal Equity and Transforming Health through Implementation Science and Training (AMETHIST@Penn) The Achieving Maternal Equity and Transforming Health through Implementation Science and Training (AMETHIST@Penn) Hub will support the vision of the NIH IMPROVE initiative by providing consultation and technical assistance to Maternal Health Research Centers of Excellence and other IMPROVE investigators. The AMETHIST@Penn team will work closely with NIH staff and the Data Innovation and Coordinating Hub/Resource Center and will support equity-focused maternal health implementation research through five Cores: (1) Administration, Leadership, and Evaluation; (2) Equity, Community, and Stakeholder Engagement; (3) Design, Methods, and Analysis; (4) Policy, Dissemination, and Communication; and (5) Training and Capacity Building. AMETHIST@Penn will serve IMPROVE investigators by advising them in engaging diverse and sometimes marginalized communities; guiding the process of implementation research including the selection of theories, models, frameworks, strategies, and outcomes; and accelerating implementation skills development in emerging and established maternal health scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial calcium transport proteins regulate important physiological functions, including cell bioenergetics, cytoplasmic calcium signaling, and the initiation of cell death. This project will determine their molecular mechanisms and the mechanisms by which small-molecule compounds modulate their activities. The results will advance our molecular understanding of the physiologically crucial mitochondrial calcium transport process, and can provide key information to facilitate the development of new medicines to treat diseases related to abnormal mitochondrial calcium homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic interventions, such as exposure therapy, reduce pathological fear in patients with anxiety disorders—but this fear reduction is often transient and vulnerable to relapse. Stress undermines exposure therapy by disabling brain circuits critical for extinction learning. The long-term goal of this project is to understand the circuit and cellular mechanisms by which stress undermines extinction learning, a program of study that is essential for improving the long-term efficacy of exposure-based therapies .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative tRNAs are essential for decoding the genome and regulating the proteome in response to nutrient availability and stress. We employ the powerful budding yeast model system and genetics/genomics, microscopy, molecular, and biochemical in vivo technologies to resolve key unknowns including tRNA nuclear/cytoplasmic bidirectional trafficking, quality control, and intron turnover/function. The requested Integra Mini 96-well channel pipette will facilitate genome-wide screens to discover importers/regulators of tRNA retrograde nuclear import and identify tRNA intron turnover machinery by allowing high throughput biochemical/molecular procedures to be conducted in the 96-well format.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low exercise capacity is one of the strongest predictors for the risk of chronic disease and mortality. However, improvements to exercise capacity in response to exercise training can be blunted in people and animal models with hyperglycemia; a condition that is becoming increasingly prevalent as rates of metabolic disease rise globally. This study will determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms for low response to exercise training associated with hyperglycemia, and test specific therapies to improve exercise capacity, which may ultimately lead to better health and increased lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pancreatitis is a painful and debilitating disease with few medical treatment options. Patients often require pancreatic surgery for relief of pain, but pancreatic surgery may increase the risk for blood glucose abnormalities and diabetes mellitus. At the University of Minnesota, we will enroll patients in multiple clinical research studies in the Chronic Pancreatitis Diabetes Pancreatic Cancer (CPDPC) Consortium and will develop new clinical studies that better define how different pancreatic surgeries impact diabetes risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative These studies seek to identify the role of erythropoietin (EPO) in macrophage training during alloimmune response taking advantage of conditional KO mice. The experiments will employ: i) mouse models of heart transplantation with prolonged cold ischemia storage, ii) life-sustaining kidney transplant models (showing pathological features similar to those found in human transplant recipients), and iii) previously stored samples from kidney transplant recipients treated with EPO. The proposed mechanistic studies will improve our understanding of alloimmunity and will identify therapeutic targets to improve outcomes of transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Defective immune tolerance promotes autoreactive T effector lymphocytes, which destroy the insulin-producing β cells in the pancreatic islets, causing overt hyperglycemia. The goal of our application is to design, develop, and rigorously test the engineered regulatory T cells carrying Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) recognizing unique β cells surface antigen, NDTPase3, for their ability to suppress diabetic autoimmunity in both in vitro and in vivo settings. We expect our CAR Tregs to accumulate within pancreatic islets and efficiently protect them from autoimmune assault, forming the foundation for future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Tuberculosis (TB), a worldwide infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb), has over the last few decades, become resistant to one or more anti-TB drugs, which is a big challenge for TB eradication program. We discovered that M.tb infection enhances the expression and activity of MDR1 in macrophages, which allows the macrophage to transport TB drugs and endogenous anti-microbial out of the cells, thereby promoting M.tb growth. We will investigate whether inhibition of MDR1 expression in mice shortens the TB treatment period and enhance the M.tb killing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: How our brain senses and responds to changes in blood glucose levels is incompletely understood. We have identified Adgrl1 as a glucoreceptor in the brain, which appears to be involved in counteracting hypoglycemia (dangerously low blood glucose levels). Through this study, we will establish the contribution of Adgrl1 to glucose sensing in the brain and its function in glucose homeostasis including counteracting hypoglycemia. Adgrl1 may emerge as a new target for preventing hypoglycemia or associated autonomic failure in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WHO estimated that 20% of the world’s population suffer from respiratory allergies and derived diseases such as allergic rhinitis and asthma. However, there is still no clear answer to the question: “why do only some people develop allergy?”, underscoring the need to revisit our understanding of immune mechanisms of allergy. Using novel genomics unbiased tools, we discovered a new type of T cells, we called THIFNR cells, that may play an important role in preventing pathogenic inflammation in allergy and asthma. This grant aims to advance our understanding of the role of this novel subset in controlling allergic immune responses. Our work will provide novel mechanistic insights that may lead to the development of better therapeutic options for patients with allergic diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Our work over the past two decades has focused on understanding caspase regulation at a structural level and has resulted in development of the most selective and potent caspase-6 inhibitor to date. IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE To understand disease mechanisms and develop effective treatments, we need to untangle the relationship between genetics and phenotypes of all organisms (such as human, mouse, zebrafish, and fruitfly). Sophisticated comparative information systems are needed to collect, search, and compare the diverse and often mutually incompatible data being generated. The Monarch Initiative has amassed the largest open collection of multi-species genotype-phenotype data in the world; here we propose to extend Monarch’s technology, data resources, and tools to use organismal data to advance precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a complex cardiac disease is a leading cause of heart failure. The emergence of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) technology offers an experimental human-based model to predict and model individual disease manifestations. The goal of this project is to study the underlying mechanisms of DCM by investigating the intricate crosstalk between cardiomyocytes and endothelial cells using bioengineering tools and next generation sequencing. Results from this work could potentially lead to new strategies that could lower morbidity and mortality, but also improve the management of DCM patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The way an individual responds to cues associated with rewards may be a key determinant in vulnerability to addiction and relapse. We will utilize an animal model to identify critical components of the neural circuitry that that contribute to individual differences in cue-reward learning and relapse propensity. The findings from these studies will enhance our understanding of the pathophysiology of substance abuse and could lead to novel targets for the treatment of addiction and related disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Community college students make up almost half of the college population, but very little research has focused specifically on this underserved group, and no research has examined their sexual health across emerging adulthood—a critical period during which the achievement of vocational, relational, and identity development milestones are intertwined with sexual decision making. We propose a project to 1) conduct the first longitudinal investigation of media use, sexual health, and quality of life of community college students across emerging adulthood—helping to expand theory and identify the most pressing directions for future programming— and 2) conduct a mixed methods study to better understand how community colleges can create more inclusive and affirming environments to support the sexual health of sexual and gender minority youth. Together, with an advisory panel of community college stakeholders, we will disseminate findings to research communities and decision makers at community colleges across the U.S., to help them better address the needs of the rising generation of emerging adults attending community college.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer cells employ lysosome-mediated nutrient acquisition strategies to survive limited nutrient availability in the harsh tumor microenvironment. Here, we will develop innovative technologies to profile the lysosomal molecular content at cell-type-specific resolution in tumors in vivo. Our work will enable the discovery of how cells adapt to fluctuations in nutrient availability and uncover cancer-specific metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited to treat human malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Solid tumors are responsible for the majority of cancer deaths in the United States. Researchers have been unable to widely employ CAR T cells, an effective form of cancer immunotherapy, to solid tumors due to a lack of tumor specific antigen targets and the risk of toxicity when target antigens are shared with normal, vital tissues. This project will optimize innovative and completely novel receptors capable of logic-gated control of CAR T cells, greatly enhancing their safety and tumor specificity, opening the door to effective therapy of solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Although both cancer rates and metabolic deregulation increase with age, it is not well understood how age-dependent metabolic changes affect cancer initiation and progression. In addition, we have limited knowledge of how age-associated metabolic differences in the tumor microenvironment contribute to carcinogenesis and how these changes are affected by environmental factors such as diet and microbial metabolites. In this proposal, we plan to elucidate age- associated metabolic changes in tumors and their microenvironment using advanced single cell technologies, which may lead to discovering metabolic liabilities and improve existing therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work seeks to define and exploit the neuronal identity of solid tumors to prevent cancer metastasis, the leading cause of death in cancer patients. Recently, the presence of peripheral nerves in solid tumors and the upregulation of neuronal genes within tumor cells themselves were both reported be associated with poor outcome in cancer. We will use cell biology, engineering and clinically translatable approaches to understand how neoneurogenesis occurs in tumors, how the neural identity of tumors impacts the systemic regulation of metastasis and how we can leverage this information for non-invasive monitoring and treatment of metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Almost all advanced cancers will eventually progress on treatment, but the emergence of resistance in cancer is poorly understood despite its clinical importance. The primary challenge is that serial tissue samples (pre- and post-resistance as well as in-between) must be obtained to understand the molecular mechanisms of resistance, but this is not feasible at scale given the logistical challenges as well as potential for procedure- related complications of invasive tissue sampling. We propose to utilize a novel integrated clinical-grade liquid biopsy platform to comprehensively profile DNA, RNA, and methylation alterations from blood samples in order to more fully understand the dynamic evolution of treatment resistance in cancer, and to develop potential biomarkers for early detection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Stroke is a number one cause of long-term disability in the United States, affecting approximately 6.6 million Americans, with a total projected cost of $2.2 trillion from 2005 to 2050. Following a stroke, more than two-thirds end up with a disability in the upper limb that lowers the ability to perform many daily activities, including self-care, vocations, and leisure, thus diminishing the quality of life. This project aims to evaluate a new technology in enhancing hand functional recovery following stroke, thereby improving independence and quality of life, with a cost-effective method.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide, with early detection being critical for improving prognosis. This supplemental project, in response to NOT-CA-24- 058, proposes to leverage the National Lung Screening Trial (NLST) dataset to improve early lung cancer diagnosis by characterizing the differential trajectory of benign and malignant nodules on serial CTs. By integrating advanced AI-based algorithms, harmonizing CT scans, and incorporating patient-specific characteristics, we aim to enhance precision in lung cancer risk stratification and aid early detection efforts, ultimately reducing lung cancer mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depressive symptoms are prevalent in up to 40% individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). People affected by AD and depression show altered transcriptome and epigenome, but the shared molecular changes underlying AD-depression comorbidity is not understood. This proposal aims to identify coding and non-coding regulatory variants associated with shared genetic risk for depression and AD in multiple cohorts.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Despite decades of research, advancements in vehicle technology, and various intervention and legislative efforts, stark racial and ethnic disparities in child occupant safety persist. This research will use a breadth-to- depth approach that integrates knowledge obtained from population-level analyses (breadth) and individual-level data collection (depth) to identify why and where racial and ethnic disparities arise in child occupant safety, with a goal of directly informing future interventions and policies. This work is the next critical step to bolster protective efforts for the most vulnerable children, and will ultimately reduce the burden of crashes experienced by children, their families, and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Colorectal cancer (CRC) is the third most common cancer in men and the second in women with a worldwide total of over 1.8 million new cases per year. Dietary factors play an important role in CRC because these tumors develop adjacent to the intestinal lumen and receive direct exposure to ingested nutrients, chemicals, and microbiota throughout the day. Fructose consumption is associated with CRC risk and CRC-specific mortality so this proposal will test how the major fructose metabolite, fructose 1-phosphate, alters cellular metabolism to promote tumor cell survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease continues to be a leading cause of mortality, despite effective therapies available for known risk factors such as high cholesterol and high blood pressure. This proposal uses a genetic approach to understand the mechanism by which the gene TSPAN14 is involved in coronary disease, and thus may reveal new therapeutic targets. We will use cell and animal models to understand how genetic variation between humans control the function of this unstudied gene in healthy and diseased blood vessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative As structure dictates the function of a biomolecule, proteins that naturally transition among more than one native fold may operate as regulatory switches by adopting distinct functional folds to modulate dynamic cellular processes, as is the case for the mitotic checkpoint protein MAD2 in humans, whose defective fold-switching is often found in cancerous diseases. To grasp and further modulate protein switches inside cells requires fully understanding the co-translational folding energy landscapes that govern the pathways along which these polypeptides attempt to fold as they are being synthesized. Using single-molecule optical tweezers and an in vitro human translation system, I aim to resolve the molecular trajectories of folding for MAD2 and mutant variants as they emerge on the human ribosome in the presence of folding effectors—and complementing with the dynamic fold-switching flux of MAD2 visualized via cell imaging—to provide mechanistic insights on MAD2 protein switch repair for potential treatments in cancers and other medical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The precise mechanisms by which the positive effects of bariatric surgery are conferred to efficiently and sustainably ameliorate the symptoms and sequalae of obesity remain unclear. We will employ unique mouse models and advanced technologies to examine the molecular mechanisms by which conjugated bile acids contribute to metabolic improvement after bariatric surgery. The results of our studies will provide insights that could lead to cost-effective, non-surgical therapies for obesity and its complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Statement - P30GM133894 The purpose of the P30 Resource is to provide the biomedical community with access to state- of- the-art facilities for macromolecular crystallography, small-angle x-ray scattering, and x-ray spectroscopy/imaging, tools that are essential for the study of biological systems. They enable information that is prerequisite for understanding fundamentals of life, and provide methods that are central to the development of new therapeutics for human disease. The overarching goal is to provide an integrated Resource that makes mature technologies available to a broad research community, and provides researchers with expert support in their use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE  At present there is an enormous need for new safe and efficacious treatments designed to relieve the burden of  chronic pain and substance use disorders (SUD). However, there is a deficit of scientists trained to conduct  clinical research investigating pain and SUD that can move the fields forward. In order to address this gap, we  propose the Promoting Excellence through Pain and Addiction Research Enhancement (PREPARE) Program  with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of investigators who will advance science through cutting  edge clinical research that helps relieve pain and ameliorate SUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the US and in the world. The overall goal of the Cancer Prevention Clinical Trials Network (CP-CTNet) is to perform early phase cancer prevention clinical trials to identify safe and effective preventive agents and interventions that can advance to late phases of clinical development, to ultimately reduce the risk and burden of cancer. Working with the National Cancer Institute's Division of Cancer Prevention and the CP-CTNet Sites, the CP-CTNet Data Management, Auditing, and Coordinating Center will coordinate trans-network activities and support these early phase trials by providing expertise and resources in 1) centralized data management and reporting, 2) clinical trials auditing, and 3) administrative and logistical coordination, including expertise in clinical trials methodology and biostatistics, across CP-CTNet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen that causes cryptococcal meningitis, a severe HIV-associated infection of the central nervous system. In healthy individuals, C. neoformans establishes latent infections that reactivate and cause clinical symptoms upon HIV-associated immunosuppression, yet disease manifestation differs across patients. Using a mouse model, this research will determine the continuum of patient immune responses and fungal genetic factors that influence clinical outcome towards the goal of developing novel immune-modulatory treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Back pain is one of the most common and disabling chronic pain conditions in the United States. Most cases remain poorly managed and many sufferers face barriers to equitable care which has led to unacceptable disparities in back pain management, with Black and Hispanic Americans, as well as individuals with less education and income, experiencing poorer outcomes. This project aims to address barriers that currently exist within the healthcare system by co-developing with community stakeholders, accessible evidence-based complementary and integrative health approaches that can be offered in community settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. While new low-dose com- puted tomography (LDCT) screening programs nationwide enable earlier detection of lung cancer, a high number of indeterminate pulmonary nodules (IPNs) are being found – many of which are benign, but still with some risk of cancer. This supplemental project aims to leverage the large collection of longitudinal clinical and imaging data on individuals who underwent LDCT as part of the National Lung Screening Trial with established cancer outcomes to identify robust longitudinal imaging biomarkers that can be used to predict malignancy, reducing overtreatment and the burden and anxiety associated with managing IPNs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells must inherit the right number of chromosomes every time they divide. Defects in this process are the most common chromosomal abnormality in cancer cells and contribute to birth defects and other diseases. We are therefore studying the process of chromosome distribution to daughter cells when they divide to understand the basis for a number of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis is the leading cause of sexually transmitted infection and elicits a major burden on reproductive health throughout the world. This project will globally define Chlamydia genes that are critical for mediating this bacterium’s ability to infect cells and establish acute and severe infections in a murine female genital tract infection model. The knowledge to be gained from these efforts will open up numerous new avenues of investigation for the field focused on determining the molecular function of proteins encoded by the essential genes, as well as potential novel therapeutics and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this project is to elucidate the brain circuitry responsible for addiction-like food motivation or “compulsive appetite” – an overlapping ramification of extensive drug and obesogenic diet histories – in rats. Candidate brain circuitry will be identified and validated in functional units of brain cells thought to provide the “brake” on food motivation. Our hope is that such knowledge will help developing medications for compulsive behavior, perhaps, across eating disorders and drug addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this study is to determine whether effective treatment of hypertension impacts brain blood flow, amyloid, and tau, hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), in older adults who are at high risk of dementia. Furthermore, we will determine the impact of hypertension treatment on brain white mater integrity and neural network connectivity and their relationship to brain amyloid and tau deposition. The new knowledge obtained is potentially important for development of multidomain strategies for dementia prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One gene can produce many proteins that are minor variants of each other. Cancer is not just caused by mutations in genes, but these variant gene products, called “proteoforms”, but most cancer models do not include this critical information. This project will derive innovative network biology approaches to completely model these protein variants, for improved biomarker and target drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplement requests funds to tailor an ad-hoc pipeline for data analysis of the high-density NCANDA dataset (mNCANDA + Fitbit) and prepare a dataset and data dictionary of the summary variables that can be added to the main NCANDA dataset for public release. These data capture how changes in alcohol use and other substances are associated with dynamic changes in sleep, physical activity, and heart rate. This supplement, therefore, supports the goals of NCANDA-A to identify neural, behavioral, and environmental risk markers for problem adolescent and emerging adult alcohol use, determine the impact of alcohol exposure variations (timing, dose, and duration) on brain maturation and behavior, identify characteristics predicting AUD resilience and recovery, and characterize sex-specific risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are one of the main immune components that control autoimmune disease and are selectively disrupted in the setting of Interleukin-2 (IL-2) signaling deficiencies. Numerous studies are examining the therapeutic potential of low-dose IL-2, but these evaluations would benefit by a more complete knowledge concerning the mechanisms by which IL-2 effects mature Tregs. This study will address fundamental questions surrounding the contribution of IL-2 receptor signaling for Treg survival, differentiation, and function to aid in the therapeutic application of this cytokine and to better define potential targets related to IL-2/IL-2 receptor genetic risk for autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will be the first longitudinal study to examine the effects of early-life exposure to breast milk poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) on infant growth trajectories and risk for childhood obesity in the context of the infant gut microbiome and fecal metabolome. Study findings will address a critical gap in our current understanding of breast milk PFAS and their obesogenic effects. Results from this proposal are expected to have significant implications in terms of identifying alterations in gut bacterial species and/or fecal metabolic pathways that contribute to obesity risk. These findings can be used in future novel intervention modalities applicable to Hispanic infants who are at increased risk of early-onset obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thrive Digital Health (TDH) is developing and testing a novel technology platform to enhance, standardize and scale the training of the Peer Recovery Supporter workforce. Peer Recovery Support Services are being increasingly implemented across the U.S. as a strategy to fill care gaps, and this platform will enable public and private organizations to efficiently and cost-effectively build their PRSS workforce, and support that workforce on an ongoing basis as they serve individuals recovering from alcohol and other substance use disorders. Over time, the innovations resulting from this project will significantly reduce costs for individuals, public and private payers, the healthcare system, and society at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium ovale and Plasmodium vivax are resistant to many current malaria control interventions, due to evolutionary advantages affecting transmission and relapse. They are increasingly identified in infections in Africa and, in the case of vivax, potentially evolving to overcome limitations to red blood cell invasion. This proposal seeks to provide the evidence base and to develop tools needed to face challenges associated with control of relapsing malarias by providing fundamental knowledge about the infectious reservoir and vectors involved in transmission, developing tools to understand relapse and defining mechanisms by which vivax malaria may be evolving to expand its range and impact in Africa.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research evaluates DENV and ZIKV immunity in humans living in endemic and non-endemic settings. This knowledge is critical to understanding the potency, breadth, determinants and correlates of ZIKV and DENV immunity as well as effective evaluation and improvement of this vaccine that is critical to control this globally important disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal develops a novel method for carrying out multiplexed measurements on large numbers of single cells. The methods developed will allow researchers to leverage new comprehensive “atlases" of tumor cells for a wide range of studies from evaluating the effects of new drug treatments, to identifying tumor cells that predict patient outcomes. Within this advanced development grant, we move from established technical capabilities to two mature fully-working methods for single cell analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal focuses on the molecular mechanisms that underlie initiation and progression of valvular heart diseases, which is one of leading causes of death worldwide and highly relevant to the mission of the NIH. We will focus on studying a new regulatory protein that controls the endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition, a biological process that governs heart valve structure and function, and investigating how abnormal endothelial- to-mesenchymal results in mitral valve thickening, a common cause of mitral stenosis. We anticipate the study of this important developmental, physiological and pathological process will identify new molecular pathways that can be exploited as therapeutic targets to combat valvular heart diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Degenerative mitral regurgitation (DMR) impacts approximately 3% of the general population and 10% of adults older than 75 years, and while treatment strategies for severe DMR have evolved, clarity on the clinical effectiveness of transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) versus surgical repair remains elusive. Our proposed study will utilize the resources of our high-volume mitral valve disease referral center including advanced multimodality imaging to compare long-term clinical and patient-reported outcome measures of both treatments retrospectively and prospectively, and their clinical and imaging correlates. Our overarching goal is to generate real-world clinical data that will facilitate development of robust clinical risk scores that can ultimately inform treatment decision making for patients with severe DMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic inequities in health care quality have been described across a broad range of clinical settings, patient populations, and outcomes and it is now imperative that we move forward to develop and test interventions to mitigate and eradicate such inequities. In response to the RFA-NS-22-002: HEAL Initiative: Advancing Health Equity in Pain Management (R61/R33), the objectives of this proposal are to develop and test the impact of two interventions – 1) regularly provided clinician audit and feedback, through the provision of ‘Equity Report Cards’ and 2) provision of real time, electronic health record-embedded clinical decision support – on overcoming clinician implicit bias and mitigating inequities in the management of pain among children seeking care in the emergency department for the treatment of appendicitis or long bone fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One gene can produce many proteins that are minor variants of each other. Cancer is not just caused by mutations in genes, but these variant gene products, called “proteoforms”, but most cancer models do not include this critical information. This project will derive innovative network biology approaches to completely model these protein variants, for improved biomarker and target drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Aggression varies substantially between different people, and extreme levels of aggression have negative consequences for individuals and society. This proposal will leverage genetic tools and resources in an emerging model system to investigate the genetic and neuronal basis of variability in aggression. Elucidating the genetic architecture underlying differences in aggression in natural populations will help establish why individual differences in social behaviors manifest, which could lead to long term solutions for treatment and management.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Maternal mental illness can adversely modify the developmental trajectory of the child and is a significant contributor to maternal mortality in the U.S. A significant portion of women can experience traumatic childbirth, and some will develop posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), although this condition remains underdiagnosed and undertreated. This study will define the course and predictors of maternal childbirth-related PTSD and its effects on the child and lay the foundation for preventive and holistic care for both mother and child.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an unmet need in the HIV vaccine field for immunogens that consistently elicit potent and broad neutralizing antibodies. We have demonstrated that HIV-1 fusion peptide prime and Env boost is a promising strategy and will test novel immunogens and immunization strategies to improve the breadth, magnitude, and quality of the fusion peptide-directed neutralizing responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Secondary lymphoid organs are a major site for HIV-1 spread and harbor viral reservoirs, which are a barrier to curing AIDS. The proposed project in this application addresses the questions how HIV-1 disseminates in secondary lymphoid organs and how viral reservoirs are generated in these organs. The outcomes of the proposed studies may contribute to developing a new strategy to prevent HIV-1 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Natural killer (NK) cells play a key role in early control of HIV infection and we have recently uncovered that in people living with HIV, a subset of memory NK cells can specifically recognize and efficiently eliminate cells presenting peptide antigens derived from HIV. This proposal is designed to comprehensively determine the mechanisms regulating the development and function of memory NK cells with potent anti-viral activity. The outcome of these investigations will provide the rationale to harness memory NK cells for vaccine design, curative or other therapeutic interventions against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Exosomes are nano-sized vesicles produced by all cells in both physiological and pathological states that play a vital role in multiple biological processes including cell-cell communication, immune regulation, tissue development and regeneration, and cancer metastasis. Exosomes represent excellent candidates for the development of new diagnostic and therapeutic tools, yet the mechanism controlling their biogenesis is poorly understood. In this Project, we will study the role of long non-coding RNA (a novel class of gene expression regulators) on exosome biogenesis, thereby advancing our understanding of these mechanisms and providing the basis for the use of exosomes as novel biomarkers and the development of new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Environmental or occupational exposures to hexavalent chromium Cr(VI) have been associated with a number of adverse health effects; yet, little is known about its impact on skeletal muscles. This proposal aims to investigate the effect of Cr(VI) exposure on myogenic differentiation and muscle regeneration. The success of the proposed research will generate valuable evidence to support Cr(VI) exposure as a risk factor for muscle impairment, and provide additional insights on prevention and therapeutic approaches for muscle-associated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Uterine leiomyomas (UL), also known as fibroids, are the leading cause of hysterectomy in the United States. These benign tumors, which are more common among Black individuals, can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and infertility. This project will examine the age distribution of when UL occur, the extent to which UL characteristics (size, number, location) predict symptom severity, and environmental factors associated with UL occurrence and growth in a cohort of Black individuals during a 15-year period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative T cells are a class of immune cells that fight diseases and cancer, whereas regulatory T cells (Tregs) are an opposing class that are essential to prevent autoimmune disease and rejection of organ or bone marrow transplants. Our project aims to understand how DNA methylation and demethylation affect T cell expansion and regulatory T cell function. This may give us new methods for improving how T cells and regulatory T cells function in the body to improve the efficacy of patient treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunosuppression is a major risk factor for non-healing wounds, indicating that signals derived from immune cells are necessary for optimal repair. Yet, exactly how lymphocytes are activated in wounds and their molecular dialogue with injured epithelium is ill defined. The goal of this proposal is to understand how type 17 immune cells are activated in response to injury and elucidate their mechanistic crosstalk with the epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic research offers a unique opportunity for rare disease diagnosis and understanding that may be transformative for people living with these complex conditions, however, access to these opportunities is inequitably distributed. With this project, we take an implementation science approach to the development and evaluation of a toolkit to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion in rare disease genomic research via a novel initiative within the Rare Genomes Project (Aim 1); evaluate the effectiveness and impact of research genome sequencing for diverse populations by identifying genetic diagnoses for historically underserved and minoritized communities (Aim 2); and explore the priorities and values of diverse populations with rare diseases undergoing research sequencing within a large consortium (Aim 3). The findings from this research will inform both research and clinical applications of genome sequencing with the ultimate goal of advancing equity for individuals and families with rare disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The diversity, population size, and health challenges of metropolitan Houston provides an ideal setting for a new NIDA R25: Providing Research Education Experiences to Enhance Diversity in the Next Generation of Substance Abuse and Addiction Scientists. The University of Houston (UH) will leverage its Helping Everyone Achieve a LifeTime of Health (HEALTH) Research Institute and NIMHD RCMI (HEALTH Center for Addictions Research and Cancer Prevention) to serve as the platform for executing an innovative substance abuse research education program to the future generation of scientists underrepresented in the biomedical, behavioral, clinical, and social sciences. The HEALTH – Future Addiction Scientist Training (HEALTH – FAST) Program will leverage a transdisciplinary approach to health-equity science with a focus on how substance use/abuse leads to chronic diseases that disproportionately affect health-disparity populations.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Gender diverse children often experience disparities in mental health and well-being. Further questions concern the stability of their gender as that has implications for medical transitions. The proposed work would examine the role of gender beliefs and self-categorization in predicting mental health and well-being, as well as provide better estimates of rates of stability and change across time in the identities of both cisgender and gender diverse youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysfunction of lymphatic vessels can lead to lymphedema and no-healing ulcers, affecting over 250 million people worldwide. Here I propose to examine the role of repair and immune-modulatory functions of lymphatic vessels in the control of wound repair to further our understanding of the cellular and molecular factors that underlie this complex process. My studies will uncover novel targets aimed at modulating lymphatic vessels, immune cells, and epidermal stem cells to advance therapeutic approaches in pathological tissue repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Neuropathic pain is a serious and long-term neurotoxic side effect of chemotherapy affecting more than 68% of cancer patients and is currently without treatment. Peripheral neuropathy and pain have also been associated with Alzheimer’s. Our studies on sensory neuronal maintenance have found NMNAT proteins to be among the most robust and versatile neuroprotective factors known and have the potential to mitigate sensory dysfunction. The proposed studies will employ innovative technologies to discover microRNA and neutral compound-based neuroprotective strategies to enhance NMNAT-mediated therapeutic treatments for neuropathic pain in the context of chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy and Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proper three-dimensional organization of DNA within the nucleus is critically important for healthy cells, and alterations to organization are associated with developmental disease and cancer. This research program aims to better characterize the patterns of DNA organization that occur in healthy cells and to investigate how these impact important cellular processes such as gene expression, DNA replication, and DNA repair. A more complete understanding of how 3D genome organization functions within the cell will provide key insights into why this process is associated with human disease and may inform new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein tyrosine sulfation plays important roles in, e.g., protein-protein interactions, inflammation, and viral infections. Due to the extreme lability of this posttranslational modification (PTM), global liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry analysis has not been feasible to date; however we discovered a novel workflow that partially enables such measurements. Here, we propose new strategies to further enhance detection and allow site determination of this widespread PTM in cells and tissues.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This novel, timely, and theory-driven Food-Body-Mind intervention addresses the national emergency of mental health crises in early childhood. By targeting Head Start racially/ethnically diverse preschoolers from low-income backgrounds in both urban and rural areas, this intervention is expected to contribute toward reducing health disparities and promoting health equity, a major priority of the NIH and Healthy People 2030. If effective, it can be scalable to Head Start programs across urban and rural settings nationally with long-term sustainability benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative The proper alignment of internal circadian clocks with the 24-hour rhythm of the environment is critical for human well-being. A central goal of chronobiology is to understand how the brain’s circadian clock center is organized and how it is modulated by environmental time-cues. Here we propose a continuation of a productive and impactful research program using Drosophila melanogaster to understand the mechanisms that circadian neural networks employ to create an endogenous sense of time and how these networks integrate environmental time-cues to ensure the proper coordination of the internal circadian system with external time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have developed a non-infectious, self-replicative SARS-CoV-2 replicon system that is a safe and effective tool for antiviral screening and amenable to genetic engineering for studying drug resistance. We have identified a small molecule inhibitor of SARS-CoV-2 antiviral activity, and early medicinal chemistry efforts have optimized this lead. This project aims to further identify and characterize compounds toward the development of novel inhibitors against SARS-CoV-2 with potent, nanomolar antiviral activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic interventions, such as exposure therapy, reduce pathological fear in patients with anxiety disorders—but this fear reduction is often transient and vulnerable to relapse. The impermanence of extinction-based therapy is a major challenge to clinical interventions for a host of disorders, including anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder. Therefore, the long-term goal of this project is to understand the neural substrates of extinction, particularly the specific brain circuits involved in the contextual retrieval of extinguished fear memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Supplement Proposal for the APS CCC  Project Narrative The APS Consortium seeks to understand the heterogeneity and underlying mechanisms of critical illness syndromes and recovery, in adults with ARDS, pneumonia, and/or sepsis, as well as the relationship and biological overlap among these syndromes, and this will be accomplished through a prospective, longitudinal observational study with common data and biospecimen collection of 4,000 hospitalized adults who have or are at risk of developing ARDS, pneumonia, and/or sepsis. Since inception, there has been an expansion from an intended 5 Clinical Centers comprised of ~18 total sites to 6 Clinical Centers comprised of 22 total sites, and a determination that the Consortium would support data capture, statistical plans, and analysis efforts for 7 individual scientific aims as well as other expansions which requires supplemental resources to facilitate rapid and broad sharing of data and biospecimens, a core function of the Consortium. The purpose of this administrative supplement is to enhance, expedite, and expand previously planned activities related to biospecimen and data sharing that are within the scope of the approved award but were unforeseen at the time of submission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plants express small RNAs that accumulate to high levels in reproductive organs harboring the male germline; these small RNAs show interesting parallels to the animal piRNAs, and perturbation of their biogenesis or activities causes sterility. Our proposed study aims to understand the localization, biogenesis, functions, and targets of a specialized class of the small RNAs (the 21-nt phased, small interfering RNAs) that are abundant prior to meiosis, using the maize as the model system. The research outcomes will provide mechanistic insights into the biogenesis and functions of these small RNAs, with the potential to illuminate why plants have evolved this unusual small RNA pathway enriched in or even specific to male reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Tumor cells form various types of clusters along the metastatic cascade, including locally invaded tumor strands,  circulating tumor cell clusters, and micrometastases. Growing evidence suggests that tumor cell clusters exhibit  deleterious advantages over signal tumor cells in terms of invasion, survival, drug resistance, and colonization,  and may be the dominant form of tumor cells that leads to metastases. Hence, understanding how tumor cell  clustering gives rise to these collective advantages is of critical importance in countering cancer. Altered  metabolism is a hallmark of cancer and holds great potential as a therapeutic target. Recent reports suggest that  tumor clusters exhibit a distinct metabolic profile when compared to single tumor cells and that cell-cell binding  can alter cellular ATP production. Hence, we hypothesize that cell clustering may provide tumor clusters with  collective advantages by altering their bioenergetics. We will leverage our expertise in tissue and extracellularmatrix  engineering, metabolic imaging, and computational modeling to test this hypothesis. In Aim 1, we will  investigate how cell-cell interactions affect the bioenergetics of the tumor clusters. We will combine micropattern  and microfabrication to engineer tumor clusters of different sizes and shapes to precisely control the degree of  cell-cell adhesions and develop a physics model to combine the free energy of the cluster system with the active  cellular ATP energy. In Aim 2, we will investigate how cell-matrix interactions affect the bioenergetics of the  tumor cluster. We will engineer the mechanical properties, ligand types, ligand densities, and topography of the  matrix to study how these factors may affect the energy production of the cells in the cluster and the associated  metabolic signaling. In Aim 3, we will investigate how heterogeneous cell-cell interactions and metabolism affect  the bioenergetics and dynamics of the tumor clusters. We will leverage our expertise in sorting cells based on  metabolic or other phenotypes and control the degree of heterogeneous cell-cell interaction by controlling the  mixing ratio of the sorted cell subpopulations. We will further combine experiments and modeling to identify if  tumor clusters of a certain size, shape, and heterogeneity, and in a certain extracellular microenvironment will  become energetically unstable and thus more likely to invade or become less sensitive to perturbations thus  more likely to survive. Together, the proposed study will establish a systematic understanding of how different  aspects of cell clustering contribute to the bioenergetics of each cell in the cluster and the whole cluster, which  may then lead to their collective advantage. As therapeutics that are effective for single cells often fail for tumor  cell clusters, the successful completion of this project will lay the foundation for future studies that allow the  development of efficient cancer therapies to counter cancer as it relates to tumor cell clustering, micrometastases,  and metabolic adaptation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The establishment of left-right (LR) asymmetry is a critical event required for the correct positioning of internal organs. Defects in human LR axis formation cause birth defects of the heart, vasculature, lungs, and intestinal tract. Our research aims to discover the central mechanism that links Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway and transforming growth factor-b (TGF-b) signaling pathway to the establishment of left-right asymmetry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have demonstrated that the unfolded protein response (UPR) pathway in the mold pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus is essential for establishing infection in a mouse model of fungal keratitis. We will test the feasibility of targeting this pathway for treatment by (1) repressing the expression of UPR genes with an exogenous repressor (genetics) and, (2) employing existing pharmacological compounds that target a key UPR protein (drug repurposing). Will also identify downstream UPR targets that may also be important for virulence and, accordingly, represent targets for novel antifungal development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global COVID-19 pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2 has highlighted the extent to which social determinants and inequities impact healthcare received and health outcomes. This project will evaluate maternal and infant effects following the COVID-19 pandemic and SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy including pregnancy complications, adverse birth outcomes, maternal and infant mortality, and maternal one-year post pregnancy cardiovascular and mortality outcomes with a focus on social determinants of health and racial/ethnic differences. Better understanding of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and SARS-CoV-2 infection during pregnancy on maternal and infant morbidity and mortality is needed to guide clinical practice and public health prevention efforts for at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed R01, Improving Medication Adherence with Pharmacist and Community Health Worker Team (IMPaCT) to Reduce Disparities in Hypertension, will test the effectiveness of an innovative, culturally-tailored, coordinated care intervention derived from previous research (RxHL Study, 1R01HL120907) and existing pilot medication therapy management program at the research site. Building on an ecosocial framework of chronic disease self-management, the IMPaCT intervention by pharmacist-community health worker team will identify and address individual, clinical, social-cultural and structural barriers to medication adherence among low- income minority patients with hypertension, polypharmacy use and nonadherence. To determine effectiveness, we will conduct a rigorous, intention-to-treat randomized controlled trial among African-American, Latino and Vietnamese patients at a community health center to create a practical solution to the adherence problem and provide a how-to framework for healthcare workforce to reduce health disparities in hypertension and prevent cardiovascular risks among the vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative All life forms require their genetic material to be organized and packaged into cells, but this genetic sequestration often silences gene expression. Here, the mechanism that relieves the silencing of virulence genes in the bacterial pathogen Shigella, will be studied by undergraduates and graduate students at the University of Nevada Las Vegas. The primary focus of these studies will be a newly identified ligand of the key anti-silencing protein, VirB.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K99 Career Development Award seeks to provide the applicant training in prenatal psychosocial stress and iron assessment, advanced biostatistics focused on machine learning, placental mechanisms of fetal programming, and research with socioeconomically-, ethnically-, and racially minoritized pregnant populations to support the applicant’s transition to research independence. Through the training embedded in this award, the applicant will develop the skills and expertise necessary to build a translational research program within a Developmental Origins of Health and Disease (DOHaD) framework that will examine pathways by which early exposure to psychosocial stress becomes biologically embedded to affect mother and offspring’s mental and physical health. This approach will ultimately identify mechanisms, markers, and modifiable risk factors relevant to maternal health and child development outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and its associated metabolic disorders represent a major threat to the American health, as well as a substantial economic burden. Thermogenic fat is a specialized tissue whose role is to expend excess energy, and activating this tissue might ameliorate metabolic disease in humans. This proposal aims to understand how this cell type is naturally regulated in order to identify new ways to therapeutically activate it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Innate immunity is encoded in germline, yet on population level it is sufficient to recognize any pathogen even in absence of adaptive immunity. Exactly how new recognition specificities arise in innate immune receptors remain unknown. This project will address this fundamental gap and develop experimental and computational approaches to understand the evolution of innate immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Virus-host interaction studies in the context of chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) have the potential to reveal novel targets for curative strategies. This application will focus on the impact of HBV genotypes and pre-core mutants on chronic HBV infection, sensitivity to antivirals, and hepatocyte responses using physiologically-relevant in vitro and in vivo models, robust multi-omics methods, and innovative genetic tools. Further evaluation of host factors and cellular pathways may be exploited for developing novel antiviral strategies towards a functional HBV cure.
