IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This two-phase “health equity acceleration” U01 application is submitted to participate in the FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award for “Racial & Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) (U01)” focused on advancing “minority health and health equity focused research, outreach, and communications as well as support training and mentoring of diverse HBCU advanced students, fellows, and researchers.” Two pilot projects/programs submitted in this application will be developed under Phase 1, and subsequently implemented under Phase 2: a) A Pilot curriculum on “Regulatory Issues and Health Equity” and potential FDA OMHHE rotations for advanced students and faculty in HBCUs in Pharmacy (XULA College of Pharmacy) and Nursing (Helene Fuld School of Nursing CSU); and b) A Pilot research project which will move the discussion beyond barrier identification to develop strategies to address barriers to clinical trial diversity, in order to increase trustworthiness, enhance transparency in sponsors and researchers, and bolster willingness to participate for African Americans, thereby strengthening equity in participation of underrepresented minority racial and ethnic groups in clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gases present in flatus are an untapped source for valuable information about gut microbial metabolism. Here, we propose to develop a Smart Underwear device to directly measure the malodorous signaling molecule hydrogen sulfide from human flatus. This research could enable rational modulation of gut microbial hydrogen sulfide production through precision nutrition strategies.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Three sentences   With a collaborative approach grounded in Indigenous core cultural values, the Indigenous Innovators Collaborative (IIC) team will engage in community-based participatory research study to address the FDA priorities as outlined in FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award: Racial and Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) funding opportunity. The IIC seeks to engage American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) communities, stakeholders, researchers in an exploration of clinical trials and promote cultural knowledge in understanding clinical trials in Indian Country. One of the fundamental goals of this study is to aid in identifying perceptions of clinical trials and gene therapy within the Native American population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulation of the ovarian reserve in mammals has been mostly focused on germ cell development; however, other ovarian elements, such as extracellular matrix, are poorly understood. Loss of homeostasis of the extracellular matrices during adulthood is associated with fibrosis, inflammation, and premature ovarian aging. This project has an overall goal of understanding the mechanisms by which the extracellular matrices regulate the establishment of the ovarian reserve during development and how their maintenance can protect the ovary from aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the 21st century, the emergence of novel influenza viruses, the emergence and re-emergence of numerous arboviruses, and the devastating COVID-19 pandemic have illustrated the requirement for strategies that allow for the rapid screening and deployment of vaccines. We have developed a “designer nanoparticle” platform, or nanophages, that can be rapidly and rigorously modified to screen and evaluate potential vaccine candidates that simultaneously display multiple antigenic biomolecules. We propose to develop second generation tools and technologies for rapid screening and formulation of vaccine candidates, herein for current and emerging SARS coronaviruses, but that can be applied to virtually any pathogenic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The University of Utah Program to Provide Pain Research Knowledge (UP3RK) mission is to impart the  science knowledge, skills, and core competencies needed by post-graduate, interdisciplinary Scholars  to address the nation’s scientific needs in clinical pain research. UP3RK trains Scholars through mentorship  and concentrated training in: 1) our four focus areas (nonpharmacological pain treatments; effective  interventions for pain and co-morbidities, particularly substance use disorders; implementation science;  research within vulnerable, diverse, and underserved populations), 2) career development and programmatic  skills, and 3) interdisciplinary research skills. We train Scholars through dedicated UP3RK Mentors within an  innovative, multi-level mentor model develop independent clinical pain investigators and successful academic  research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1 infection of the cornea causes a vision-impairing chronic inflammatory condition called herpetic stromal keratitis (HSK). This project aims to investigate the molecular mechanisms for HSV-1-mediated macrophage metabolic reprogramming and how immunoregulatory cytokine IL-27 promotes antiviral and anti-inflammatory responses during HSK pathogenesis. Since current HSK treatment approaches are partially effective and cause severe side effects, the information gained from these studies will identify novel targets for developing new therapies to treat recurrent HSK.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on optimizing outcomes for patients with severe aortic stenosis undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The VA is the largest single provider of HIV care in the US and Veterans with HIV use significantly more healthcare services and have a 1.5-2x higher risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) compared to uninfected Veterans. Our goal is to improve BP treatment for Veterans with HIV to reduce ASCVD risk. Within a RCT, we hypothesize that our VA adapted nurse-led intervention will result in a clinically significant 6mmHg reduction in SBP over 12 months compared to those receiving enhanced education only. The study is innovative because of the use of stakeholder-engaged design process, multi-component nurse-led intervention, and VA Video Connect (VVC) to monitor CVD risk factors. The project meets VA strategic priorities including: 1) greater choice for Veterans; 2) improve timeliness of services; 3) focus more resources more efficiently (strengthen foundational services in VA). If shown to be effective, this intervention will have substantial impact among high-risk Veterans, potentially reducing ASCVD events by more than a quarter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Periodontitis is a chronic disease affecting millions of people globally and has complex underlying cellular and molecular drivers. Here, we aim to leverage a systems biology functional approach to dissect the cellular states driving periodontitis and the added burden of type 2 diabetes. We will characterize clinical samples by single- cell expression profiling, perform advanced computational analyses, and test regulators of cell state and signaling that may offer future novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). There are two major biologically distinct molecular subtypes of DLBCL, germinal center B-cell (GCB) and activated B- cell (ABC). Differentiation of these subtypes is crucial for the right treatment. The goal of this SBIR phase I proposal is to develop a Zip-MeltTM DLBCL Classifier Assay to differentiate these subtypes using Zip-MeltTM Multiplex Probe Technology in a single qPCR reaction. This high multiplex assay will be quicker, simple to perform, cost-effective, and will address the molecular diagnostic need, especially, for resource limited setting and will be ecofriendly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Right ventricular failure (RVF) is a prevalent cause of cardiovascular collapse and a major public health problem. Unlike left ventricular failure, RVF is not frequently investigated, which has contributed to the lack of effective therapies for RVF. Here we propose to use computational model predictions, based on state-of-the-art, multi- scale, comprehensive experimental datasets, to improve our understanding of RVF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Synthetic methods that rapidly generate complex organic molecules are critical for the development of selective biological probes and therapeutics. The overarching goal of this project is to explore transition metal redox catalysts for the reductive generation of carbene equivalents from readily available gem-dihalo starting materials. Using this approach, we will develop cycloaddition reactions that form odd-membered rings and vinylidene carbon–carbon coupling reactions that form chiral building blocks.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Smith-Lemli-Optiz syndrome (SLOS) is a genetic, developmental disorder arising from impaired sterol biosynthesis. We will test three already approved medications that can potentially improve the disrupted sterol function, using a mouse model of SLOS. Furthermore, we will perform a high throughput screening to identify which of the >2,500 molecules in a library of natural compounds can be important complementary drug candidates for treatment of SLOS in patients with various underlying gene mutations and health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - Shayna T. J. Bradford, Ph.D. Kidney disease is a global health concern that disproportionately impacts Americans of African descent. Current therapeutics to manage end-stage renal disease, the most severe form of kidney disease, include renal replacement therapies, which are costly or have significant wait times to obtain. Findings from this research will enhance our fundamental knowledge of novel cellular and molecular mediators involved in the acute kidney injury to chronic kidney disease transition, which could be targeted therapeutically to lessen the burden of kidney disease, especially in the vulnerable African American community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Poor recovery from orthopaedic injury, including severe pain and impaired bone healing, affects millions of Americans. Myeloid-lineage cells (peripheral macrophages and spinal cord microglia) are mobilized to resolve tissue damage, however, persistent activation of these cells can be detrimental by contributing to pain and delayed healing. This work aims to develop approaches to monitor dysfunctional myeloid-lineage cells and modulate specific targets for novel therapeutics that will improve post-injury recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Forty-percent of lymphoma patients relapse and face poor prognosis highlighting the inefficiency of current treatment options and the demand for targeted therapies. BAF-complex genes are one of the most mutated in cancer, with 20% of cases overall and 23% in lymphoma, yet, the mechanism by which BAF promotes malignant transformation is poorly understood. This proposal aims to decipher the biological role of BAF in the initiation, propagation and clonal evolution of lymphoma through effects on chromatin structure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental health problems in childhood are highly prevalent and impairing, placing an immense social and economic burden on society. Parent-child relationships in the early years of life play a critical role in promoting child mental health, with critical and coercive relationships increasing the risk of mental health problems across the lifespan. Our project includes the creation and systematic evaluation of an innovative technology-based therapy system that employs artificial intelligence to monitor and responsively administer dynamic (i.e., as needed) supports to families in real-world settings in order to promote positive family relationships and improve child mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many patients with chronic kidney disease develop heart failure, but the underlying causes remain unclear. Animal models of human disease suggest that the inflammasome may contribute to the development of heart failure in patients with chronic kidney disease. An epidemiologic study and a clinical trial will be conducted to improve our understanding of the role of inflammasome activity in the development of heart failure among adults with chronic kidney disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fe-S proteins play a central role in redox control and stress response, which is crucial for human health and the survival of bacterial pathogens during infection. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Millions of people worldwide receive bone-dwelling biomaterials each year to replace lost or damaged orthopaedic or dental tissues, but long-term implant survival rates are lower in patients who may have impaired wound healing. The aim of this study is to evaluate how physicochemical cues of biomaterials and injury caused by the surgical implantation procedure affect the activity of macrophages, key regulators of the host response to implanted materials. This will allow us to identify key signaling molecules in the local environment that can be targeted to control the inflammatory process and accelerate bone healing in these challenging cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormalities in the calvaria (upper part of the skull) are a major class of birth defects in humans. The proposed project will provide detailed information on the genetic regulation underpinning development of the suture mesenchyme cells, a crucial component of the calvaria. The knowledge gained from this project can help devise new methods for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of birth defects affecting the calvaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We have developed a method to psychophysically measure nociceptive sensitivity as a separate entity from pain sensitivity. Nociceptive sensitivity will be measured in patients with temporomandibular disorder, some of whom have nociplastic pain features. We will compare their nociceptive and pain sensitivity with data from pain-free controls, which may constitute a novel biomarker for use in other mechanistic studies and clinical trials and give insight into the mechanisms underlying pain hypersensitivity in patients with nociplastic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), characterized by persistent and painful exposed bone, is a devastating outcome that can occur in patients taking anti-resorptive drugs, and is most common amongst cancer patients taking high doses of these drugs, who harbor a ~5% risk of developing ONJ. Here we integrate cellular, molecular, and pharmacogenomic approaches to characterize the development of ONJ, and identify genetic risk factors for developing this condition.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative The utility of EHRs as a resource for Big Data analytics to generate meaningful insights for understanding disease and improving quality of care is currently limited due to non-random data missingness. In this project, we seek to reduce data missingness and disparity in missingness by leveraging breakthroughs in Large Language Models, and AI-enabled statistical approaches. We will then evaluate the impact of improved data completeness on our understanding of the drivers of periodontal health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: Despite recent advances using pharmacotherapy that greatly expanded treatment options for diabetic retinopathy, the cure for this blinding complication is not yet achieved. We have previously demonstrated that ASM is highly upregulated and ELOVL4 is downregulated in the diabetic retina resulting in the shift in the dial of ceramide rheostat from protective, pro-barrier very long chain ceramides (C≥26) to pro-inflammatory and pro- apoptotic short chain ceramides (C≤24). This proposal will test therapeutic potential of increasing ELOVL4 and very long chain ceramides to preserve blood retinal barrier in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the consequences of opioid use disorder (OUD) is a disruption of the daily patterns of sleep and stress. Medication-assisted treatments such as methadone and extended-release naltrexone are the front-line treatment for moderate to severe OUD, however there is little understanding of how persistent disruptions of the daily patterns of sleep and stress might impact patients on these medications. This study will use a dual- orexin receptor antagonist to better understand the role of the orexin system in daily patterns of sleep and stress, and whether improving sleep and reducing stress also improves OUD treatment outcomes for persons utilizing methadone or extended-release naltrexone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations play critical roles in the development of cancers and have significant implications for treatment strategies for cancer patients. However, the functional consequences of most of these mutations, particularly in the context of heterogeneous cancer cells, remain unknown. Our study will demonstrate how we utilize single- cell genomic technology and a computational framework to engineer, track, and study the impact of various mutations on the subclonal properties of cancer, including growth.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory over-responsivity (SOR), or increased reactivity to and avoidance of sensory stimuli, is associated with substantial anxiety, distress, and social difficulties and affects about two-thirds of children with common neurodevelopmental disorders including autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and nearly one-fifth of school-age children overall. The proposed research tests the hypothesis that neural mechanisms of sensory prediction are attenuated in children with SOR by assessing whether children with SOR (including children with and without ASD) exhibit diminished neural measures of sensory adaptation, suppression, and surprise relative to typically developing children without SOR. Drawing upon discoveries from sensory neuroscience, the proposed work aims to determine whether mechanisms of sensory prediction in specific brain areas are disrupted in SOR, thereby dramatically improving our understanding of the neural correlates of SOR and highlighting targets for future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative: Despite the high prevalence and urgency for early diagnosis, Intimate Partner Violence (IPV) remains profoundly underdiagnosed. Our objective is to develop a novel clinical decision support tool derived from historical radiological and clinical data that provides IPV risk and severity prediction in every patient encountered at the point of care. The automated IPV risk and severity predictions can then be integrated into clinical care to transform the care plan for victims and make the “invisible” visible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Dysfunction of pre-sympathetic neurons in the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus (PVN) is implicated as a potentially causal factor in major cardiovascular and metabolic diseases in which sympathetic nerve activity becomes chronically elevated. A large and rapidly expanding number of factors has been implicated in autonomic dysfunction, but there is presently little evidence from which to generate specific hypotheses for how these pathogenic factors disrupt the normal balance of synaptic excitation and inhibition in the PVN. Proposed studies will provide new and potentially important insight into the basic mechanisms that generate and dynamically defend the strength of synaptic inhibition by GABA, which normally ensures that PVN neurons are held nearly quiescent in the unstressed animal. Pathogenic mechanisms that activate PVN pre-sympathetic neurons must subvert or overwhelm these fundamental mechanisms of synaptic homeostasis in order for sympathetic nerve activity to become chronically elevated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and liver cancer are highest for Mexican-origin adults in the Southern Arizona U.S.-Mexico border region, highlighting a critical need to improve liver disease and cancer health literacy to reduce the disparities among this high-risk population. The proposed research will address this gap by implementing a culturally tailored, multi-channel educational communication campaign, including promotora-led outreach, to increase knowledge and public awareness of liver disease and liver cancer risk factors in Mexican-origin adults. This effort will have a significant public health impact by contributing evidence to the Community Preventive Services Task Force for engaging promotoras de salud (community health workers) in liver disease management to improve health outcomes, including liver cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The ultimate goal of the proposed work is to develop novel insulin-pramlintide co-formulations in combination with incretin hormone therapy to enable transformational new treatments for diabetes more closely mimicking endogenous hormone secretion in response to increases in blood glucose. The most challenging aspect of optimal glycemic control in the treatment of diabetes is limiting large increases in blood glucose after a meal. Our novel combination hormone therapy will yield unprecedented postprandial glycemic control and catalyze the development of a powerful tool for diabetes management affording thus far unrealized therapeutic impact.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Aortic aneurysms are a potentially deadly expansion of the main blood vessel carrying blood from the heart. Aortic aneurysms have no medical therapy and often have no symptoms. They have a very high mortality (85-90%) if they expand, go undetected, and rupture or dissect. These aneurysms are very prevalent in the male Veterans population (especially Veterans who smoke) with estimates running as high as 15%. The goal of this application is to understand the relationship between aortic aneurysms and gut bacteria, and to uncover the molecular underpinnings of how gut bacteria protect from development of aortic aneurysms. This understanding could form the basis of new therapies that prevent or treat aortic aneurysms so prevalent in the VA population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Improving primary prevention of opioid use while effectively treating pain is a pillar of the NIDA HEAL response to the opioid crisis that would benefit greatly from research producing actionable data. The CDC opioid prescribing guidelines (update late `22) define evidence-based practices to improve opioid related morbidity and mortality by decreasing opioid exposures and high-risk opioid use, but lack robust effectiveness data. This single system research project will support the development of EHR based clinical decision support tools to promote CDC guideline recommendations followed by an evaluation of patient centered outcomes by linking provider prescribing to existing Prescription Drug Monitoring Program, insurance claims and death data sets.

PHR: Narrative. The Consortium for the Study of Pancreatitis: Pittsburgh Clinical Center (PCC) is a clinical- translational program at the University of Pittsburgh and UPMC designed to conduct studies related to chronic pancreatitis, diabetes and pancreatic cancer. As a member of the Consortium for the Study of Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes and Pancreatic Cancer (CPDPC), the PCC will participate in collaborative studies planned by the consortium. The track record of accomplishments of the PCC in the CPDPC as well as leadership and contributions to other collaborative networks will ensure continued success and effectiveness of the CPDPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is an emerging, but poorly understood condition in children that significantly impacts quality of life with high healthcare costs. The objective of this application is to delineate the natural history of pediatric CP through careful prospective analysis of INSPPIRE-2 cohort, to define the impact of genetic modifiers on disease course and to determine the mechanisms involved in pancreatogenic diabetes mellitus. Our long-term goal is to develop diagnostic modalities, prognostic factors and better treatment approaches for pediatric chronic pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: 2024 NHSN Conference Administrative Supplement Project Narrative Hispanics constitute the largest racial/ethnic underrepresented group in the United States and are disproportionately impacted by substance use disorder, such as drug types, alcohol, tobacco, and more. There is a pressing need to study the biological, individual, familial, community, legal, and contextual factors that differentially affect substance use, its consequences, and the use of treatment services in Hispanic populations through interdisciplinary and translational approaches. The proposed annual NHSN conference will continue to serve as the premier venue for transdisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and interprofessional scientific discussions on strategies to minimize the impact of substance use disorder on health disparities in Hispanics and other underrepresented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity increases the risk of death from endometrial cancer and predisposes to high levels of insulin; however, it is unclear if these findings are directly linked. The growth of endometrial cancer cells is stimulated by insulin via the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathway. This proposal will target the PI3K pathway in human endometrial cancer using a combination of dietary and pharmacologic strategies that reduce insulin together with small molecule inhibitors of PI3K to prevent the growth of endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 60% of older adults have at least some persistent pain which is associated with impaired physical and emotional function and increased risk for morbidity and mortality. Older adults from underserved communities (e.g., low SES, racial and ethnic minorities, immigrants) are at the highest risk for negative pain outcomes, yet we lack nonpharmacological treatments within community health centers that serve them. Using the socioecological frameworks, Aaron’s stage model and Proctor’s implementation model, we aim to culturally adapt GetActive, an evidence-based mind-body activity program for chronic pain, to incorporate the values, facilitators, resources, and language, for disadvantaged older adults with chronic pain and routine implementation in the community based clinical settings that serve them.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framedwithin our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The human genome has been sequenced, and yet so much is unknown about what it does; what we do know is scattered across multiple, heterogeneous data sources that are difficult to integrate. The Phenomics-First Resource (PFR) coordinates the efforts of a large community of researchers and clinicians to help interpret the relationship between the differences (called variants) in a patient’s genome and their physical characteristics (phenotypes). The PFR will gather and unify the data from numerous sources to advance genomic interpretation in clinical settings, and will empower both researchers and clinicians to overcome long-standing barriers to discovery and patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is an inflammatory disease that has substantial impacts on patient quality of life and health care resource utilization. This proposal focuses on enhancing the PI’s contributions in patient-oriented research focused on chronic rhinosinusitis pathogenesis, developing the PI’s mentorship skills and experience, and guiding the next generation of translational researchers in rhinology and paranasal sinus disease. Longitudinal multi-omic analysis of patient-derived samples will be used to identify novel mechanisms of disease and new targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiac fibrosis is a grim consequence for almost all myocardial injuries, currently with no cure in sight. To date, studies failed to identify therapeutic targets mainly due to the heterogeneity in fibroblast biology between disease types and even between various anatomical regions in the heart. The proposed study will utilize newly developed in vivo genetic tools to rigorously interrogate all of the extracellular matrix-producing fibroblasts within the heart in order to find common and disease-specific mechanisms underlying cardiac fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Capsular polysaccharide (capsule) is the outermost barrier that protects bacteria from external threats and is required for colonization of the human gastrointestinal tract. The project areas proposed here focus on understanding how a predominant genera of gut bacteria regulates capsule abundance and attaches it to the bacterial cell surface. The results of the proposed projects have the potential to shed light on this fundamental process, which could be harnessed to restrict bacterial fitness in targeted niches.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Molecular Transducers of Physical Activity Consortium (MoTrPAC) is collecting a large and complex multiomic dataset to understand how tens of thousands of molecules change in response to exercise. This work ensures that the results of the Consortium are robust, reliable, valid, and available and usable by the entire scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. New small molecule probes are critical to illuminating biology in ways that can be harnessed for the treatment of human disease. Our group is developing natural product-inspired chemical biology platforms that integrate chemical synthesis with sophisticated biological investigations to discover new phenomena relevant to priority disease areas (e.g., antibiotic-tolerant biofilm infections, cancer, opioid addiction). During this award, we will (1) expand our tryptoline ring distortion platform to generate new complex and diverse compounds, and perform an array of biological studies to explore their re-engineered activities, and (2) develop robust strategies to expand the spectrum of activity for halogenated phenazine biofilm-eradicating agents to address the underlying cause of chronic and recurring bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After a sexual assault, peers often express confusion about how to best support survivors and may encourage drinking to cope, which can exacerbate the wide range of physical and mental health problems survivors experience, contributing to persistent distress, long-term healthcare costs, and loss of productivity. The current project involves the design and feasibility testing of a novel web-based intervention to increase effective peer support of survivors by focusing on behaviors incompatible with heavy drinking, which will in turn reduce alcohol use and related consequences within high-risk social networks of sororities. If feasibility and preliminary intervention effects are supported, this intervention could be widely disseminated and facilitate change in drinking norms among social networks of young adults, as well as mitigate distress after sexual assaults.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative We will evaluate the effects of the Medicaid postpartum coverage extension in Louisiana and Mississippi, and postpartum depression screening mandate in Louisiana, compared to Arkansas. The intended outcome will be to evaluate the effectiveness and contextual factors of implementation strategies that aim to improve maternal postpartum health and health equity. This study will generate urgently needed data on practical, robust, and sustainable population-targeted strategies to improve maternal health outcomes, reduce maternal health risks, and eliminate maternal health disparities in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anterior eye segment diseases such as cataract, refractive error, and corneal opacity are leading causes of global blindness, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. In order to improve access to anterior eye disease screenings in rural settings, our project aims to develop and validate a smartphone-based, community health worker-led platform to screen patients for common anterior eye diseases. We will compare performance of ophthalmologists’ remote grading of smartphone screening data to the gold standard of in-person eye camp exams; we will also compare performance of a machine learning algorithm trained using smartphone screening data and images to the gold standard of in-person eye exams.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE WHO estimated that 20% of the world’s population suffer from respiratory allergies and derived diseases such as allergic rhinitis and asthma. However, there is still no clear answer to the question: “why do only some people develop allergy?”, underscoring the need to revisit our understanding of immune mechanisms of allergy. Using novel genomics unbiased tools, we discovered a new type of T cells, we called THIFNR cells, that may play an important role in preventing pathogenic inflammation in allergy and asthma. This grant aims to first complete the characterization those THIFNR cells. First, we will use animal models of respiratory allergy to understand how THIFNR cells function in vivo. Second, we will use single-cell genomics tools to dissect the molecular mechanisms responsible for the development and persistence of THIFNR cells. If successful, our work will provide novel mechanistic insights that may lead to the development of better therapeutic options for patients with allergic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Puberty is a period marked by the emergence of enhanced cognitive functioning, but also an increased incidence of psychopathology. Some research has suggested that the drastic changes in sex hormones that occurs during the pubertal transition, namely dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), testosterone, and estradiol exert sex and region-specific effects on neural structure that affects cognitive and affective development, but research to date has been largely restricted to animals, with only a handful of human neuroimaging studies in this area. The proposed work will train a promising physician-scientist to use an advanced dynamic functional brain mapping method to identify the impact of developmental changes in DHEA, testosterone, and estradiol on brain and higher-order cognitive function in typically-developing children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. However, all past research projects following the disease’s behavior over time have been marred by confounders such as administration of course-altering treatment or by using models which only partially reflect the glaucoma process. We will overcome these shortfalls by investigating glaucoma in non-human primates who naturally develop the disease by applying advanced ocular imaging methods to determine changes in the eye that will be directly related to the human eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The gut immune system must maintain tolerance n the steady-state while retaining the ability to rapidly induce immunity to pathogens during infection. We have uncovered an intrinsic capacity of the gut to switch from tolerance to immunity and propose this is a physiologic response to infection and when inappropriately activated potentially contributes to intestinal inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Venezuelan equine encephalitic virus (VEEV) infects humans and can cause inflammation, acute degenerative neuronal changes, behavioral changes, memory loss and seizures, with severe cases resulting in death, but there are no therapeutics available to treat this disease. The capsid protein of VEEV is able to suppress antiviral responses, thereby making it an attractive therapeutic target. We aim to develop more potent and safe second generation inhibitors that will interfere with VEEV capsid-host protein interactions preventing VEEV induced diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lynch syndrome (LS) affects over a million of people in the United States and is one of the leading causes of hereditary cancers (e.g., colorectal and endometrial cancer), which can be prevented or treated with active screening and early diagnosis. Cascade testing for at-risk relatives of patients with LS is cost-effective, but underutilized because there are many barriers to testing. Increasing pre-test genetic counseling in this population will have substantial public health impact by promoting awareness and identification of LS and subsequently help reduce cancer morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Epigenetic dysregulation is frequently observed in the disease pathology of pediatric cancers, including neuroblastoma (NB), the most common extracranial solid tumor in pediatric patients. We’ve discovered that adoption of a mesenchymal lineage is associated with loss of GD2 expression, resulting in resistance to anti- GD2 therapy. This proposal outlines the targeting of PRC1.1 via inhibition of USP7 as a therapeutic intervention to directly target neuroblastomas and restore the response to anti-GD2 therapy. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial proportion of the growing elderly population have Alzheimer's disease or related dementias (ADRD), and their progressive daily challenges to meeting essential needs (e.g., managing finances, medication, transportation) are exacerbated when they live alone and thus lack cohabitants who can compensate for the cognitive impairment, leading to emergent problems including untreated medical conditions, self-neglect, malnutrition, falls, and fires. To help address this large and growing problem, the proposed research will elucidate key barriers and facilitators to accessing and using long-term services and supports (LTSS) for older adults with ADRD, especially those who live alone and racial/ethnic minorities. The results of this study will support policies to increase access, affordability, acceptance, and use of essential LTSS for these vulnerable populations. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Families are a key social determinant of the health and well-being of older adults, potentially creating or expanding inequities in how well care needs are met. Disadvantage may be especially heightened among older adults with ADRD who may be more likely to live in complex families. This project seeks to enhance measurement of family and kinship ties and caregiving norms and behaviors regarding care for older adults in order to better understand under what circumstances complex family and kinship ties become activated and how this process differs for individuals living with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall  Defining bone marrow cell identities and states using quantitative spatial maps of RNA, protein, and N- glycans, our proposed Bone Marrow Tissue Mapping Center will dissect the cellular composition and spatial structure of bone marrow niches to understand which cells and interactions are critical to each branch of hematopoietic maturation. The multi-arm sample collection strategy, leveraging of clinically-validated pre- analytical pipelines, assay technologies (Nanostring DSP, Multiplexed Ion Beam Imaging, and MALDI-MSI), computational tools (pixel-based analyses, cell-based analyses, neighborhood analyses), and biological principles are broadly applicable to and complement other HuBMAP projects. Interrogating the interdependence between bone marrow tissue structure and hematopoiesis is informative not just in blood cell maturation, but for understanding metabolism, aging, and development of cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE This training program is specifically designed to train a new cadre of researchers and leaders to address major but as yet under-studied public health problems engendered by conditions prevalent in urban and rural informal human settlements (slums) of low and middle-income countries (LMIC). This training is relevant also to developed countries as informal settlements in the form of homeless encampments expand. Selected candidates will undergo field training on site in LMICs to develop new global health research skills framed within our project research theme of health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Metalloenzymes are ubiquitous throughout biology, comprising approximately half of all known enzymes, yet their biogenesis and active site maturation is often unclear due to complicated mechanisms of assembly. Metallocofactor assembly in Photosystem II provides a convenient model system for structural and biochemical studies due to its light dependence and recent advances in controlling its step-wise assembly. Because metalloenzymes are implicated in a variety of human diseases, gaining a fundamental understanding of their biogenesis and metallocofactor assembly may lead to improved therapeutics and synthetic metalloenzyme design principles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In many types of cancer, cancer cells from the primary tumor can intravasate into the peripheral circulation as circulating tumor cells (CTCs). Cancer cells respond to the forces in blood flow in ways that are not yet fully understood. This project will develop new technology to facilitate new understanding of the response of cancer cells to fluid flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative To characterize the intestinal microbiota populating different sites of the gastrointestinal tract, we propose to develop an ingestible device termed “micro-pill”. The 3D-printed micro-pill will be fitted with pH and oxygen sensors such that it can sample autonomously from pre-determined intestinal sites after ingestion. Given the importance of the intestinal microflora to health and disease, the ability to non-invasively sample intestinal microbial populations throughout the GI tract will facilitate the development of precision nutritional prescriptions aimed at optimizing long-term health outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE: Maintenance of life-long skeletal integrity requires bone to be continuously remodeled by osteoclasts that erode old bone and osteoblasts that deposit new bone, and many human bone diseases are caused by excessive osteoclasts eroding to much bone, weakening the skeleton (e.g., osteoporosis, fibrous dysplasia). We will resolve how a novel regulator controls osteoclast formation/function and characterize how disrupted osteoclast-osteoblast signaling promotes the progression of an osteoclast-based bone disease. Our project will fill fundamental gaps in the understanding of how osteoclasts form and remodel bone and identify novel therapeutic strategies for the targeted treatment of human bone disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a common but poorly understood condition, particularly in non-Whites, that is non-malignant but often harbors mutations in “driver” genes. This Study will use state-of-the-art single cell transcriptomics, epigenomics, exome-sequencing and a bioluminescent transplant model to catalogue somatic mutations across a diverse cohort of patients and dissect consequences of somatic mutations to identify new therapeutic opportunities. These insights are expected to pave the way to the development of precision medicine for endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR LAY AUDIENCE Ovarian cancer is responsible for more than 150,000 deaths per year and so it remains a high priority to develop effective prevention approaches and to identify new disease specific therapies to reduce disease mortality. The research we propose here has two components: (1) To characterize the component of genetic and epigenomic interactions in ovarian cancer development; (2) to establish the functional relevance of genetic findings for clinical translation. This is a highly integrated multi-disciplinary research program – but these approaches to novel discovery and functional understanding are desperately needed to advance our basic knowledge of this disease to develop clinical interventions that save lives.

ORG_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRI & TECH ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this research is to improve our understanding of the biopsychosocial factors that impact cognitive outcomes among middle-aged and older Black adults. This study, known as the Black American United Memory and Aging Project (BA-UMAP), will establish and remotely assess a cohort of 600 middle-aged and older Black adults in order to identify the sociocultural, behavioral, environmental, and biological factors influencing cognitive functioning and cognitive decline, as measured by established and novel online and mobile cognitive assessments, and remotely collected non-invasive biomarkers. It is hoped that this work will inform risk reduction strategies, given Black adults are disproportionately affected by Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.
PI_NAMEs: BROWN-HUGHES, TRAVONIA S (contact);GRAHAM, STEWART F;THORPE, ROLAND J.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Nytricx is developing a new class of Nitric Oxide (NO)-releasing intravascular medical catheters to combat infection and thrombosis associated with indwelling vascular catheters. Nytricx NO-releasing technology represents a disruptive innovation that will result in saving patients’ lives and cutting medical costs, especially those related to hospital acquired blood steam infections and thrombosis, associated with intravascular catheters.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative As one of four Centers of Excellence (COEs) of FDA's Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, JIFSAN conducts various research and outreach activities in food safety and applied nutrition to help ensure that regulatory decisions have a sound science footing and that the best methods and tools are available to advance food and public health. The JIFSAN's programs support the Food Safety Modernization Act that emphasizes the concept of preventing food safety-related problems before they occur and enhance FDA's efforts to partner with other nations to improve U.S. and worldwide health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Many patients that are suffering with Lyme disease experience chronic symptoms despite having undergone extensive antibiotic therapy and appear to be free of infection. The lead investigator of this proposal discovered that 1) the disease-causing agent sheds a component of its' cell-wall into its environment; 2) this molecule can be detected in patients' months after antibiotics; and 3) the cell-wall, alone, is capable of causing disease pathology. In this project we will determine what about the cell-wall is making us sick and how it is doing so, with the hope that we will be able to leverage this information to treat Lyme disease patients, even when antibiotics fail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unhealthy drinking can exacerbate two highly prevalent HIV-related comorbidities/co-occurring conditions, chronic pain and physical inactivity, which in turn, can intensify alcohol use and affect physical and mental function in people living with HIV (PLWH). In this Program Project, we will conduct state-of-the-art e-health clinical trials research on scalable approaches to address the HIV-associated conditions chronic pain and physical inactivity in PLWH with unhealthy alcohol use. We will also support secondary analyses of the existing Boston ARCH cohort of PLWH with unhealthy drinking, and provide support and mentoring to trainees and investigators accessing the cohort data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We recently found that a naturally occurring inherited change of one amino acid in an extracellular matrix protein called the lysyl oxidase propeptide (LOX-PP) results in worse oral cancer outcomes in people. Here we propose to investigate why the variant LOX-PP, unlike the more common LOX-PP, fails to bind to and regulate how a cell surface protein known as FGFR1 results in an immune cells including macrophages to control other immune cells and mesenchymal cells to promote cancer. Understanding molecular interactions between LOX- PP and FGFR1, and how this interaction controls how tumor cells, immune cells, and bystander cells communicate will help us to come up with new strategies to help control oral cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Tooth delay and loss are common problems, and little is known in enamel regeneration from human cell source. The proposed research aims to develop a well-defined 3D material microenvironment for regulating self-renewal and differentiation of human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs), producing scaffold-grown tooth germ in vitro, and generating tooth tissue from scaffold-grown tooth germ in a clinically-relevant orthortopic mouse model. Successful completion of the proposed research will make a profound impact on stem-cell biology and technology and on human tooth tissue regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative As the prevalence of children being born to opioid-dependent mothers has increased, there is a pressing need to understand the mechanisms whereby prenatal opioid exposure increases the susceptibility for problematic substance use, particularly alcohol given its widespread accessibility and the significant morbidity and mortality associated with alcohol use disorder. Using a mouse model of prenatal exposure to methadone, a commonly used opioid in pregnant women, we found that prenatal methadone exposure increases alcohol drinking exclusively in male offspring, consistent with literature showing males are more sensitive to prenatal opioid exposure. Here we use a multidisciplinary approach, that extends from the synaptic proteome to the behavioral level, to explore the interaction of prenatal methadone exposure and alcohol on specific corticostriatal synapses that mediate excessive alcohol drinking behaviors in order to determine the mechanisms whereby prenatal methadone exposure produces enhanced alcohol drinking in males.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Men are missing from mental health care and family-focused research; their inclusion through scalable, relevant treatment can improve the burden of mental health problems especially in low-resource settings where treatment gaps are largest. The proposed K23 supports the candidate’s transition to a research career designing and testing scalable interventions for caregiver mental health to improve child mental health in low- resource settings that consider social determinants of health focused on men and father. The resulting knowledge can inform public health policy and intervention strategies to reduce the global burden of mental disorders for men, and subsequently children and family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria belonging to the Borrelia genus include Borrelia burgdorferi which is an infectious tick-borne spirochete that causes nearly 300,000 cases of Lyme disease in the United States annually. Borrelia are also known to cause other serious vector-borne human illnesses including relapsing fever and Borrelia miyamotoi disease. In this project is we will use structural, biochemical, and microbiological approaches to study a group of evolutionarily-related, multi-functional, borrelial lipoproteins with the goal of understanding their role in promoting bacterial survival and persistence in immunocompetent hosts.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Grasping is impaired in a number of individuals with cervical spinal cord injury. This proposal aims to examine the contribution of physiological pathways involved in grasping behaviors, and to maximize the recovery of grasping by using tailored non-invasive stimulation protocols with motor training. Novel methods will be used to strengthen transmission in residual corticospinal and reticulospinal connections and to enhance voluntary control of hand muscles. Because deficits in hand control are a major problem after stroke, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, multiple sclerosis, and other motor disorders, our work may also be relevant for individuals with other lesions of the CNS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pelvic pain (CPP) is a debilitating condition that negatively impacts the social and sexual quality of life in up to 20% of American women. Botulinum neurotoxin (BoNT) has received growing interest in managing CPP, but it can cause dose-dependent side- effects and is expensive. This FastTrack SBIR project aims to develop a commercializable, personalized, precision BoNT injection medical device, i.e., the PelviMap system, implementing validated vaginal HD-sEMG technology to optimize the treatment outcomes in CPP management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall The underserved vulnerable African American, Asian-Pacific American and Hispanic American populations in the PA-NJ-NYC region experience significant cancer-related health disparities across the cancer continuum, from a higher prevalence of cancer risk factors to delayed screening and diagnoses, experiencing more advanced disease, and poorer outcomes. SPEECH has made significant strides toward transforming cancer health disparities research and education; research infrastructure and platforms that enabled investigators to advance cancer health equity in these underrepresented and underserved populations. In the next five years, our Partnership aims to advance cancer health disparities research, training/workforce development, and community-informed interventions by breaking structural, systemic barriers and promoting inclusive excellence across disciplines among basic, clinical and population science researchers, trainees and diverse underserved communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Humans can show tremendous flexibility in every day life, rapidly recognizing and responding to contextual cues with appropriate behavioral changes, even in unfamiliar situations where the appropriate behaviors could not have been learned through direct experience. Here we examine the neural basis of this flexibility, with a particular focus on how arousal signals elicited by perceived context changes might coordinate neural representations in the brain to facilitate appropriate behaviors in changing and unfamiliar situations. This work will provide an understanding of how the brain generates flexible behavior, and why it does so differently in different individuals, thereby serving as a foothold for future work seeking to understand what goes wrong in conditions characterized by failure to cope with uncertain and changing environments.

PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health and specifically to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge about the behavior of living systems and apply that knowledge to enhance health and reduce the burden of disease. This work will pave the way for new treatments that enhance antibiotic cure of H. pylori.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a genetic disease that affects millions of people worldwide, causing frequent pain episodes, stroke, organ damage and a median life expectancy in the mid-forties. We propose to determine the detrimental and potentially beneficial effects of unintended large gene modifications due to Cas9-cutting, and develop ways to reduce large deletions, with the goal of increasing the efficacy and safety of genome editing based treatment of SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Massachusetts, Boston (UMass Boston) and Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC) Partnership is committed to further developing a shared rigorous and collaborative transdisciplinary cancer and disparities-related research program that is primed for “Bridging the Divides: Innovations to Address Gaps in Cancer Disparities Research, Education, Outreach and Infrastructure.” Sophisticated research projects are proposed across several areas of basic biomedical and population sciences that will employ evidence and methods to converge upon and impact cancer and cancer health disparities at multiple levels of analysis. These projects, together with state-of-the-art Outreach and Research Education Cores and creative Research Design and Analysis Core and Genomics Cores, will serve to build research capacity and infrastructure at UMass Boston, expand the cancer disparities platform and community outreach programs at DF/HCC; and make, at an elevated level, significant advances to the science of cancer control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We plan to define how the sequences of specialized nucleic acid molecules (so-called ribonucleic acid or RNA) in the cells of blood vessels of the lungs are dynamically altered to control a mysterious disease called pulmonary hypertension (PH). If successful, the results of this work will advance our understanding of how PH develops and will provide a substantial basis to generate more effective tests to detect and treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enterovirus D68 (EV-D68) has been implicated in severe respiratory illness and acute flaccid myelitis (AFM), a polio-like illness causing paralysis in previously healthy children. There are no specific treatments for AFM, most children are left with residual deficits, and it is currently unknown how EV-D68 targets the central nervous system. The goal of this proposal is to identify how EV-D68 mediates cellular damage in the human spinal cord by using an innovative human spinal cord organoid model.

PHR: Project Narrative Aortopathy including aneurysms, dissection, and rupture are life-threatening diseases that have no validated medications. The only therapeutic option is watchful waiting prior to major surgical intervention. This project will provide novel mechanistic insight into these diseases that will enable more focused efforts in understanding the disease pathogenesis and developing medical treatment.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is a serious and often fatal infectious disease, posing an enormous global health challenge with over 250 million cases per year and more than 600,000 deaths in year 2020. Our goal is to develop small chemical molecules that trick malaria parasites into producing multiple versions of an inhibitor of one of their own essential enzyme complexes, consequently overcoming resistance. Successful completion of the proposed studies will provide novel anti- malarial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cancer is a leading cause of mortality among people with HIV (PWH) in the US, data to inform tailored strategies to reduce preventable cancer-related deaths using recommended screening modalities are lacking. Through this proposal, we aim to address this gap in scientific knowledge, leveraging the All of Us data resource a national cohort including survey and a novel electronic health record-based linkage of multiple health systems throughout the US to gain real world insights into (1) patterns and trends in cancer screening uptake, follow-up, and outcomes among PWH compared to those without HIV and (2) social inequities (social determinants of health) in screening behaviors among PWH to identify actionable targets for intervention. Our results will elucidate mechanisms that could lead to the development of future interventions to: 1) improve coverage of cancer screening among PWH, 2) address barriers to cancer screening access and follow-up among PWH, and 3) optimize screening guidelines for PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Minoritized children are at risk for severe early childhood caries, which are often treated with dental surgery under general anesthesia (DGA). DGA does not address underlying oral health behaviors that can prevent future disease recurrence, and no research to date has developed a multi-behavioral parenting intervention for this population. The current study aims to develop and test the initial efficacy of PROTECT (Preventing Recurrent Operations Targeting Early Childhood Caries Treatment), a 6-month, community health worker-delivered, behavioral parenting intervention for a minoritized, preschool-aged, pediatric dental surgical population targeting tooth brushing frequency and consumption of added sugars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research seeks to promote best practices in interactions among dental healthcare professionals, parents/caregivers, and young children ages 0 through 5, and so has broad public health relevance for all children in this age group. Building upon research on usual care in dental practices to understand skills currently being used with children, the present research will develop and test mechanisms of change involved in a workshop for dental providers on evidence-informed interactional skills. Currently, evidence-based, specialized training for dental providers to achieve a positive, acceptable, and comfortable dental experience for young children is unavailable; providers having such skills may significantly benefit the quality of care families of young children receive in oral healthcare settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In metazoans, gene expression is controlled in a tissue- and cell-type specific manner through regulatory sequence elements in the genome. Elements that suppress gene expression, termed transcriptional silencers, are not well understood. The goals of this project, using Drosophila embryonic mesoderm as a model system, are to quantify the activities of large sets of tissue-/cell-type specific silencers, elucidate their chromatin signatures, and reveal the DNA sequence motifs, repressive proteins and chromosomal interactions through which silencers exert their regulatory effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure of pregnant women to environmental pollution and toxicants significantly increase risks to mother’s health after birth. Using already collected samples, our study will use innovative technologies and will identify the drivers of immune dysfunction and potential modifiable factors. We will determine how these immune findings are associated with pollution exposure and outcomes of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I propose a biologically motivated, mathematical modeling approach to understand how neuroimaging and other biomarkers can be used to better understand Alzheimer’s disease biology. I plan to fit mechanistic models to data from 3 cohorts across the age span of Alzheimer’s disease onset: Longitudinal Early Onset Alzheimer’s Disease Study (LEADS) (ages 40-64), Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) cohort (ages 55-90), and The 90+ Study (ages 90+). The long-term objective of this research is to improve our understanding of the age-specific pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s disease, determining the precise relationship between tau and cognition, with the ultimate goal of guiding therapeutic development and trials for Alzheimer’s treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Desmosomes are critically important in resisting mechanical stress, impacting tissue morphogenesis and human health, but much is unknown about its role in the mechanics and mechanotransduction at the epithelial cell-cell junction. Through this program, we will examine the desmosome’s ability to maintain the mechanical integrity of the junction and determine its potential to transduce mechanical cues at the junction in coordination with molecules at the adherens junctions and the actin network. The understanding will aid in developing treatments for disorders resulting from interference with this adhesive junction.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The indirect impacts of disasters—morbidity and mortality due to compromised conditions such as food security and clean water—are typically not included in estimates of disaster deaths. Child health is particularly sensitive to such compromised conditions and understanding the indirect burden of disasters on child health is central for designing mitigation and adaptation strategies. This project aims to estimate the indirect child mortality burden from floods and severe storms around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The well-established Meharry Medical College/Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center/Tennessee State University Cancer Partnership (MVTCP) triad provides an exceptional environment to identify and address health care inequities in cancer seen in underrepresented minorities. The proposed research projects, cores, and shared resource cores will grow research and propose evidence-based solutions address to these inequities. Further, the development of expanded research infrastructure at MMC and TSU, enhancement of minority education programs, and improvement to the effectiveness of cancer-related activities will address health care disparities in the greater Nashville geographical region, with the ultimate goal of contributing to reducing health disparities among cancer patients in minority and underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Approximately 15-25 million people worldwide are infected with HTLV-1 with a small percentage developing adult  T-cell leukemia. The cancer is aggressive and there is currently no effective treatment. This project focuses on  a novel viral gene encoded by the antisense strand of the HTLV-1 genome, termed hbz, and the proposed studies will provide a significant advance in our basic knowledge of the role of hbz in transformation and disease  and will have significant implications for therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Exposure to interpersonal violence (IPV) is associated with long-term negative mental health consequences, including an increased risk for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), especially in women. Our previous studies examining the impact and timing of IPV experienced during specific developmental windows revealed increased psychophysiological reactivity and a unique EV protein signature belonging to a 17q21 gene cluster and associated with skin keratinocytes, specific to Merkel cells and only found when IPV was experienced between 14-18 yrs. Our overarching hypothesis to be examined here is that tactile-based IPV trauma exposure during late adolescence increases the sensitivity of threat circuitry, and we propose a cross-species translational study to examine molecular and physiological analyses of the RDoC Acute Threat construct.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes Kaposi’s Sarcoma and B cell lymphomas. KSHV expresses 12 miRNA genes and a number of viral long noncoding RNAs, including anti-sense and circular RNAs.  Using ribonomcs techniques we demonstrated that KSHV infection leads to de-regulation of cellular lncRNAs in  a miRNA-dependent and -independent fashion. The main focus of this project is to increase our understanding  of how viral short and long noncoding RNAs contribute to viral disease, and specifically to tumor formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The transforming human gammaherpesviruses EBV and KSHV establish stable latent infections in B cells,  providing a lifelong reservoir of virus that can contribute to the development of malignant disease. Thus, defining  the mechanisms that govern long-term latency and tumorigenesis is critical for designing rational strategies to  prevent disease. In work here, we will use a mouse model of gammaherpesvirus infection and tumorigenesis to  defined the mechanisms by which viral noncoding RNAs shape critical B cell signaling pathways to promote virus  dissemination, latency and tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal we will carry out the first unbiased screens and genetic interaction mapping of all lncRNAs and their associated protein partners in human and murine macrophage cells. We will generate genetic mouse models of candidate genes to show their critical role in contributing to sepsis in vivo. Our aim is to identify those functionally conserved lncRNAs involved in the regulation of critical biological processes in macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic pain and opioid use disorder are, respectively, leading causes of disability and accidental death in the US; there is a public health imperative to identify modifiable risk factors so that these inter-related problems can be better understood and prevented. Sleep disturbance is a common and highly treatable risk factor for both chronic pain and OUD and we hypothesize that sleep disturbance increases risk for pain and OUD by dysregulating brain mu-opioid receptor (MOR) signaling. To answer this question, we will conduct a randomized controlled experiment in healthy individuals, testing the effects of two common sleep disruption patterns experience by the majority of individuals with chronic pain and OUD (insomnia pattern and sleep apnea pattern) on: 1) brain imaging measures of MOR signaling, and 2) the analgesic response and abuse liability profile of hydromorphone, a prototypical opiate drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria often stick to the surfaces of implants, causing infections that can lead to implant removal or replacement. Additionally, biomaterial implantation may result in significant scarring that decreases the effectiveness of a number of biologically important devices, including cochlear implants. To improve ultimate performance and safety, we are developing a coating for implants using light that prevents bacteria from adhering and growing while also decreasing scarring, thereby, improving the overall benefit and safety of implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both HIV and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) establish life-long infections that, despite the development of antiretroviral therapy and antibiotics, cause millions of deaths every year, emphasizing the need to develop a cure. This proposal aims to define the methods by which HIV and Mtb evade immune-mediated clearance by characterizing their common target cell, the macrophage, and how this cell acts to shield these pathogens from immune responses. Insight into these mechanisms will help identify macrophage-specific pathways that can be exploited to make these infected cells more susceptible to immune-mediated clearance, potentiating the development of cure-based strategies for HIV and Mtb infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goals of this project are to 1) examine preferences for diabetes care among adult Samoans recently diagnosed with diabetes using a discrete choice experiment, 2) prospectively estimate the associations between diabetes care and glycemic outcomes among adult Samoans, and 3) longitudinally assess diabetes care decision-making and coping strategies. The project will use the tools and methodologies of health economics, longitudinal quantitative and qualitative approaches, and implementation science to comprehensively assess diabetes care experiences and provide formative data necessary to build evidence- based, patient centered and sustainable diabetes interventions and treatment programs

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal aims to determine the potential of mesenchymal stem cells from bone marrow, adipose tissue, and corneal limbus to differentiate in vitro into functionally active corneal endothelial cells, and the feasibility and efficacy of differentiated cell transplantation into the anterior chamber in vivo to restore corneal endothelial function. I propose a training plan that will allow me to achieve this goal through different biochemical and cellular techniques, and through in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo models. If the in vivo phase demonstrates that differentiated cell transplantation is safe and effective, corroborating in vitro data, the treatment will be deemed worthy of further clinical investigation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatologists provide life-supporting care to babies born with difficult health conditions. In this proposal we will build an electronic tool to improve the quality of care and patient safety for these very fragile patients. Improved care is realized by providing a variety of clinical decision support tools to clinicians including: a continuous searchable stream of relevant data, smart thresholds and alarms, protocol support, shift-change hand-off support, and improved information visualization utilities that highlight critical changes in patient condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE This study aims to evaluate child welfare policy and local factors to improve the wellbeing of pregnant people with substance use disorder and their infants. The study will include an evaluation of state-level Plan of Safe Care (POSC) policy, a quantitative assessment of how POSC has impacted infant outcomes and racial and ethnic disproportionality in infant foster placements, and a qualitative assessment of contextual barriers and facilitators of POSC implementation including which POSC elements may contribute to changes in racial and ethnic disproportionality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with HIV-infection and those exposed to HIV without infection are at very high risk of becoming wasted (low weight-for-height or mid upper arm circumference). In the R21 phase of this grant, we propose to develop and test a novel mHealth intervention, called MAMMS-IYCF, that aims to facilitate the prevention and treatment of childhood wasting among these children. During the R33, we will then conduct a randomized clinical trial to establish the effectiveness of this novel intervention at improving child health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative. Antibiotics are wonder drugs that have tamed bacterial infections over the past century. Unfortunately, pathogens are now becoming resistant to the best antibiotics used in clinical practice today. This project is aimed at identifying non-antibiotic strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections. Successful execution of this project will add to the arsenal of tools we have to fight bacterial infections.
