IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although preterm birth is the leading cause of neurodevelopmental disorders, preterm infants are less likely than their term-age peers to receive human milk, which is recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics to promote optimal neurodevelopmental outcomes. This novel research will explore how maternal postnatal stress may affect lactation/feeding outcomes for preterm infants in the K99 phase and use a biological systems approach in the R00 phase to elucidate how human milk and preterm infant gut composition may be altered by maternal stress in ways that impair neurodevelopment, with the goal of improving neurodevelopmental outcomes for this vulnerable population. The proposed work will assist in identification of targets for psychosocial intervention and supplementation of mother, milk, or infant to enhance the bioactive qualities of human milk and reduce the incidence of neurobehavioral disorders, thereby improving the health of preterm infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The multipotent neural crest cell population contributes to a wide range of derivatives including most of the craniofacial skeleton and dental tissue, and their aberrant development results in numerous human congenital defects including Mowat-Wilson Syndrome. These experiments will demonstrate precisely how ZEB2 regulates human neural crest cell formation, differentiation, and the Mowat-Wilson Syndrome pathology by coupling pluripotent stem cells with the development of a novel organoid model of human tooth formation. This project is relevant to the mission of NIDCR because the expected results will advance our understanding of the molecular underpinnings of this understudied pathology, and provide a unique platform from which to further explore molecular and environmental influences on human craniofacial and dental development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research proposed here will systematically quantify the effects of craniofacial transcription factor dosage changes on molecular, cellular, and morphological phenotypes. This work will provide: (1) mechanisms underlying sensitivity to transcription factor dosage in normal-range and disease-associated variation, (2) insights into the specific facial phenotypes observed in a range of craniofacial syndromes, and (3) basic insights into the mechanisms of transcription-factor mediated regulation. Finally, by driving forward our understanding of craniofacial variation and disease, the proposed research will nominate key genes and pathways that one day could inform disease prediction and/or therapeutic development.

PHR: Project Narrative: Coronaviruses can emerge from wildlife reservoirs and infect humans resulting in outbreaks of pneumonia, as we are experiencing with Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). We want to identify how coronaviruses evade the early warning system of the immune response. These studies will teach us how coronaviruses slip under the radar of our immune defenses and cause disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Pharmaceutical drugs have reduced mortality and morbidity across all areas of medicine; however, key challenges such as undesirable side effects, poor efficacy, and the need for frequent administration or complex administration routes limit their ability to have even more pronounced impact on patient welfare. The projects described within this proposal seek to overcome these challenges by developing injectable drug delivery platforms that can precisely control pharmacokinetics, reduce the frequency at which drug needs to be readministered, deliver biologics in their bioactive form, and enable multi-drug therapies that match dynamic patient needs. To achieve these goals, we will develop surface-eroding biomaterials that protect the encapsulated payload in combination with advanced fabrication methods that define microparticle geometry— and thus the release of drugs encapsulated in surface-eroding materials—to rationally design injectable particles that are compatible with a broad array of drug classes and exhibit predictable release kinetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians by addressing the confluence between biological, social, and policy drivers through high-impact, cutting-edge research; person-centered care across the continuum, from prevention through survivorship; community integration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. The core of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG) since 1975, and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports efforts across the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement; cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity, equity, and inclusion; shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding to supporting team-based, transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined, catchment area priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project seeks to develop small-molecule antagonists of the K-RAS oncogene to inhibit tumor growth in cancer. The project is relevant to public health because small molecules that emerge from this work may lead to therapeutic agents for treatment of patients with pancreatic, lung, and colon cancer. The project is relevant to the NIH’s mission as it has the potential to reduce mortality due to range of cancers driven by aberrant K-RAS signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis is a global epidemic with a high disease burden, although clinicians caring for septic patients are unable to distinguish between septic patients who will rapidly recover and those who will develop a prolonged disease course marked by significant morbidity and mortality. This is partly due to our incomplete understanding of the complex underlying immune responses in sepsis as well as our inability to translate research findings into information that is useful to clinicians. This research will contribute to the development of novel techniques that will help clinicians to get individualized results about their patients’ immune responses, to guide their decisions about whether immune-adjuvant therapy may be appropriate for each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Residents of correctional facilities are disproportionately at risk of developing and dying of COVID-19. To mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2, Departments of Correction have instituted prevention measures including vaccine campaigns, social distancing, and mass screening. Through this proposal, we seek to derive an evidence base for these prevention measures and develop an adaptive intervention simulation model to identify scenarios when prevention measure modification is justified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH We have developed a minimally invasive approach to determine the expression of DNA damage response (DDR) biomarkers in human PBMCs (from whole blood sample). In this proposal, we will analytically validate the Luminex multiplexed assay which uses the multi-analyte platform (xMAP) technology (UH2 phase) and then establish clinical validity by using biospecimens from the Fox Chase Cancer Center Biosample Repository Facility and from two clinical studies in locally advanced rectal cancer (UH3 phase). The ultimate goal of this research is to utilize the blood-based DDR biomarkers to guide patient stratification for treatment in the setting of locally advanced rectal cancer and potentially other cancers in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Pharmacy-based models of care can close a critical implementation gap in delivering HIV testing and PrEP to priority populations affected by the HIV epidemic. Utilizing well-established implementation science frameworks, this study will examine key determinants, strategies, and mechanisms of implementing rapid HIV testing and PrEP initiation in community pharmacy settings, with the goal of maximizing the program’s acceptability, feasibility, appropriateness, and reach. The research will provide key implementation data for an adaptable pharmacy-based HIV testing and PrEP initiation model that can reduce health inequities and expand access to these evidence-based practices in communities affected by HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This supplement project extension is designed to strengthen research, training, and outreach by the Fred & Pamela Buffett Cancer Center with the goal of training predoctoral, postdoctoral, and early-stage faculty scholars from American Indian, Hispanic, rural, and financially disadvantaged populations, which are often overlapping populations within Nebraska. This project extension will focus on guiding diverse scholars into the pathway of cancer-related research training, optimizing their professional development and networking skills, and facilitating the advancement of these scholars through NCI workforce opportunities. In addition, during this project extension we will prepare to monitor the scholars’ success as they advance in their careers in cancer research and clinical care, and we will conduct evaluations of the training activities’ outcomes, complete project reports, and disseminate the knowledge gained from this project on best practices in mentoring these scholars.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – JOHNS HOPKINS ERC OVERALL Situated in the largest, most highly ranked school of public health in the world, the multidisciplinary Johns Hopkins Education and Research Center for Occupational Safety and Health prepares occupational safety and health professionals in the areas of research, education, practice, and policy development, and provides outreach and continuing education in occupational safety and health. Since its establishment in 1977, the Johns Hopkins ERC has evolved in response to changing demands in the field, as well as to scientific and technological advances that impact occupational safety and health practice, research, and education, while retaining steadfastly its commitment to an integrated, interdisciplinary approach to training researchers and practitioners. The Center addresses ongoing and emerging issues, thereby building the national capacity to provide care, set policy, design and manage safety and health programs, and conduct research to further the National Occupational Research Agenda and advance the body of knowledge in this field—and as the only ERC in federal region III, which includes Maryland, Washington, D.C., Virginia, West Virginia, Delaware, and Pennsylvania —we are dedicated to meeting regional as well as national and international needs, and our center’s Outreach and Continuing Education efforts serve hundreds of organizations each year within our region alone, including private-sector businesses, nonprofit and academic organizations, local, state, and federal government agencies, and the military.

PHR: Narrative The life quality of bone metastasis patients is extremely poor as metastasized tumor cells frequently fragilize the bone, causing intolerable pain and immobility. Currently, there is no effective treatment in the clinic to cure bone metastasis. To solve this important medical problem, we will develop next-generation cement material that can deliver anti-cancer drugs and restore the bone health of cancer patients to recover their lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Breastfeeding provides substantial protection against subsequent metabolic disease for mothers with obesity and/or diabetes and their babies, yet these women are at increased risk of inadequate milk production. The aims of this project will be to investigate the effects of maternal metabolic hormones on mammary development and function using cells derived from human milk and complementary in vivo and in vitro mouse models. Studies will be performed at a top tier program in lactation research and will identify interventional opportunities to improve lactation outcomes in an effort to decrease long-term metabolic risks for both mothers and their children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss-of-function of the Src-family kinase Lyn is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an auto- immune disease that is 10x more common in women than in men. We have discovered that the shorter isoform of Lyn (LynB) has a dominant function in maintaining immune balance in mice, whereas the longer isoform (LynA) confers specific protection to females. With the long-term goal of modulating the pro-inflammatory and pro-ho- meostatic functions of Lyn for potential therapies, we propose to define the unique signaling functions and sex- specific regulation of the two Lyn isoforms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Silicosis and asbestosis are progressive scarring diseases of the lungs caused by inhalation of silica and asbestos, respectively. Effective therapies are limited due to our incomplete understanding of the mechanisms that initiate and perpetuate the disease; however, scarring is thought to arise from impaired regeneration of the lung after injury. The objective of this application is to identify the specific mechanisms by which normal regeneration is impaired and promotes scarring in silicosis and asbestosis, thus identifying novel therapeutic targets.

PHR: Narrative Exposure to fine particulate air pollution (PM2.5) is a leading cause of cardiovascular disease, respiratory disease, and premature death. This research will investigate potential links between PM2.5 composition, its ability to promote oxidative stress in the body, and its short-term and long-term health effects on a national scale. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Fluoride exposure is ubiquitous and has been associated with impaired neurodevelopment in children. Adolescence is an understudied life stage during which profound brain remodeling and behavioral development may be influenced by early life environmental factors such as fluoride. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy cells have numerous safeguards to slow or halt replication when faced with DNA damage or other forms of cellular stress. Many cancers, however, have the remarkable ability to tolerate high levels of DNA damage and other replication challenges imposed by environmental and endogenous agents, often at the cost of more mutations. Understanding the mechanisms by which cancer cells can accumulate mutations and become drug resistant may ultimately lead to new therapeutic approaches to this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Pyramidal neurons in the primary visual cortex (V1) undergo dynamic plasticity changes throughout visual associative learning. This proposal will define which learning events drive differential plastic changes in V1 and how learning or V1 activity shape cortico-cortical functional connectivity. We expect our findings to provide important insight into the behavioral underpinnings of V1 and cortico-cortical plasticity throughout learning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is designed to establish an interdisciplinary training program in clinical pain research at Mass General  Brigham (MGB) in Boston. The long-term goal is to expand the number, diversity, and collaborative network of clinical  pain researchers, advancing our understanding of pain and our ability to effectively manage pain without opioid  medications. This program offers interdisciplinary mentorship and training in clinical pain research by bringing together a  diverse group of mentors from an array of backgrounds, including Psychology, Neurology, Neuroscience, Psychiatry,  Epidemiology to promote innovative solutions for pain management and improve patient care by providing high-quality  training to future leaders in clinical pain research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed trial will provide one of the first rigorous tests of whether the effects of topiramate in AUD generalize to patients with co-occurring PTSD, and one of the first rigorous tests of whether topiramate has beneficial effects on PTSD symptoms in this population. It will be the first study to test whether the rs2832407 genotype predicts clinical response to topiramate for AUD and PTSD in patients with both disorders. Further, it will contribute to the understanding of topiramate’s mechanisms of action in the co- morbid AUD/PTSD population, and to the discovery of predictors of treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Programmable nucleic acid targeting tools such as CRISPR provide a new modality for programmable RNA targeting but current RNA-targeting tools suffer from potential issues with safety, specificity, and versatility. We propose to develop new, specific RNA-targeting CRISPR systems without off-target collateral activity in cells and engineer these systems to generate new RNA writing technologies capable of all possible base conversions, insertions or deletions of any size, and exon replacement. The technologies developed from this work will accelerate the study and modeling of disease biology and provide a revolutionary platform for RNA-based therapeutics, including many triplet repeat disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggregating across biological datasets reveals a patchwork of different technologies and conditions of interest; however, several holes exist in this patchwork, hindering our ability to entirely utilize biological datasets that currently exist. We propose to use a special class of methods, called domain adaptation methods, that can leverage the local patterns in the patchwork to build models that can either work around the missing pieces or fill them in. To show the strength and flexibility of these approaches, we apply our methods to three biomedical application areas: 1) inferring missing cell-type-specific treatment responses in Rheumatoid Arthritis; 2) predicting the tissue-of-origin of cell-free DNA (cfDNA) from a model trained on a different but complementary data type to cfDNA; 3) predicting gene expression patterns in the bone marrow from cfDNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal exposure to HIV can affect both the oral immune system and the microbes that normally inhabit the mouth (including the bacterial microbiome), which may increase the risk of oral HPV infection. Using a large cohort of children born to HIV-infected mothers (and, for comparison, children born to uninfected mothers) from Nigeria, this study seeks to understand the risk of oral HPV infection and role of the oral microbiome in youth perinatally exposed or/and infected with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alabama has launched a statewide action plan for cervical cancer elimination as a public health problem known as OPERATION WIPE OUT. We propose to expand and examine the feasibility of an integrated theory-driven, participatory multi-channel communication campaign to promote HPV vaccination, cervical cancer screening, and follow-up with high school students being agents of change with the support of OPERATION WIPE OUT partners and linked to school- based vaccination as well access to HPV vaccination, screening, and follow-up in the community.

PHR: Project Narrative: The importance of mechanosensitive channels to human health is underscored by the association of many disease states with compromised mechanosensation, including atrial fibrillation, muscular degeneration, arrhythmias, polycystic kidney disease, and numerous neural diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Youth-onset type 2 diabetes (T2D) typically manifests during or shortly after puberty and is characterized by a greater frequency and severity of diabetic kidney disease compared to adult-onset T2D and type 1 diabetes of similar duration. Puberty is recognized to accelerate kidney injury in youth with obesity and diabetes and may explain the magnified risk of diabetic kidney disease in youth-onset T2D, yet the pubertal mechanisms contributing to kidney injury in obesity and youth-onset T2D are unknown. The accelerated longitudinal study proposed in this application seeks to address these substantive gaps in knowledge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of the proposed University of Michigan (UM) HEAL National K12 Clinical Pain Career Development Program (UM-HCPDP) is to develop a national training program for early career clinician- scientists so as to grow the next generation of clinical pain research scholars. This national K12 program develops guidelines for career development and mentoring in clinical pain research, and coordinates training for scholars across institutions and mentorship teams, and with the Coordinating Center for National Pain Scientists Program (CCNPS). The UM-HCPDP seeks to train clinician-scientists with a deep understanding of pain mechanisms, non-opioid treatment options, scientific methodological rigor, leadership, patient-centric perspectives, and compassion for those who are suffering. This supplement seeks to expand the number and diversity of clinical pain research scholars entering the field of pain research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans have developed mechanisms to restrict bacterial access to metals during infection, and thus, pathogens in turn have evolved high-affinity metal acquisition systems to overcome this restriction. This project will identify the mechanisms used by Yersinia pestis to acquire zinc in order to cause the human disease plague. As metal acquisition is essential for virulence, defining these mechanisms will reveal novel targets for the development of new anti-plague therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Bone lesions from a variety of pathologies, including multiple myeloma, can occur anywhere in the skeleton, cause pain and spinal cord compressions, leading to pathologic fractures and paralysis, thereby diminishing the patient's quality of life. We propose to develop and evaluate an efficient whole-body magnetic resonance imaging (WBMRI) technology that can accurately identify these lesions and measure their response to treatment. This will provide relevant clinical information for treatment decisions to positively impact patients' quality of life and overall survival.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The most recent conflicts are creating a new generation of veterans, including an increasing number of women veterans, who present with comorbid PTSD and chronic pain conditions, including Fibromyalgia (FM), from deployment-related physical injuries and exposure to psychological trauma. Health behavior change is important in treating these conditions and proactively preventing long-term negative health sequelae, in order to benefit these veterans directly and reduce the challenges to our healthcare system. The proposed SPiRE application will use an innovative translational research approach to study whether a progressive -based exercise program will reduce FM pain in patients with PTSD and to elucidate and modify potential PTSD- related deficiencies in neurobiological and psychological responses to exercise to optimize the physical and psychological benefits of exercise for these individuals.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Previous studies suggest that Veterans with a leg amputation who use a prosthesis have impaired physical function, which could increase the risk of osteoarthritis, leg/back pain, and diabetes/obesity. The alignment of a lower limb prosthesis, which is the orientation of prosthetic components with respect to the socket, affects the risk of secondary injury and physical function of Veterans with leg amputation. Currently, there are no objective methods to assess prosthetic alignment in Veterans with a leg amputation. Thus, we will develop an accurate, precise, and cost-efficient measurement method to objectively [assess] prosthetic alignment in a clinical setting. In the long term, [this approach could be used to investigate the relationship between prosthesis alignment and comfort, secondary injury risk, and quality of life in Veterans with lower limb amputation. We ultimately aim to advance measurement technology and rehabilitation to reduce discomfort and improve the physical function and quality of life of Veterans with an amputation.]

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Narrative Osteoarthritis (OA) is a prevalent condition that compromises activities of daily living and has few treatment options that preserve the joint. To address this limitation, this proposal extends and applies our progress in functional cartilage tissue engineering to address the `holy grail' of biologic joint resurfacing by fabricating and testing, in a large animal model, a stem cell-based replacement for the majority of the load bearing surface of the medial femoral condyle. Once validated in this pre-clinical model, this technology can be extended to other, more complex joint surfaces throughout the body. Our goal is to eliminate the need for replacement with metal and plastic and alleviate the serious implications of OA in the Veteran population, and in society as a whole.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Incontinence associates with military service and post-traumatic stress disorder in both male and female Veterans. Neurogenic detrusor overactivity (NDO) is caused by spinal cord injury or disorder, or peripheral neurodegenerative conditions, and causes urine leakage at low volumes. NDO is disproportionately experienced by Veterans treatment effectiveness varies greatly between individuals. This project will demonstrate the feasibility of a new type of nerve stimulation—triggered sacral neuromodulation—to treat NDO in Veterans. A wireless bladder sensor will be inserted into the bladder to transmit a feedback signal enabling stimulation from a percutaneous lead. The wireless sensor will also measure NDO symptoms during simulated activities of daily living without catheters. Catheter-free detection of bladder activity will improve the outcomes of neuromodulation evaluations for Veterans with NDO. Future work could use the triggered neuromodulation system to study other methods of nerve stimulation to treat bladder, bowel, or sexual dysfunction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: LOUIS STOKES CLEVELAND VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Dr. Kirsch’s research activities focus on restoring shoulder, arm, and hand movements to individuals with extensive paralysis due to spinal cord injury (SCI). SCI is a devastating condition that often causes significant disability and loss of independence. There are approximately 296,000 individuals in the United States with a SCI, at least 42,000 of whom are Veterans eligible for VA care. Dr. Kirsch has used functional electrical stimulation to elicit contractions in paralyzed muscles that can power movements, and novel control methods to coordinate these muscle contractions to generate functional movements. He has also examined cutting edge “brain computer interface” techniques to give the users of such a system the ability to intuitively command the desired movements of the upper limb. Dr. Kirsch is also very active in “translational research” programs that assist researchers in developing their laboratory discoveries into products that improve the independence and overall health of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  Fluorinated drugs, accounting for 29% of all 276 Type 1 FDA new drug approvals between 2011-2019,  demonstrate the growing importance of fluorine-18 labeled molecules in PET applications. By merging  radiochemistry with organometallic chemistry, this proposal aims to meet the demand for aromatic fluorine 18 radiomedicines. The development of new metal-mediated and metal-free late-stage radiolabeling methods  can significantly expedite the production of fluorine-containing molecules, particularly those of high  commercial importance.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will convene cuffGEN, the largest consortium to date, to study the genetics of imaging- confirmed rotator cuff tears and fatty infiltration, which lead to shoulder pain and disability. In addition to identifying high-risk individuals with genetic variants associated with rotator cuff tear and fatty infiltration, the study prioritizes gene discovery by incorporating gene expression information and assesses causality between obesity and fatty infiltration. Data from this study can also help identify individuals for whom treatments are most likely to be successful based on their genetic profile.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Achieving better T2D self-management remains a challenge for socio-economically disadvantaged populations and immigrants. Adult Haitian immigrants with T2D have higher insulin resistance and A1c than other comparable racial/ethnic groups increasing their risk for morbidity and mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Siteman Cancer Center (SCC) is committed to overcoming structural barriers that have limited diversity and equity in academic medicine and the cancer research workforce. The overarching goal of the SCC initiative to Strengthen Research, Training, and Outreach Capacity is to provide personalized training navigation to link scholars to cancer research supports. SCC staff will collaborate to implement infrastructure and processes that increase: trainee awareness and use of shared cores and resources appropriate to their interests; identification of mentors; awareness of catchment priorities and cancer health inequities; and trainings including grant writing, scientific editing, and travel supports to advance the career development and trajectory of SCC trainees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE OF FUNDED R15 GRANT (R15CA254006-01A1) Immune cells from the bone marrow are known to migrate to tumors and play an important role ongoing tumor growth. Bone marrow-derived hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells are also present in tumors but their role in tumor activity is still unknown. This proposal will elucidate how hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells are maintained in tumors and identify the role they play in tumor progression and response to therapy. The long- term goals are to use findings to develop novel treatment strategies that overcome the pro-tumor effects of these stem cells resulting in better patient outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project is to develop and validate low-dose quantitative dynamic contrast enhanced (DCE) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pancreas under free-breathing conditions. This will be accomplished by cultivating a new technology, DCE MR Multitasking, which can quantify tissue kinetic and flow parameters even in moving organs. The resulting technology will offer clinicians and investigators a valuable tool to diagnose, monitor, and study pancreatic and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Through this supplemental funding award, the UCLA Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center Community Outreach and Engagement (JCCC COE) team will collaborate with community partners, the Mixteco Indigena Community Organizing Project (MICOP) and Antelope Valley Partners for Health (AVPH) to develop tailored multi-channel communication campaigns to promote cancer screening and tobacco control in predominately low-income Latinx communities in two high need regions served by the JCCC. Supplement activities are expected to reach over 78,500 residents and will include radio campaigns, social media campaigns, training of community health workers, and referral to cancer screening services. Receipt of this supplement will be instrumental in expanding our capacity to promote cancer screening and tobacco control in the high-need Latinx communities served by these organizations and to disseminate our messages and approaches more broadly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: CHARLES R. DREW UNIVERSITY OF MED & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this IPERT renewal application, submitted by California State University, Long Beach (CSULB) Center for Health Equity Research (CHER), is to provide enhanced educational and mentored activities to increase the readiness of diverse early career faculty at minority serving institutions (MSIs) to conduct community-engaged biomedical research designed to promote health equity, including research with basic, clinical, behavioral, and translational outcomes. CHER aims to increase the number of scientists from MSIs represented among National Institutes of Health (NIH)-funded investigators because scientists from MSIs bring unique perspectives and experiences, which are required to successfully diversify the workforce and enhance health equity biomedical research, particularly in the areas of reaching underrepresented minority communities, building trust, healing historical injustices, and enhancing participation in research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infects one-third of the world’s population and causes almost 1.3 million deaths per year, including 100, 000 children. Approximately 90% of infected persons have latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI), have protective immunity and remain well, but 10% develop primary tuberculosis (TB) soon after infection or reactivation TB many years later. TB is the leading cause of death in HIV-infected persons and more than half a million coinfected people die annually. Children are more susceptible to TB infection, due to an immature immune system. HIV infection in children markedly increases susceptibility to TB. To develop adequate prophylaxis or therapy, it is important to understand immune responses to Mtb. Identification of HIV+ children with LTBI who are at greatly increased risk for development of TB would allow treating only high-risk children, facilitating completion of therapy for LTBI and preventing future development of TB. To identify these children, it is important to pinpoint the nature of the defective immune responses that permit development of active TB in HIV+LTBI+ pediatric patients. This proposal will identify a novel memory-like NK cell subpopulation mediated mechanisms that regulate immune responses and pinpoint the nature of the defective responses that permit development of active TB in HIV-LTBI+ and HIV+LTBI+ children. These studies will lay the groundwork for strategies to develop novel anti-tuberculosis vaccines that stimulate strong NK cell mediated immunity in HIV+ and HIV- children with LTBI, and reduce development of TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our innovative multicultural, multilingual, multichannel educational campaign (MICEO) on HPV related cancers reaches diverse audiences of adolescents and young adults in the African American, Hispanic/Latino and Chinese communities of Los Angeles. We collaborate with federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) and multicultural community-based organizations in partnerships that engage adolescents and young adults in a participatory manner in the creation of targeted messaging regarding HPV delivered via social media and outdoor media placements. Our MICEO campaign is expected to reduce pervasive HPV related cancer disparities in communities at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians by addressing the confluence between biological, social, and policy drivers through high-impact, cutting-edge research; person-centered care across the continuum, from prevention through survivorship; community integration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. The core of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG) since 1975, and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports efforts across the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement; cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity, equity, and inclusion; shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding to supporting team-based, transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined, catchment area priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The senses of hearing and balance rely on tip-link protein filaments that pull on transduction ion channels to transform mechanical stimuli into electrochemical signals that can be processed by the brain. Mutations to the proteins forming the tip link and the transduction channel complex have been shown to cause deafness in humans and animal models. Here we propose to use structural and computational tools to gain insights into how the inner-ear proteins forming the tip link and the transduction channel complex function in normal and impaired hearing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Childhood cancer survivors are a high-priority, underserved population for HPV vaccination because they are less likely to be vaccinated and more likely to develop second cancers caused by HPV as adults when compared to the general population. This project will use an iterative, participatory, and collaborative approach to leverage, build on, optimize, and expand an HPV vaccination campaign for childhood cancer survivors to include peer-to-peer patient family experienced and clinician education and training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proper assembly of membrane proteins as folded subunits or macromolecular complexes, is of critical importance to cellular physiology, yet we do not have a fundamental understanding of the physical reasons why membrane proteins assemble in the hydrophobic environment of the membrane. In this project, we are studying the equilibrium dimerization reaction of the CLC-ec1 Cl-/H+ antiporter as a model system to dissect the thermodynamic driving forces underlying membrane protein association in lipid bilayers. The results from this study will identify the molecular mechanisms for how protein sequence, lipid composition and general anesthetics modulate stability, and thereby lay down a physical foundation for the development of new strategies aimed at correcting stability defects in membrane protein folding diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The U.S. mining industry remains one of the most dangerous and challenging environments for workers according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), and the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA). BLS and MSHA show that mining fatality rate is five times higher than other U.S. industries with an average of 36 fatalities per year within 2009 and 2018. This research initiative will reduce miners’ risk of traumatic injuries and fatalities in underground mine emergencies via new wireless communication, improved human-robot interactions, and refuge alternatives, and mine fire and explosions response and evacuation management.

PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Research, Technological Innovations and Human Factors for Effective Miner Self-Escape from Underground Mine Emergencies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: FDA guidelines stipulate that all new drugs be tested for dangerous side-effects on the heart as part of preclinical research; however, the current tests are poorly predictive of both dangerous and safe drugs leading to unwarranted attrition and dangerous drugs reaching clinic. Human cardiomyocytes derived from donor tissue (iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes) are widely considered to hold great promise for clinical trial in a dish studies of drug cardiotoxicity. This STTR proposal is to commercialize a high throughput platform to accurately identify drug candidates that have cardiac side effects, in particular adding the ability to detect the type of primary heart cell damage common with anti-cancer drugs in a fully automated (high throughput) robotic assay for the first time, to improve the efficiency of preclinical research and the safety of human clinical trials, which will also likely have the added benefit of reducing animal research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Behavioral health problems among Veterans have raised awareness of the critical need for more reliable, effective, and accessible ways to recognize those in need, direct them to help, and ensure that they receive the best evidence-based care available. AboutFace is a novel peer education program that features the personal stories of Veterans and is designed to improve Veterans’ likelihood of engaging in PTSD specialty care. Using a randomized controlled study design we propose to compare the efficacy of AboutFace relative to standard care for improving treatment engagement and outcomes. Additional data from VA providers will provide valuable information on wide scale implementation and dissemination of AboutFace. If AboutFace increases access of services, data will have broad implications for overcoming barriers to care for Veterans with PTSD and other stigmatized conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US health care system leads the world in administrative complexity and its associated costs. Cancer is a complex and often high-acuity condition with persistent disparities in health outcomes, making cancer care delivery a priority setting for assessing patient administrative burdens and identifying solutions. The proposed research uses qualitative, survey, and claims data in a sequential mixed methods analysis that will enable the measurement and diagnosis of administrative burden across cancer care settings and produce evidence identifying and motivating actionable organizational or policy targets for clinical leaders and policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the ADAM9 gene lead to loss of vision in human and veterinary patients. The proposed research utilizes genetically modified mouse models to address the pathophysiological mechanisms underlying photoreceptor degeneration due to the loss of ADAM9. Identifying these mechanisms is critical for developing therapeutic interventions aiming to prevent vision loss in affected patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Traumatic brain injury induced chronic traumatic encephalopathy and vascular dementia are two major forms of aging related neurodegenerative diseases affecting millions of Americans. The goal of this proposal is to investigate a conserved and early molecular mechanism driving neurodegeneration in both diseases and to evaluate the preclinical therapeutic potential to target this mechanism. Understanding of this molecular mechanism and therapeutic assessment may provide insight into the disease progression and early therapeutic intervention to prevent dementia in traumatic brain injury induced chronic traumatic encephalopathy and vascular dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triclosan is a nearly ubiquitous exposure that has been phased out in some but not all consumer products due to recognition of its potential deleterious effects, including adverse neurobehavioral development. The proposed research will clarify the potential for triclosan to impact adolescent neurobehavior and elucidate the role of the gut microbiome and its metabolites in this association. This work has the potential to identify modifiable determinants and health effects of the adolescent gut microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research will lay a foundation for developing innovative, individualized interventions to improve nonverbal communication (NVC) experiences for autistic adults, based on the values and first-hand experiences of our target population. Improvements in NVC are necessary for downstream improvements in a range of func- tional contexts, resulting in overall improved life outcomes associated with autism in adulthood. This project is relevant to NIDCD’s mission pertaining to intervention, and to the NIH’s Interagency Autism Coordinating Com- mittee’s dual missions related to intervention and lifespan issues. This project will produce a set of specific, stakeholder-driven recommendations for designing and prioritizing NVC intervention development, opening new horizons for how NVC is conceptualized and addressed in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of acute leukemia in adults and most patients will die from their disease. Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy is a novel form of cellular immunotherapy that has demonstrated great success in acute lymphoblastic leukemia, but translation of CAR T cell therapy to AML is complicated by (1) heterogeneous target antigen expression in AML, (2) expression of some target antigens on normal bone marrow cells in addition to AML, and (3) active immune-suppressive strategies employed by AML. The goals of this project are to generate multi-antigen-specific CAR T cells to eliminate AML by mitigating escape of antigen-negative leukemia, to identify sets of AML target antigens that are either non- myelosuppressive when targeted or that are myeloablative and can facilitate donor hematopoietic cell engraftment, and to further engineer CAR T cells to overcome AML-induced immune suppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Caregiving is commonly acknowledged as one of the most stressful, under-recognized, under- paid, and under-supported jobs. The new MapHabit System Caregiver Training Program (CTP) will offer a technology-driven caregiver training platform that will train caregivers to be more knowledgeable about memory and dementia while also learning to better manage their own stress and their quality of life needs. In this way, caregivers can be more innovative in their care strategies using person-centered wellness plans and thoughtful decision processes. Informed patient care reinforces effective caregiving, reduces patient emergency visits, hospitalizations, caregiver dropout, and reduces overall burden on the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Genome duplication and repair require complex regulation. These regulatory mechanisms have broad influence on human diseases, ranging from developmental deficiency to cancers. Our work will use a combination of approaches to understand how cells ensure completion of replication, removal of DNA repair intermediates, and turning off the genome stress response at the right time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have shown that SEMA7A promotes multiple aspects of breast cancer progression, including proliferation, survival, invasion, and immune evasion. The F99 portion of this proposal (Aim 1) aims to investigate SEMA7A- mediated alterations to TAMs and T cells in the TME responsible for suppressing anti-tumor immunity and if targeting SEMA7A directly can impede tumor growth and immunoevasion. The K00 aspect of this application (Aim 2) proposes to identify novel mechanisms of immunoevasion in renal cell carcinoma and pancreatic ductal carcinoma, which may reveal novel targets for treatment to prevent metastases and prolong patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD8+ T cells are crucial immune cells in our body’s fight against cancer and the degree to which CD8+ T cells traffic to and infiltrate the tumor greatly impacts cancer patient survival, especially melanoma patient survival. The F99 section of this proposal focuses on a new pathway existing between CD8+ T cells and a protein present at the tumor that negatively impacts CD8+ T-cell survival. Through mouse models, we will illuminate this mechanism to be able to block this negative interaction between CD8+ T cells and this suppressive protein to increase CD8+ T-cell survival, and ultimately improve melanoma patient survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Bim1 is linked to increased virulence for Cryptococcus neoformans in a mouse meningitis infection model and participates in Cu-homeostasis. Related BLP genes are also present in several fungal pathogens affecting humans, including Coccidioides immitis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Talaromyces marneffei, and Aspergillus niger but little is known about how BLP sequence variation affects biological function. In the proposed research project, we will explore the active site design of this novel class of BLP copper trafficking proteins and explore their mechanism for Cu-delivery at the fungal cell surface; ultimately our findings will lead to a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of copper homeostasis in fungi which may be exploited for the development of future antifungal treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus mutans is a common oral bacterium that is found around the world and is associated with tooth decay and extraoral infections like infective endocarditis, with annual related health care costs in the US alone exceeding 60 billion dollars. S. mutans produces several proteins that form insoluble amyloid aggregates during biofilm growth so it is important to understand how the amyloids form and are regulated to better treat and prevent disease. This research will characterize monomeric compared to amyloid structures of these proteins, and evaluate how other components within biofilm matrices, such as extracellular DNA and lipid membranes, impact amyloid formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Individuals with sickle cell disease (SCD) often endure multiple acute pain crises throughout their lives and as they contend with chronic pain. Music Therapy is a promising, safe option response to chronic pain and anxiety, but future multi-site randomized trials are needed. Completion of the proposed R01 and the subsequent RCT (UG3/UH3) could provide critical evidence to support inclusion of MT as a chronic pain intervention for individuals with SCD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Millions of persons with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa are now surviving for decades on treatment but are devel- oping chronic non-communicable disease complications that require new science and new directions in pre- vention, detection, and treatment. The University of Zambia (UNZA)-Vanderbilt HIV Research Training Partner- ship (UVP) has been extremely successful, achieving all its aims including supporting 11 UNZA PhD students, evaluating and facilitating a new structure for the UNZA PhD Program, and hosting two UNZA Visiting Faculty Scholars at Vanderbilt. We will deepen and extend the impact of UVP in catalyzing UNZA's research capacity by shifting the grant's primary leadership to UNZA, training five UNZA PhD students and four postdoctoral sci- entists, implementating UNZA's new postdoctoral fellowship program, adding two South-South partnerships with the University of the Witwatersrand and the Consortium for Advanced Research Training in Africa (CARTA), and establishing a Biostatistics Support Core service at UNZA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the deadliest form of cancer and is diagnosed by performing biopsies with a bronchoscope; how- ever, this tool is limited in its ability to explore deep into the periphery of the lung, where cancer can remain undetected. This proposal focuses on the design, development, and validation of a novel soft surgical robot to address critical unmet needs within the world of lung cancer. These include increasing the depth of access in peripheral regions and improving navigability within the lungs, enhancing the precision and accuracy of tissue biopsies, and enabling for the first-time rapid diagnosis and simultaneous therapy in a single bronchoscopy pro- cedure to hasten cancer treatment and increase the rate of survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We will build on sophisticated technology that we have invented to measure how groups of animals interact with each other as well as with their surroundings during long-term, longitudinal studies of aging, and how these interactions affect demographic and molecular measures of health. These new technologies and experimental paradigms will push the limits of behavioral monitoring and analysis in any organism and will be used to investigate the molecular causes and consequences of social interactions on aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative In humans, the greater the social connectedness and socioeconomic status, the lower the burden of diseases and mortality rate. Unfortunately, the causal role of social context on aging-related diseases is difficult to ascertain because randomization is impossible/unethical. This project will develop rigorous socio-behavioral models and innovative assessment tools in laboratory mice, with the ultimate goal of identifying social factors affecting individual variability in aging processes, and socio-behavioral intervention to increase resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Aging is a chronic condition that afflicts all living systems; healthy vs. unhealthy aging can be measured using a frailty index which is often used in interventional studies. Here we propose to develop scalable frailty index using computer vision and machine learning in the context of genetically diverse mouse populations with diet- based interventions to mimics human aging. The resulting tool will strengthen the utility of animal models for behavioral and social research toward understanding how social and physical environmental factors contribute to aging processes and the etiology and progression of age-related conditions and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sarcopenia is a debilitating age-related skeletal muscle wasting syndrome associated with poor quality of life and high health care utilization. Identifying the mechanisms underpinning sarcopenia is critical for developing pharmacologic therapies to enhance late-life health and function. The proposed work will interrogate the extent to which cellular senescence, a central aging mechanism, mediates skeletal muscle dysfunction and thus, may reveal a new druggable target for treatment or prevention of sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health as there is still a gap in understanding maternal-infant pharmacology. The UCSD MPRINT Center of Excellence in Therapeutics will bring together basic and data scientists, pharmacologists and clinical researchers in a highly collaborative fashion to understand the impact of infant exposure to maternal antibiotic treatment via breastmilk on the metabolism of the drugs, microbiome and immune function. The proposed research will help create a national resource for expertise in maternal and pediatric therapeutics and is relevant to NICHD’s mission by furthering the field of pediatric developmental pharmacology and in working towards ensuring that “all children have the chance to achieve their full potential for healthy and productive lives”.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The rapid histopathological examination can allow for an accurate intraoperative diagnosis and confirm negative tumor margins in the resected tissue (i.e., suggesting all of the cancer has been removed), providing surgical guidance and avoiding second surgeries. Currently, the intraoperative diagnosis in clinical practices relies mostly on the frozen section technique, which usually suffers from compromised diagnostic interpretation due to processing artifacts and only applies to limited tissue types. To address these challenges, I propose developing the deep learning-assisted photoacoustic histology platform to generate readily interpretable computer-aided images for pathologists and surgeons to diagnose intraoperatively and remotely.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Music-based interventions (MBIs) including music therapy (MT) are known to be effective for managing pain in several populations, but substantial gaps remain in understanding the mechanisms of action by which MBIs influence pain. This proposal seeks to establish a NEW network: Effective Network to advance Scientific Evidence related to Mechanisms of music-Based interventions for pain and support coLlaborative Efforts (ENSEMBLE). ENSEMBLE will be instrumental in 1) promoting meaningful interdisciplinary dialogue; 2) building multi-institutional capacity for initiating MBI research in pain management; 3) generating preliminary data for future R21 or R34 grant proposals; 4) improving data infrastructure; 5) developing future MT clinician researchers; 6) focusing future scientific efforts; and 7) disseminating best practices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic pancreatitis (CP) is a progressive, unrelenting disease, often leading to loss of exocrine and endocrine function and debilitating abdominal pain, resulting in significant healthcare costs. The Consortium for the study of Chronic Pancreatitis, Diabetes and Pancreatic Cancer (CPDPC), now entering the final year of its second five- year funding cycle, has undertaken comprehensive clinical, epidemiological, and biological characterization of patients with CP (including adults and children with acute recurrent pancreatitis) to develop treatments and gain insight into the pathophysiology of CP and its sequela: chronic pain, pancreatic exocrine and endocrine insufficiency, and the diabetes/pancreatic cancer association. The Indiana University clinical center pledges to continue its contribution to ongoing high-priority CPDPC studies, which are described herein.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance As a large number of informal family caregivers (over 11 million) are at high risk for stress and depressive symptoms related to the difficulties of caring for individuals with Alzheimer's Disease (AD), there is a need for effective, accessible and cost-effective interventions. The new Recharge Behavioral Therapy (delivered by the Recharge Mobile App, RMA) will be an innovative program for teaching Behavioral Activation skills to AD caregivers, motivating healthy behaviors, and improving psychological well-being, which can be deployed widely and at low cost. After Phase II completion, the expected project outcomes are: reduce stress, alleviate depressive symptoms, enhance coping skills, and improve the quality of life of AD caregivers; in addition, the following indirect benefits are expected (not measured by this study): delay patient institutionalization, decrease caregiver medication related to stress/depressive symptoms, and thereby lower economic costs associated with AD caregiving.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  This study will determine if neck-skin vibration sensor and head-mounted microphone signals can be used to identify the physiological sources of modulated voice and to track responses to voice treatment. It is expected that the study findings will advance clinical identification of the subsystems affected by tremor and facilitate evaluation of individualized, targeted treatments for speakers with VT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will investigate the mechanisms that govern immune response to the brain tumor, glioblastoma. These mechanistic insights will help to inform the development of potential new combination therapeutic strategies for manipulating the specific immune cells, macrophages, in order to enhance anti-tumor immune response. This career development award will provide the applicant with high-level training and thereby allow her to launch an independent research career aimed at improving outcomes for patients suffering from brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although colorectal cancer (CRC) is enriched with pathogenic mtDNA mutations, the role of the mitochondrion in CRC remains unknown. In this proposal, we will leverage our expertise in mitochondrial biochemistry, state- of-the art in vivo, in vitro, and ex vivo CRC models, and viral genetic manipulation to define the molecular pathways linking mitochondrial metabolism to CRC growth. By providing a mechanistic link between mitochondrial bioenergetics and CRC, this work will move the field forward in our understanding of the role of mitochondria in CRC, ultimately paving the way for CRC-specific mitochondrial interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a complex, polygenic autoimmune disease that results from the immune destruction of insulin-producing cells. There is extensive heterogeneity in which AABs are expressed and at what levels, along with variations in donor/family information and Social Determinants of Health (SDoH), which significantly influence disease prognosis and outcomes. This project aims to define and harmonize common data elements to support interoperability and to enforce, and sustain the adoption and compliance of the developed CDE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Symptoms of Lower Urinary Tract Dysfunction Research Network (LURN) was assembled in 2012 to increase the understanding of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), which has included determining relationships between psychosocial variables and LUTS. In this supplement, we will focus on 1) Determining the relationship between level of cognitive function and LUTS and 2) Determining baseline predictors of LUTS trajectories in a sample of men and women with urinary urgency. We also plan to explore psychosocial variables that have not been explored with respect to urgency, such as intolerance of uncertainty, catastrophizing, and adverse childhood experiences, which will add to the understanding of phenotypes among patients with urinary urgency as a primary symptom.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epstein-Barr Virus and Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) modulate human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs) within the cell they infect. This grant investigates how these activities intersect and synergize to promote the development of lymphoma in people living with HIV, and how translated HERV products could create neoantigenic targets for immune attack in diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

PHR: Yr20 Supplement Request Narrative CTN-0109 Randomized, placebo-controlled trial of extended-release naltrexone and monthly extended-  release buprenorphine for cocaine use disorder (CURB-2) Currently there are no pharmaceutical treatments for cocaine use disorder (CUD). This study is an 8-week, double-blind, randomized placebo-controlled trial to determine the efficacy of a combination of extended- release naltrexone and extended-release buprenorphine compared to placebo injections for the treatment of CUD.  Yr20 Supplement Request Narrative CTN-0132 Randomized, Double-Blind, Active Placebo-Controlled Trial of Ketamine for  Methamphetamine Use Disorder (KMD) Currently there are no pharmaceutical treatments for methamphetamine use disorder (MUD). This study is a 12-week randomized, double-blind, controlled trial comparing intravenous (IV) ketamine against IV midazolam, delivered over six weeks in adults with moderate to severe methamphetamine use disorder (MUD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Protect Narrative The overall survival rate of oral cancer has only marginally improved in the last few decades due to its late diagnosis. This project aims to use a combination of gene expression, immune cell profiling, and clinical information to identify biomarkers to predict the development of oral cancer from pre-malignant oral lesions. By identifying these markers, it is possible to more accurately predict which premalignant lesions are at risk of progressing to cancer to provide guidance to clinicians for appropriate management with a concomitant reduction in oral cancer morbidity and mortality.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: This K26 grant is for support of Dr. Michal L. Melamed in her mentoring of the next generation of Pediatric and Adult Kidney Health researchers. Dr. Melamed is an award- winning mentor with a long history of successfully mentoring individuals from Diverse Backgrounds. This award will allow her to devote more time to mentoring multiple trainees, including individuals from groups Underrepresented in Medicine, into academic careers in clinical research in Kidney Health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Hazardous drinking is a large and growing problem for Veterans across age groups. Many Veterans with hazardous drinking and other mental health problems seek care in the Emergency Department (ED). This study is a randomized controlled trial (N=450) of an alcohol intervention starting in the VHA ED with peer support personnel delivering brief alcohol advice, combined with a continuing 6-session program of post-ED strengths-based peer mentorship to facilitate reductions in alcohol use and to link Veterans with alcohol problems to needed primary and specialty care including other needed services such as homeless outreach and case management where needed. If successful, the proposed study will provide key data on the effectiveness of using peer support specialists in the VHA to help Veterans with hazardous drinking who may have difficulty engaging in needed care that potentially improve their mental and physical health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Integrase stand transfer inhibitors (InSTI), in particular dolutegravir and bictegravir, are potent, safe, well- tolerated drugs used for the treatment of HIV infection, but we do not yet fully know how to use them in patients with HIV and tuberculosis. Drug interactions with rifampicin, a key first-line tuberculosis drug, reduces exposures to these drugs and may reduce their efficacy, so we will therefore study whether increasing the doses of these drugs can overcome drug interactions and will be safe and effective for the treatment of HIV infection. Specifically, we will examine drug exposures, safety and efficacy of dolutegravir when given twice daily (double dose) to children (20-35kg) with HIV and TB on rifampicin to provide an evidence-base for the use of this drug in this subpopulation, and we will test twice-daily bictegravir/ /emtricitabine/tenofovir alafenamide (BIC/TAF/FTC) in adults with HIV taking tuberculosis treatment to ensure drug concentration and efficacy targets are met.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE In response to the lack of scalable, personalized support for family caregivers of people with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD related Dementias (AD/ADRD), our company, Plans4Care, Inc, proposes a Fast-Track SBIR to build and test a digital platform that delivers personalized care plans to caregivers on a smartphone, tablet or computer. A novel clinical algorithm links >50 care challenges to >1,000 nonpharmacological strategies to generate a personalized care plan that provides disease education and specific strategies to address care challenges and access to telephone sessions with a care advisor as needed. Standardized measures will assess feasibility, acceptability and utility in Phase I, while a randomized trial with 160 caregivers enrolled through primary care will evaluate its effectiveness to improve caregiver wellbeing and reduce health care utilization of people with AD/ADRD in Phase II.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Though higher education is a strong social determinant of lower risk of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), large Black-White inequities in ADRD persist among college educated adults. Given that the majority of ADRD studies are comprised of White adults, we must consider educational risk factors that uniquely impact Black Americans to address this disparity, specifically Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). This proposed research will advance our understanding of early life exposure to HBCUs as a source of cognitive resilience for Black adults and potential target for future interventions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain and Alzheimer’s Disease are related, major health concerns and that have increasing evidence supporting their overlapping etiologies and pathologies, and there is an urgent need to understand the mechanisms contributing to the development of these comorbid conditions as the population ages. Epigenetic modifications contributing to immune system dysfunction have been highlighted as a critical factor contributing to both chronic pain and AD/ADRD development. The proposed work will elucidate nutrigenomic mechanisms associated with related to pain and cognition, assess nutritional supplementation on epigenetic mechanisms related to pain and cognitive decline in older adults, and findings will have strong implications for advancement of pain management and AD/ADRD prevention strategies in older adult populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Valley Fever is a fungal disease that causes mortality and morbidity across a large range of the western United States. Our work will lead to a better understanding of the fungal infective process, which will help in the development of prevention, therapeutic, and diagnostic strategies. Our ultimate goal is the development of a highly efficacious nucleic acid vaccine to provide protection against Valley Fever.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertension is an important risk factor for the development of heart disease, stroke, and kidney disease that affects greater than 40% of the population in the United States. Many hypertensive patients, especially African Americans, exhibit sensitivity to salt. Exaggerated stimulation of ion transporters in the kidney of these individuals increases the retention of salt, which heightens elevations in blood pressure associated with an increase in dietary salt intake. Our study will determine the mechanisms that regulate an intratubular TNF system that is activated in renal epithelial cells in response to increases in dietary salt intake and attenuates salt-dependent increases in blood pressure.

PHR: Projective Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and age-associated neurodegenerative disorders are a major public health concern. The proposed studies aim to further develop squirrel monkeys as a model species for studies on cognitive aging and their potential associations with neurological and pathological changes in the central nervous system. Further development of primate models for studies on AD pathology and related dementias will provide new and alternative avenues of therapeutic interventions with increased translational value compared to other model species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Many people think of type 1 diabetes as an autoimmune disease of the insulin-producing cells of the pancreas, however, the exocrine pancreas, which is involved in digestion, is also substantially impacted. The primary goal of this project is to determine when in the development of type 1 diabetes the exocrine pancreas becomes affected and whether stool or blood exocrine pancreas markers predict the onset of type 1 diabetes in those who are at risk. The secondary goal of this project is to investigate what is specifically causing the exocrine pancreas changes seen in type 1 diabetes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Immunosuppressive conditions, such as HIV infection, may play a major role in SARS-CoV-2 transmission and emergence of variants of concern. We will use advanced molecular methods to determine the effect of HIV infection on SARS-CoV-2 evolution and epidemiology in a high HIV-prevalent country. Information from our study could be used to develop interventions to prevent and prepare for emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The comorbidity between substance abuse and mood disorders is an ongoing challenge for the mental health field, with a need for improved understanding of the mechanisms underlying these comorbid illnesses. The goal of this project is to identify the role of L-type calcium channels (LTCC) in mediating mood disorder phenotypes after repeated cocaine or repeated stress exposure. This work in rodent models will address a significant gap in current scientific understanding, will identify mechanisms by which LTCC blockade produces antidepressant and anxiolytic effects, and will provide a strong foundation for future clinical and therapeutic focused investigations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The role of the pancreatic b-cell is to secrete insulin in response to glucose. Defects in this process can result in inadequate insulin secretion causing diabetes or excessive insulin secretion causing hyperinsulinism. The goal of this project is to understand how the same mutations in the transcription factor HNF1a can cause both of these opposing diseases through disruption at different points along the insulin secretion cascade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD4+ T cells from Cftr deficient mice have recently been shown to have increased CD4+ Th2 cytokine production, and our preliminary studies suggest CFTR may function as a GATA3 responsive negative regulator of CD4+ Th2 polarization and effector function. In this proposal, we will use CD4+ T cells from mice and humans, a murine in vivo allergen model of Th2 inflammation, and electronic health record data to investigate the mechanisms of CFTR in Th2 inflammation and test whether CFTR modulation can reduce allergic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major obstacle to rational HIV-1 vaccine design is the lack of an outbred primate animal model where the induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) can be achieved in a consistent and reproducible manner and the molecular events leading to bNAb elicitation deciphered. This application proposes a novel “reverse vaccinology” strategy to overcome this roadblock leading to new immunogen designs and a pivotal proof-of-concept preclinical immunogenicity and protection trial in rhesus macaques. This trial will test the ability of a germline-targeted Q23.17 SOSIP Env prime, followed by lineage-designed Q23.17 SOSIP Env trimer boosts, to elicit bNAbs that protect monkeys from a heterologous tier 2 virus challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Humans with IgE sensitization to the mammalian oligosaccharide allergen galactose-a-1,3- galactose (a-gal) have larger coronary artery plaques and unstable plaque features signifying increased coronary artery disease (CAD) compared to those without IgE to a-gal. However, the causal role of IgE to a-gal in CAD is unknown. The proposed research seeks to understand whether IgE to a-gal directly promotes atherosclerotic plaque development and define immune mechanisms mediating IgE sensitization to a-gal linked to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in mice and humans.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NICHD established the Neonatal Research Network to investigate persistent unanswered questions regarding the safety and efficacy of treatment and management strategies for newborn infants. A Data Coordinating Center (DCC) provides essential expertise to such a large multicenter research enterprise by ensuring rigorous and consistent standards for study design, development, data collection, and data analyses. The DCC also provides objective statistical expertise for formulating, designing, and analyzing studies (especially, masked randomized trials and monitoring thereof), and coordinates communications, regulatory and logistical support across diverse clinical centers, both inside and outside the Network.
